atmospheric and and everything is reverb Dan just huge and an arena sized and it just kind of feels like the start screen to a Super Nintendo game and it really sets the mood on the second track it g-funk vocoder vocals and these really really kind of scattered beats twittering away in the background and a lot of these tracks have these really quick fast high energy loud build ups before they drop into a heavy beat like we and then this drop comes in kind of like a dubstep tune but the wobbling bass isn't there a funk beat or a two-step beat is there instead and there are also moments on here on catching a really strong hip-hop flavor like the song City Star where man just just the drum programming really reminds me of something Lex Luger would do maybe I could see somebody like Rick what if I was like Anthony Fantana hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd time for a review of the new Feist LP metals this is going to be a kind of weird review because Feist's new album Feist Leslie Feist Canadian singer-songwriter this is her new LP follow-up to the reminder very big record sold hundreds of thousands of copies and launched her into the acclaimed contemporary female singer-songwriters status that she enjoys today and this is a weird feeling because most albums I kind of feel like I listen to them over and over and over and I kind of get to know them just just blanks become filled in slowly one after another and I guess right now I know how I feel about this record I don't really like it but I'm not 100% sure why I do kind of know why I feel like this album drags on forever but it's not because it's quiet it's not because nothing happens actually I think this album is louder than Feist's last LP which also had that you know broke pop chamber pop element to some of the tracks on there but this this LP comes on even heavier with the extra instrumentation so the dragging for me is is definitely not for lack of things occurring and this album is not longer than the last album either what has kind of shifted on this LP is is the mood I know it's been four years about four years and spiced has come out with their last album but it actually kind of feels like 50 because the reminder felt so fresh and so young and just so vibrant to this by comparison is is really dreary worn tired old it's a series of songs that kind of feel like they have nowhere to be and nowhere to go actually I would say this album sounds exactly like the cover looks a really gray desolate landscape there's no life in any direction as far as you can see and there's nothing to look at except a giant wooden F and all I can think is what am I doing here to me a lot of these tracks wander really really wander wander with vocal melodies that that don't feel all that memorable wander aimlessly in the in the sea of instrumentation that's been arranged around these songs also while we're on the instrumentation on this album I think the kind of tired and worn emotions that are showcased on this LP really get out shined by the strings and the horns and the woodwinds it's to the point where I will get really bored with a track until I hear an instrumental swell or something and then some emotion will hit me take the second track for example I think the instrumental swell toward the end of that song is way more interesting than anything that happened to before it in a way this album does feel more mature than the reminder to me definitely definitely but it just kind of makes this album feel old when I'm listening to this album I kind of feel like I'm a four-year-old kid and I'm bugging my grandpa this album to come play let's go let's play yeah let's play yeah yeah and he's all like no I'm watching the crashes rap I long to get up some of you guys may remember my review of how come you never go there a little earlier this year and I'd like that song like by itself I think that's one of Feist's better vocal deliveries on this album and there are other spots on here that don't feel weighted down in all this heavy instrumentation and in a song a focused clear-cut song really kind of shines out I'm thinking of a track like the sixth track bittersweet melodies a lot of the other songs on here don't feel complex or complicated to me they just kind of feel like the Feist I'm usually used to hearing but kind of smothered in molasses while I do like some of these tracks separately I feel like listening to them from really becomes a very tiring gauntlet for me kind of an unrewarding gauntlet in some ways maybe this album is is fitting as a fall album but it's not the kind of picturesque fall day that that one would imagine it's more like a day where all the leaves are dead and have fallen off all the trees and the sky is gray and the wind is blowing hard enough to give you frostbite so yeah I didn't like this I'm kind of feeling like a strong for decent too strong for on this but you know I would love to read somebody's comment below telling me why you like this album or loved it if in fact you didn't love it and and that's it man y'all know this is just my opinion but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana Feist forever you you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd time for an EP review the new James Blake enough Thunder I've reviewed this guy earlier this year English music producer touched down on his self-titled LP I think as far as electronic music goes blake has some of the more interesting ideas out there right now however if his discography so far is is any proof I don't think James Blake likes focusing on one single thing even if that single thing is a good idea and a fresh idea the self-titled LP was much different than the EPS that had come out before it and the LP itself is loaded with a ton of different sounds and styles on there an acoustic guitar ballad piano ballads a dubstep Feist cover drones auto-tune lots of multitrack vocals lots of keyboards he's always trying something different even if that something ends up being not that good or a song that is very unpleasing to his fans I mean look at the order panned single that came out after the self-titled LP which is a kind of alienating transition for anybody who jumped on the bandwagon when they heard songs like the Wilhelm scream sure some people on the internet found out that you could take both sides of that single and combine them into kind of a different song but my point still stands now of course enough Thunder is a different direction to this thing kind of concentrates a little bit on the piano ballad Rhee that was on the self-titled album and if you guys remember from my review that was maybe my least favorite part of the LP the part that kind of left me wanting more where I was really underwhelmed but on here James Blake is making a serious effort to try to improve upon this kind of piano playing singer-songwriter side of him just take the opening track from this with these really lonesome open vast piano chords and vocals there they're both kind of slathered in this atmospheric reverb and the song doesn't really have a clear structure or direction or anything it just kind of like repeats this one melodic idea to the point where it becomes kind of hypnotic like a mantra something that blake was doing on the full-length but there's something kind of off about the track and that's the miscellaneous electronic is kind of surrounding the vocals and and the piano those little low-end rumbles and the and the I feel like these sounds kind of interrupt more than they actually add but the song not long now I think is is the best combination of these two worlds the acoustic piano world and these electronics that Blake is trying to incorporate but the song kind of shoots itself in the foot a little bit toward the end when this beat comes in and it just doesn't feel like it comes together the piano and the vocals kind of remain unchanged the beat just appears and it ends up sounding like two different songs playing at once I just kind of like scrambled and wondered if there was something wrong with my copy of this EP the only songs on this thing that I liked were the straight-up piano and vocal tracks especially a case of you which has some very loving and tender lyrics but of course before I finish this review I have to I have to talk about the song Fall Creek Boys Choir the first track to drop from this EP of course a collaboration with Bon Iver a lot of people were freaking out about this song when it first hit the Internet and I'll give it to him it doesn't sound much like anything else I've heard this year sure it does remind me of of the final moments of bony bear's new album it does remind me of some spots on Blake's full length but this definitely hit a new level of something now first off with this track I like the melody I like the melody a lot actually I think it's the one grand thing about this track the drum fills aren't bad the piano is nice but what's over it is about half a dozen auto-tune Bon Iver voices layered into a couple casserole of ugliness and part of me finds it kind of intriguing but only in like a Frankenstein monster kind of way like this is a serious kind of musical mutant so for me this IP it's it's a kind of a different direction for Blake if you've heard the full length you're not going to be completely surprised by what you hear on this thing it just kind of goes further down a road that he's toyed with before what hurt Blake's full-length album in my opinion is that there were too many moments that felt like just loose sketches and ungroomed ideas this EP a majority of it feels like that so I'm kind of feeling like a strong four to a light five on this thing but what did you guys think of it did you like it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next you have any Fantana James Blake enough Thunder forever

La Dispute Wildlife hello my needle drops Anthony fan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review these easy these guys are a Michigan band second album and I think my first reaction to them was up pretty bad pretty negative I heard them in a blog TV and I I think I just felt like their music was annoying overly dramatic overly emotional whiny but since they put out this sophomore album I've been listening to it and I've I've done a bit of a 180 with these guys now these dudes get labeled as post hardcore a lot but don't worry this is not your crappy average modern post hardcore where you get the kind of scream vocals and then you get a dime-a-dozen kind of breakdown right after and then right after that you get all these really cheap sugary ultra clean vocals kind of swooping in like when I'm listening to bands who do vocals like that it's like listening to a million nyan cats all fly into the music at once crapping rainbows in every direction instead this is some of the most raw urgent and emotionally intense rock music you're going to hear this year I think to start off with the production I think it sounds great the guitars are sounding fantastic on this LP they're heavy they're loud they're blaring when these guys reach like mountainous climaxes but also they have very quiet subtle moments to where the guitars just go soft and don't lose their flavor in the process these guys have a lot of dynamics and all of their energy translates perfectly through this record sometimes it doesn't even feel like I'm listening to a record it just feels like I'm listening to these guys play live in the studio just sort of like really in the moment now the bass and drum sound great they play a lot of fantastic grooves on this LP and I can actually hear the based on here which I like a lot and the vocals are in an amazing spot on this thing they are so audible I hear almost everything they're saying but yet they don't feel too much louder than the rest of the music musically I think this LP is pretty pretty good too it's very ambitious for a rock album of of any styles to me these guys remind me of some of my favorite old-school post-hardcore bands or emo bands or screamo bands like like rites of spring like Fugazi because they have this very raw going to use that word again intensity to them energy to them but they have this more modern and and musically and emotionally and lyrically complex side of them that is totally within the new school of post-hardcore that's been around ever since bands like refused and at the drive-in sort of made it big yeah some of the pounding buildups do sound a little Sammy Sammy on a few tracks but overall the guitars the bass the drums are just this perfect backdrop the perfect dramatic backdrop for the vocals the lyrics the stories on this thing and now we got to talk about vocals because I think these are what is going to make it or or break it for a lot of you guys on this album the frontman for the span Jordan Dreyer I believe his name is he is so bold and emotive and sincere with everything he says on this album this dude's lyrics are very wordy and very very specific there's tons of imagery in everything he's saying which makes me kind of feel like I'm watching a movie when I listen to some of these tracks because when I'm following this dude's words I'm thinking of all the things he's saying like st. Paul Missionary Baptist Church blues where he kind of just paints a picture of this church going into just major major disrepair losing its congregation and kind of likening his loss of love for living and just his interest for life to that kind of faltering Church or Edward Benz 27 times where he tells a story about this the schizophrenic kid on pills and and there's a really intense like twist ending at the track I see everything where he's just talking about this cancer patient and kind of giving the the the progress of his deterioration over these specific dates or probably the biggest song on here King Park where it's a track about a drive-by shooting and eventually ends with with a standoff with police that gets pretty what's important is that this album didn't make me feel like oh I relate by you know kind of being really vague about the situations it discusses it made me feel like oh I understand because it's so specific and so detailed this album is kind of like an emotional exorcism for me I imagine it is for the guys playing in this band a lot of these vocals are just shouted screamed whispered narrated it's not just singing or or fronting for the band but it's its acting this this album has a lot of stuff kind of beating down on it but it's determined to survive to the next day to a day when things are better when things are nicer I'm feeling a decent too strong eight on this a lot of flavor to this what do you think about this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana why dispute forever [Music] you

dippity-doo hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's coolest music nerd time for an album review you you you these guys are a Texas band this is their third LP and on this album they're feeling like a fresh new group but I will start off this review by saying that this may be their last album and this album was recorded almost two years ago it's just being released this year that's all this band's older albums most people have labeled as indie rock I would agree with that and I think this LP kind of fits into that same category but the mood and the personality are kind of different on this I think the previous two records I think we're kind of upbeat and kind of lively a lot of shouting in the vocals but this thing is very listless kind of depressing bit of a slacker attitude this album feels really kind of tired of the monotony of life or maybe it's just beat down from laying in the Texas Sun all day in the lyrics and the vocals this LP just has this really cynical attitude toward life and everything it has to offer and is just loaded with punchlines that make me laugh but then right after I kind of let out a depressing sigh and the reason this is a mood changing album to me the reason I think the personality of this album changed is because the frontman Andrew savages personality kind of altered for this record and what changed about savages delivery as a frontman is he's singing in a lower register his lyrics I think are a little bit darker something that you might have picked up on an LP that he was on that I reviewed earlier this year Ferguson Geronimo's on learn and that LP definitely has a huge emphasis on on satire and being funny and just making some interesting observations this concentrates more on being a damn rock album I don't want to call it a recording on this thing the mix it's really thick it's really loud it it they're an indie band but they got that punk band volume and they reach that aggression to on a track like zealous convert where they're making a lyrical jab at religion and playing at a faster speed and while we're sort of mentioning the lyrics the lyrics are another thing that kind of make this album pretty moody for me references to atheism and shoplifting and friends who you haven't seen in a long time and karaoke and and rebellious bands becoming trends this album feels like to me a good friend of mine who you could just hang out with and just talk with for hours you know just like be nasty with but you know you don't want to be around them all the time or else you know you might kind of lose your positive outlook on life if you have one another kind of issue I have with this LP is that I don't feel like there's anything really new here musically I feel like there's a really good recording on this LP oh well oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review wilco the whole love I'm finally reviewing this all I needed was just you know a little personal time to go back and revisit some older albums in Wilko land and I would try to give you some background on these guys but I'm just going to let kal George s to do that before we start off this review thank you anything at the wilcos is a group of reck musicians and they release albums on a regular basis and their first album came first before all the other albums that they have released now their newest album is newer it came after all of their older albums which were released before this album believe it or not that that might have been his most accurate band introduction to date alright so new Wilco album Wilco sadly is is another one of those groups whose new material is constantly getting shot down by haters and by fans because their older stuff is praised so highly wilcos new stuff gets labeled as dad rock they get called out constantly for not being as experimental as they used to be and even though I think this new LP goes against some of those stereotypes this album will probably not shake anybody who's been saying that stuff even though this album is much louder and much bolder than sky blue sky most of the time even though this album to me is as experimental as a ghost is born in some points even though this album is is way noisier and Messier and more experimental than the self-titled LP even though this LP finishes off with a heavily arranged 12 minute piece of alternative country and even though the opening track has these rising strings in this heavy be in all these electronic textures that kind of remind me of Radiohead's last album all that stuff will probably not shake naysayers because people love being right and if anybody decides to just like opt out of listening to this that's fine let them because I thought this was a fun listen Wilco has really gotten their act together again and assembled a series of really catchy fun straightforward pop rock tunes that I think longtime fans if they're open to it and newcomers can enjoy the LP starts with a kind of impressive opener like I mentioned earlier that Radiohead kind of similarity there between the strings and the beats and the electronics it's a really impressive piece of studio work and I know Wilco isn't exactly known for this sound but they sound so comfortable doing it the only spot I wasn't in love with on that track was toward the end where they really sounded like they were playing their asses off but the mix is kind of thin and not all that great it didn't feel it didn't feel aggressive it just felt like the guitars could have just been pumped up a little bit too mmm add some herb then maybe it would have blown me away you know it wasn't a fantastic ending but I thought it was still pretty decent track and pretty ambitious but after that song it's just clear sailing for country ballads power pop tunes and psychedelic popery just really good songs with great personality melodies that just stick in my head as a band I just think Wilco showcases a lot of charisma on this record which is why I'm kind of able to see past the fact that most of these songs really where their influences on their sleeves on the song I might there's this organ that sounds totally like it should have been on that classic garage rock tune ninety-six tears the song son loathe has this really Beatles esque psychedelic pop atmosphere with these rising vocals in the background that kind of remind me of the song because from Abbey Road and the song capital city to reminds me a little bit the beetles like when they would play these tunes that featured a lot of like pre-war jazz chords like when I'm 64 or honey-pie and the song dawned on me I think has the most borrowed melody out of any song on this album the melody sounds like Madonna's like a virgin it sounds like super grasses alright doodyhead we listen for you thank you the songs open mind and born alone have melodies that sound really familiar to me and standing O has an introduction that you've probably heard in a million rock songs still wilcos really great production and sincerity and just ability to rock some of these ideas out make hearing them all over again kind of worth it it makes these ideas kind of feel like shiny and new again like a virgin now my favorite moments on this LP are the upbeat tracks and thankfully there's a lot of those to be had on this I mean Wilco has really kind of turned up the energy on some of these songs I know these guys are no Punk band but they have not kicked this much ass in their songs since like the 90s I might just has these really wailing guitars and pounding drums and Jeff Tweedy sounds like so energized with his vocals and when the hook comes on it's just this swell of glockenspiel and acoustic guitar and organ and drums and it just sounds really really friggin messy but it's also fun too they're going more for this energy thing as opposed to this you know refined kind of thing to me all the upbeat songs kind of share that that characteristic dawned on me standing OH it's energetic but innocent it's like drawing all over the walls with crayons and shit now the slower tracks and the softer tracks on here they're decent I'll listen to them but they don't get me going as much as much as the faster moments and it's not necessarily because they're softer it's just that songs sort of like black moon for example are wrapped up in the same kind of you know generic instrumental arrangements that that made sky blue sky so kind of under well I guess the softer tracks on here copied just as many ideas as the more upbeat tracks but for some reason they just don't sound as interesting to me wilcos softer and darker and sadder side is usually what gets people talking what gets people freaking out but those songs on this record just don't have as much impact for me songs like the title track on this LP are the ones that just have this really feel good fuzzy mood to them and I think they come off the most successful and I think that's a great thing especially for Wilco a band that's usually known for the opposite plus I think a lot of groups kind of go for that aesthetic they try to make something upbeat they try to make something sweet and fun but it ends up just sounding too sugary and Wilco does you know have some sweetness to them on this LP but they kind of even that edge out so there's no sugar rush by making things a little noisy a little experimental a little sweaty I didn't hate anything on this LP but there were a good handful of tracks on here they're just kind of breezed by me and don't hold my attention especially the last song which which I don't think justifies it's it's 12 minute length with enough changes in my opinion but still I thought this is a pretty good record I hey everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd going to review this new 9th wonder LP the Wonder Years 9th wonder is a huge hip hop producer must be known if you're a hip hop fan you consistently kind of stays in tune with both sides of the aisle he's worked with giants like jay-z Destiny's Child Erykah Badu and he's nowhere near fading and relevancy because he's working with current people - like Drake and Chris Brown the dudes come out with great collaborative albums - with MERS and one you definitely have to check out with Jean Grey genius that in his early work and the group little brother make him an underground hip hop legend as well now his beats are heavily heavily dependent on soul a very warm sound and the guy has come out with solo albums before but I was hoping that the Wonder Years would maybe be something a little different at first considering the first track which is kind of a retrospective of of ninth one ninth one 9th wonders career and the title of this album and kind of the the old worn look of the the cover I was hoping this would be kind of a retrospective you know of what brought 9th - where he is today and in the way kind of is because this album is is littered with pretty much the emcees that he's met along the way in his producer journey of course MERS and Fonte a lot of emcees he's close with are on this album but he's got members of wu-tang on here and tons of up-and-comers which I like a lot for Sean kendrick lamar's on here as well Mac Miller is on here in MC who he worked on a mixtape with recently - Tom Rd every track has different feature every track has a different flavor and it all kind of adds up to nothing more than a light casual come whatever time you want to party there are some party snacks some good conversation a few drinks maybe you'll meet a couple people you think are cool but it's not really one of these crazy all out unforgettable parties that that everybody's gonna be talking about tomorrow and there will be some incriminating photos uploaded onto Facebook and because of that this has a very smooth ambience to it but also nobody on this thing is really bringing the heat there's little to no aggression on this thing the few MCS that do kind of come hard stick out like a sore thumb but you know is that surprising it's not like 9th wonders beats are all that conducive of a cypher or something like that and a good chunk of the songs on this thing of love songs I mean overall I like the beats on this thing they're pretty good but it's just the the guest MCS either they're not that great and they're just underwhelming me or their MCS that I really really respect but they're definitely not bringing some of the best material I've ever heard them bring I did like Raekwon on here MERS was pretty good Vontae was great but for the most part the mcs that stuck out to me the most on this mixtape were the ones that were younger the ones that had kind of something to prove out of all the love songs on this thing I think the only one I liked was actually Mac Miller's because his was not only cute but kind of immature and had a funny twist ending and was really kind of self-aware saying yeah love songs they're corny but everybody falls in love there have been other LPS where producers have sort of had the power to kind of cherry pick their favorite MCS produce a bunch of different tracks and then sort of feature them on whatever songs they like mad libs done it Jake one has done it but the thing is those two LPS to me aren't all that fantastic for the same reasons that this one doesn't feel all that fantastic as much as I may like a good handful of the tracks on here there are so many that just that just lose me and I think it's gonna feel that way to a it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan out ninth wonder forever

Oh oh it's so beautiful it's a double rainbow ah ah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's koulos Taemin coldest music nerd and it's time for an album review J Cole Cole world the sideline story oh oh I love albums with colons in the title ah Cal calmly calls Cole's : cool crazy chick rock J Cole is a rapper producer singer who's recently been signed to jay-z's record label Roc Nation it's his first official release for a while he's been putting out mixtapes and little EPS kind of you know finding his sound and his style and for the most part this new LP is everything that he's he's been doing but he's kind of going big time with it I mean he's really kind of come a long way from sounding kind of generic and really murky in 2007 now a lot of the students lyrics are about struggling and coming from nothing and making it in the rap game and you know we've all heard that angle before but he you know kind of peppers his lyrics with flashes of social awareness and now that he's kind of hitting the big time he's no longer rapping about how he wants money and he wants girls now it's more like he has money and he has girls let's start with the production on this thing I first heard of J Cole when he was producing for one of my favorite rap albums of this year Kendrick Lamar section.80 he made the beat for high power and damn such a good beat and the thing is like anybody who makes a beat that good must be checked out so I had to check him out J Cole shines the most as a producer and I think jay-z how he signed rapper producer Kanye in the early 2000s he's now trying a little bit to kind of create that magic for the most part the beats here are really cinematic the sideline story because of the instrumentals feels like a story rising string sections and glistening pianos and cymbal swells and that's only on the first two tracks the dudes got a pretty diverse array of sounds throughout this album I like the really heavy just like bumping electronics on coal world I like the chill guitar and organ sampled on nobody's perfect where Missy Elliott is featured there are these giant epic pitch shifted choruses on rise and shine and these quivering like heart-wrenching vocals in the background on God's gift and I love the Latin music sample on can't get enough I know Jay Cole did not produce that particular track on the album but still it's on here and it sounds good the dudes even bring him back oldschool boom-bap beats that are littered with soul and jazz piano like lights please lost ones sideline story Jay Cole really knows how to set the mood musically he knows what sounds kind of should be paired with what messages and ideas and that's really important but the thing is Jay Cole is a rapper is really kind of where I end up wanting more I feel I feel I feel I feel like he has great ideas great tastes and a story and a message but half of the time all he's doing is just reminding me of other rappers I mean he has this really mellow light sad introspective side that really reminds me of Drake a lot where he kind of perceives himself as this character who is famous now but he's still kind of awkward and he doesn't know quite what to do he's kind of feeling weird in this Fame situation where the lights are blinding him and also like Drake he has a lot of stories a lot of lyrics about the ins and outs of bad relationships but I think he goes a little darker with it sometimes especially on tracks like never told and lost ones and I like that and sometimes when he goes hard when he goes in on some of these tracks he reminds me of Kanye West which is something new because I was not getting that vibe from a lot of the tracks on Friday Night Lights one of his last mixtapes I mean it's to the point where it was really like making me mad I couldn't handle the irony of the track Cole world he's rapping all over that song about how other rappers are ripping off his style and about how there's no innovation in the game how can you say that when at the end of almost every one of your lines you're doing this Kanye West growl hey he's going hard and he's got some lyrics but like practice what you preach come on so I'm just kind of sitting here wondering if Cole is going to grow into his own or really just end up copying the styles of other rappers in the future because to me I feel like it could it could go either way at this point because there are a lot of tracks on here that catch me as being of a personality that is only his like lights please where he's rapping about being in this relationship that's really sexual relationship it's hot but it kind of distracts him from deeper thoughts and pursuits sidelined story God's gift dollar in a dream part three those songs hit me is just being really really personal just all him in the song breakdown oh yes that song is bold I don't hear more songs like that more because man he just like tells this story about how his his relationship with his father is just non-existent it's terrible and I've heard a lot of rappers attack this angle before but man he hit the nail on the head he just made me feel for him on that track I wanted to cry just kind of like battling this this hatred for his father but this you know this insane need to have a dad and a track that feels even bolder than that one to me is lost ones we're such a weird concept but follow me he basically raps from the perspective of an irresponsible male who gets his girlfriend pregnant doesn't know what to do is saying we can't take care of this kid we're kids this is insane but then in the second verse he starts rapping from the perspective of the girl he got pregnant how many rappers do that it was kind of weird at first but it actually works he paints a really detailed story and he really gets into the character it does not sound like him when I first heard this track I thought it was a feature track and I'm like who's this other guy rapping from the perspective of this girl it was him acting I'm hearing spots on here that are really exciting and unique and I just want more but then Jay Cole will just turn around and do a song like mr. nice watch and come on if you've heard that song let's admit it that is a throw away from Watch the Throne come on the electronic be the Kanye level cockiness Jay Z even comes on for a feature and has the balls to recycle the same flow he used on him now as far as lyrics go for the most part Cole has him but sometimes he doesn't I got the game in headlock I'm red-hot and here's a good one I'm here I'm there I'm everywhere they're not these might pass in 1982 but not 2011 I let you feel like you're the but boy you can't out fart me got a hundred fifty bitches in the club starin at me how that feel very happy it's like it's like waka flocka flame your ghostwriter not to mention that you could probably start a drinking game at this album oriented around how many times Kol uses his name in place of the word cold the moments on here where Cole is being really introspective being his intelligent self those are the moments I like the most where he's just being creative he's trying new things he's rapping from the perspective of a pregnant girl I like that he's just challenging other rappers abilities by doing something different the party money girl tracks are kind of where he loses me and not because I'm against those kinds of tracks in general but because when he does that stuff he just ends up sounding like somebody else he doesn't sound like himself I have a that bad not good hi everyone Anthony Fantana the Internet's baddest music nerd right here going to do a review of the new bad bad not good LP a lot of you may have seen that today this YouTube channel is featured on the front page of youtube.com and maybe y'all are wondering maybe y'all are speculating ain't nothing changing around here hmm just going to write a reminder that everything is going to stay the same I'm even going to put this reminder in a bag where I keep very important reminders right here these guys are a Canadian jazz trio this is their self-titled self-released album and to simply call them just jazz is a little bit of a lie this is not the bebop that you remember from the 1950s and these guys don't want it to be there's a funny quote at heum at the end of this album I think it's the drummer talking his name is Alex and it starts off with a question it says Alex what do you think of giant steps and Alex says something to the note of it's 50 years old it sounds like crap write a new song I know those are harsh words for a beloved standard but I think musicians on some level have to kind of have that attitude or else they're not going to propel themselves past what influences them it's important to have influences and understand where things were to understand where things are but what's the point of rehashing the same ideas the same exact way again and again and again another example for me is is is in punk music classic punk music I mean I'm a huge punk fan but if you told me that for the rest of my life I would never hear the songs blitzkrieg bop anarchy in the UK or I'm so bored with the USA again I think I'd be okay with that and it's because I want to hear something new you know it's like I've heard those tracks so many times it's like I know them like the back of my hand bad bad not good has the same attitude about jazz and it's not like jazz has stopped or anything like that there is new jazz music out there that's pretty good but the has a lot of jazz these days is now kind of being marketed to and tailored for in adult contemporary audience the jazz listener base is not as young as it used to be bands like bad bad not good I think could change that up this is jazz infused with electronics infused with hip-hop music as well it's not that new of a sound or concept because hip-hop in a lot of ways has always reflected a jazz influence the Tribe Called Quest J Dilla diggable planets DJ premier Madlib the roots Kid Koala the Beastie Boys to the list of hip-hop artists that have sampled or referenced jazz music in their music goes on forever but we've got to admit that if we were going to make a list of jazz musicians who have celebrated hip hop the list is going to be much shorter the link between hip hop and jazz already exists what I like about this album is that bad bad not good makes this street seemed more like a two-way street not just a one way street so what makes this LP jazz what makes it hip-hop well first off these three guys piano bass drums together they just show a lot of great musicianship there are a lot of great improvisation to enjoy on this LP and they just play off of each other so well you've got really intense moments like the improvised Jam that I think is track 3 these guys really bring that track to some some hot and heavy climaxes and then they're just as good at creating quiet subtle moments to like the beginning of fall in love with this really moody modal intro that song just sounds like a beautiful delicate shiny ice sculpture to me and the solos are so good at some of these points just looked like fun to listen to you know you don't have to sit there and be like ooh this is just I love listening to this drummer the intro track I could just like hear this guy all day is just rocking this great B and as far as some of the piano solos go look at one of the final tracks on this album sorry is song where the melody he's playing on that he is cradling it like it's a baby he's just so gentle with the melody on that track I love it and the bass player is really great as well another moment toward the end of the album he's playing the lead melody on the song and I did not see that coming most of this LP is nothing but recreations of popular hip hop instrumentals and I know on paper conceptually that seems a little gimmicky but the thing is I don't see why these dudes play with so much sincerity they're taking songs relevant to them and reinventing them so what's relevant to these guys Gang Starr not old dirty bastard Joy Division slum village Flying Lotus and the soundtrack to Legend of Zelda's ocarina of time now I'm not trying to say this album is perfect I do think some reinterpretations go over better than others there takes on slum villages fall in love gang stars mass appeal and nas's the world is yours I think are the best tracks on here the electric pianos are just glistening the drums are hard and heavy and just pushing these fat hip hop beats and the bass is just got this really nice round obese sound I think the only reinterpretation that I didn't like all that much was flying lotuses camel and the reason I didn't care for it all that much is because they don't jam on it really for the most part they're just really recreating the song instrumentally which is the feat in and of itself if you've heard that Flying Lotus track and as long as I'm complaining I wish there was more original material on here one of my favourite tracks is an original on this list eerie osis and that song just has like these escalating tense piano chords over this boom that beat it feels like just like running up an endless flight of stairs salmonella listeria says I get it guys funny there's kind of an experimentally electronic spot on the song freedom / billion Evans and I like that track it's a nice from the other songs I would totally be interested in not only seeing these guys kind of run further down that trail but maybe combine it with their jazzier elements a little bit more now if this thing were a Christmas tree the star on top of it would be the 10-minute Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time medley I know some of you may be much younger than me or much older than me and because of that you don't quite understand that in the late 90s Nintendo 64 was the shit the Ocarina of Time was like the life of a lot of kids back then mine too to the point where the music of that video game is laced into my childhood so deeply I will probably never forget any of the songs and I've heard a lot of covers a lot of tributes and this ranks among them is one of the best and the reason why to me is because it works outside of the nostalgia you don't have to have played Zelda on the n64 to love that song actually I don't think you need to know any of these songs that these guys are covering to enjoy them because the musicianship is so strong the solos are great the melodies are clear and emotive these guys are having fun playing together so for the listener it's a fun experience to hear I think this LP is a little all over the place but bad bad not good to me is still in a very kind of fetal stage all of their material isn't really coming together and flowing in this one focused direction still despite the fact that this LP is a combination of older and newer material and features a lot of different ideas it flows pretty well so I'm excited about what I'm hearing on this LP I'm excited about what it means for this band what it means for jazz music and what it means for hip-hop and what it means for music fans - I'm feeling a strong 7 - a light 8 on this LP it's brought me many smiles and if you want to hear this thing it's free just go on the band's band camp there's a link below this video you can download the whole thing and once you've heard it or if you've already heard it let me know what you thought of it did you like it did you hate it why and what should I review next thanks for watching and thanks to all my new subscribers for subscribing Anthony Fantino bad bad not good forever [Music] [Music]

mastodons guitars especially on this LP feel more heavy than they do harsh their production is usually pretty bright and smooth and accessible the vocals are usually some clean with a nice harmony in the background it's really hyper melodic - and this has brought a lot of fans but this has also brought some naysayers as well because without a doubt these guys have put a more accessible face on the tracks and 13-minute songs as well but the thing is the accessible angle Mastodon is always kind of stereotyped to play comes out on a new level on the hunter it's really really really gone far this Leviathan that you know left me on the edge of my seat wondering what was gonna happen next tracks like curl the burl don't really hit me like that they don't sound like music that I'm really intently listening to they sound like music that I put on to go do something else it's loud but there's no real intensity there's no real bite to it there's no real urgency to it it does everything that you would expect a radio rock single to do nothing more in order to kind of break things up Mastodon starts throwing in some kitschy sounds on some of these tracks like octopus has no friends where they Oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's wildest music nerd time for an album review of the new Wild Flag album wild flag is a rock outfit from Portland Oregon which made its full-length debut earlier this month now even though these guys are a new band their ranks are filled with indie rock veterans Carrie Brownstein Mary Timoney Rebecca Cole Janet Weiss between the four of them they've worked in the spells sleater-kinney the minders the go-betweens and that's not even like close to the full list of projects that they've been affiliated with and to me they are playing indie rock on this album but it's this really simple fun catchy kind of muscular style of indie rock it's not this cheap glossy pretend happy like stereotype reinforcing brand of indie rock that gets thrown at us all over the internet that of all the group's wild flag is affiliated with I think sleater-kinney is going to warrant the most comparisons especially since Carrie Brownstein is kind of fronting the band but even though those comparisons will be made I don't think this album really leaves off where sleater-kinney did in 2005 with woods which was a really noisy experimental kind of emotionally intense album to me wild flag takes a detour from that intensity and takes just just a more scenic route I think longtime sleater-kinney fans will see parallels between this and an older album like dig me out the faster catch your tracks from that album but still wild flight by comparison is noticeably different to me the post-punk spirit is here but none of the the sorrow or pain or angst it's a terrible word I know but of the angst that fueled some of those sleater-kinney LPS just is not here it shows up a little bit on some of my favourite tracks like boom where Carrie Brownstein is singing in this really kind of eccentric kind of slightly deranged vocal or even future crimes which is a little upset and a little desperate in a way that I like but the thing is for the most part this album really kind of has no tears to shed I mean this album is really in too good of a mood to be depressed or all that self-aware wild flag is writing songs about glass tambourines and electric bands and throwing haze and Yaz and okay's and all rights into their lyrics I could totally see Carrie Brownstein playing these songs live and like doing windmills on her guitar or something that's how upbeat this album feels to me even in its most depressing moments the drums are really sharp and snappy the bass lines have a lot of spunk bunk the organs are kind of quirky and I like that and the guitar leads are just rough and wild they just wail when I first heard this LP I kind of questioned it because of how simple it is you know oh it's you know it's it's so simple it's not really all that intricate but as I listened to it more I kind of ended up enjoying how free of of complications it is there's no weird abstract deeper layer to this album what you see is is what you get and what you get is just a nice attitude and a group of 10 songs that kind of just want to rock and there's a nice variety among these songs too I don't feel like I'm hearing the same song over and over and over these guys write a group of tracks that land around two or three minutes but they could totally just change gears pull out a 6-minute track like racehorse with this drum being guitar riff that reminds me of Fugazi and yet it still sounds good and for the duration of the song they stay engaging there's a consistent sound and style on this the production is pretty good in my opinion I feel like the songs that were on that wild flag 7-inch that came out earlier this year that got reworked for this open you came out pretty good there were moments like something came over me that felt a little underwhelming to me but overall I thought it was a very good debut but I think some fans are gonna look for more from this album considering who is is making it and I and I have to admit I did too a little bit but still what's kind of interesting is that all these members in wild flag kind of seem to have brought themselves back to square one with this band in a good way because they're kind of writing and performing as if this is like their first band almost all the members of wild flag sound really excited to be making this album they sound really energized this album feels really flag forever

Oh path heritage oh you've done an intro like this already hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review and of all the requests that I get all the time this review is kind of become a highly highly anticipated review oh pets heritage now these guys are a Swedish rock band known mostly for their interpretations of progressive metal and progressive death metal but I've never ever ever ever ever been an Opeth fan never their melodic and and to me kind of overproduced take on death metal just has never ever done anything for me I know that's gonna piss some people off because opeth has kind of become over the years through a consistent style and a lot of releases become this metal sacred cow but on this new LP heritage Opeth throws away all death metal and even just metal in general sounds for this record and just makes a really complete and an honest and Breece of progressive rock now it's not like that's anything new for these guys they've done that once before on 2003's damnation and some of the quieter moments on this new LP actually reminds me of 2002's deliverance a little bit at least that's what I think even though Opeth has played in this area before this album is getting a lot of mixed reviews and I'm not completely sure why I'm not a huge fan of this LP either I don't think it's gonna be for the same reasons that Opeth fans are the band's frontman whose name coucher chesta is going to pronounce nikhil Ecker fileted tim has put his death growls away for this album but i don't see how that would ruin it I mean I don't think it's just simply his growls that were bringing opeth fans to the table to me Opeth on this album they're embracing in older shade of progressive rock to me this album is like totally King Crimson it's totally jethro tull it's even a little Mahavishnu it points especially in the drums these these drums on this record are fantastic they're just these jazz fusion drums with these you know hard-hitting rolls and fills but you know you've got these jazzy ride cymbals and great grooves flowing underneath a lot of these tracks I like the texture of the guitars on this thing - they've got a nice edge to them but they don't come off like just distorted and blaring like your average metal guitar I mean it even sounds like a kind of close friend of the band Steven Wilson from porcupine tree had a bit of an influence on this record since there are moments on here that remind me of songs off Steve Wilson's new solo album and I like how tight up at the sounding on this album - especially the second single that these guys dropped this year The Devil's orchard the syncopated drums guitars an organ on that track are great they just sound so badass in the way that organ just colors the background with this just sinister sinister sound is nice the band shows a lot of dynamics and a lot of interplay as they transition from these latter moments to these softer moments they just it just happened so gracefully to me it's not like there's a heart in or a heart out or it's really obvious it's like I don't know where the band is going or what they're going to do until they finally get there especially tracks like I feel the dark which start off with vocals acoustic guitar but then they subtly grow into bass drums keys in the background and then when this main booming guitar riff just punches in it's like this nice shot of progressive rock adrenaline I think a lot of the tracks on here of interesting song structures it's just not your average verse chorus verse but like I said I'm not really a fan of this album and it has a lot to do with just one single thing have you ever had an entire album ruined for you because you're not into one single thing on the I'm just one sound that they keep using or or one instrument or or just one way they mix the drums or something I've never been into Opeth vocals sadly I just I just have not the growls have been pretty good in the past but the cleans just do nothing for me and this album is nothing but cleans the vocals have a good range there on pitch I can't take that away from them that's fine that's fine but it's just whatever technical term you want to slap on it the the tambour of the vocals the cadence the inflection just the the sound of them they just sound like your average modern hardrock vocals to me it sounds like this is a voice I would hear if I went out to the local bar to hear the best cover band in town that's not really the issue I mean there's little there's a larger problem for me and that's that to me the vocals just don't feel urgent to me they don't feel emotional to me they just don't grab me they don't captivate me they don't pull me in let's take one of the first big thematic lyrics from this album comes off the devil's orchard god is dead god is dead it's repeated a bunch of times God is dead one of the most revered figures in history is dead shouldn't I feel something or think something when I hear this being said this line sounds like it's being sung in a local musical theater production the vocals just hit the right notes that's all I can say they do they just don't convey any emotional highs or lows to me they never feel really depressing or really soft or you know really dark and they never feel really intense they never feel really in my face or thrilling I know I like the way the band is playing on this LP I know I like the style that they're embracing but to me the vocals are just such a central part of this album I know a lot of Opeth think I should review next you have to be Fantana Opeth this is just my opinion forever [Music]

enter jackson jihad what are you laughing at what do you laughing at what are you laughing at can't I just you know be happy can't I just be happy Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's jihadist music thank you and to the review Andrew Jackson jihad knife man there are a lot of albums coming out this month toward this part of the year I'm getting really overwhelmed by it but I'm happy that a lot of them are good these guys get labeled as being folk punk a lot and it's understandable they take a lot of folk instrumentation and they fuse it with a with a punk energy in an ethos but in 2009 with the album montane that they came out with they were fleshing out their sound and their style a little bit with different kinds of songs and different instrumentation electric guitars and horns and junk and this album knife man goes further down that road with lots of fat red cords esque distorted guitars kazoos piano organ strings I mean they were sounding really skeletal in 2007 with this album but now with knife man they've really done a 180 with how they stir the production value has been bumped up and I can name a lot of bands who have done that but have lost their flavor in the process these guys still feel like the same group to me they're still targeting society with the the same consistency a band like crass would personality is really what this record and ever Andrew Jackson jihad record comes down to because usually on a record from these guys the chord progressions aren't anything new being familiar familiarity is is intentional because the message is what needs to be focused on what makes knife man a little different for me is that Andrew Jackson jihad just kind of felt like they were playing these communal folk songs before but now with all this extra instrumentation in this better production they don't feel like these you know little whispers and these little stories that are passed down from person to person they feel like anthems now now I'm going to talk a little deeper about what I think my favorite thing on this album is and it will probably also be the least favorite thing of a lot of people the vocals the lead singer of this group sounds like a skinny whiny white guy it sounds like he just boils on the inside with all these nasty thoughts about the world around him and doesn't let them out until he's actually writing lyrics for his songs I mean the first lyric on this album is the Michael Jordan of drunk driving played his final game tonight I mean this guy's got some really polarizing thoughts and I don't think that's a bad thing I think it's a great thing it makes this record stick out this thing is hilariously bitter and cynical from racism to sexism to poverty to love songs and even the Sun these guys have something nasty to say about almost everything I love the track American tune which is pretty much about being a white straight male and how that kind of comes with some privilege if you live in America where you're walking down the street you're not being raped you're not being hassled by police officers I like the track no.1 which is kind of really bluesy and and depressing and about people who are poor and forgotten friendless family lists helpless there's a hilarious line on here about priests feeding sinners with fur food with diabetes inducing high fructose corn syrup and I think to me my favorite line on this album not because it's funny but it's just really it just cuts to me hope is for presidents and dreams are for people who are sleeping but the thing is you know I could see the questions popping up in people's heads who is this band who are these guys who are they to judge us judge society I would kind of feel that way a little bit too but what I think is interesting about this LP is that the preachy songs are like balanced out with these introspective and kind of self-deprecating songs where the frontman of this band sees himself as kind of being just as flawed as the general public he's critiquing I think my one issue main issue with this album is that some of the punk rock tunes on here just sound really really kind of plain they sound like any modern pop punk band that like I said earlier would kind of be on Fat Wreck chords with with kind of a poppier Punk sound but still these guys are great at coming up with lyrics and stories and images that keep me on the edge of my seat waiting to hear what the next thing is it's going to be said not only that but go back and re listen to this album to pick up things that I missed and this LP is 45 minutes long which is kind of a stretch for Andrew Jackson jihad I've enjoyed these guys plenty of times before but I never saw myself enjoying them for like 45 minutes but the thing is even though this album is a little disjointed stylistically there's like a track that's a blue song on here there's a track that's like you know a tear in your beer country jukebox kind of song like I said punk tunes there are stripped-down folky acoustic moments that feel like they could have been on earlier Andrew Jackson releases all this variety makes this album feel kind of fresh for me and makes it feel worth it to listen from beginning to end it's a little bit like a mixtape for me I loved this thing I wouldn't listen to it again I had a lot of fun listening to it um feeling a decent too strong eight on it thought it was really good but what do you think about it do you like it do you hate it is this band too preachy and and whiny for you or are they speaking to you Anthony Fantana Andrew Jackson jihad vote for us in that YouTube competition forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review but first two things one I just hit 40k thank you and two we mustn't get complacent we're still in the middle of YouTube's on the rise contest and I know originally I was 5,000 votes behind and that I caught up and I was in the lead and I I'm still in the lead but our competition is no slouch they're catching up and it's going to be a close one if you haven't voted for the needle drop yet look for a link right below this video in the d box and it will bring you to a page where in the upper right hand corner pick tnd and then you can pat yourself on the back because you've done your good deed for the day alright so Veronica Falls English band some members from Glasgow Scotland - I believe been listening to this thing pretty hardcore for the past few days and coucher chest has been overhearing it as well cow what did you think of the Veronica Falls is she okay no that's that's the band's name what did you think of the band what being Veronica Falls oh all right is she okay I hate cow church esta ah to be honest Veronica Falls doesn't really reinvent the style of music that they're playing but they do play this stuff really well they managed to add a lot of detail to this indie rock sound while simultaneously making a sound so light simple and like effortless they sound pretty similar to a lot of groups from the UK who got labeled as as either being truly or cat6 and the 80s like pastels or shop assistants it's a sound that a lot of groups on the same record label that these guys Ron are trying to recapture and relive groups like the pains of Being Pure at heart procedure club brilliant colors and these groups all kind of have their own take on this style the muddy bass guitar the kind of jangly guitars made gargantuan by reverb and effects very simple straightforward driving drums and these vocals these boy/girl vocals that sound so breezy they sound like basically anybody could sing them like now Veronica Falls has their own kind of spin on this stuff this thing is definitely a perfect fall record I mean this thing sounds like the leaves changing on some trees in a graveyard on a very gray windy day and outside of the style that these guys clearly put themselves in I'm catching some whiffs of some Velvet Underground of some Pixies or the breeders and I'm hearing a lot of influences coming from like English folk tunes too with how these guys arrange their vocals on a few of these tracks and the vocals really are kind of the biggest treat for me on this album they're kind of what makes this thing both sweet and sad at the same time if this thing is a fall album the vocals really are kind of the the chilly wind blowing through the trees making the leaves fall off the melodies here they're just either so sweet and catchy and just stick in my head instantly like on the song found love in a graveyard which is kind of literally about falling in love with a ghost and on the other side of the coin you have songs where the melodies the vocals are kind of eerily beautiful like the fountain the only thing I love more than the vocals on this LP is how these guys structure their songs the parts themselves are pretty simple and skeletal but you've got a lot of different parts in each song moments where these guys are speeding up and slowing down and playing double time or coming up a little segue or a little fill into the next section you've got plenty of bridges and solos and moments where the vocal melodies altered slightly from from line to line so that they don't repeat entirely these guys really do keep the longer tracks on this album from stagnating which is great now even though the music here is very sweet it's very approachable it does have a post-punk influence you know it's got some speed it's got some momentum there is a bit of aggression there a bit of an edge and that you know really keeps me interested plus this sounds like the recording of a band playing together not a bunch of people performing on click tracks so there's definitely that momentum I guess in terms of negatives I wish this album had a little more meat on it lyrically there are moments on songs like found love in a graveyard and come on over where I kind of wish I wasn't hearing the same lyric or the same hook repeated over and over and over and some of the songs here are a little too kind of breezy for their own good to the point where I I don't even remember them all that much like all eyes on you I'm feeling a light 8 on this loved it loved a lot of songs on here but what do you think of this LP do you like it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino Veronica Falls friends
