st. Vincent hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review the new Saint Vincent LP st. Vincent is singer-songwriter Annie Clark as far as I can tell former member of The Polyphonic Spree and this is her third album under this name strange mercy the LP she came out with in 2009 actor this was not one of my favorite albums of the year but that's only because in 2009 I sucked at reviewing music and now I only suck at it a little bit less but after going back to that album and giving it a deeper listen and then listening to this thing there's such different albums to me let me know if you think the opposite but for me actor is kind of a very friendly record it's a very approachable record tracks like actor out-of-work stick out as being especially noisy and that's the kind of direction that this album moves in strange mercy is a weirder st. Vincent album but it hasn't lost the beauty that makes st. Vincent's music so good it's kind of turned into this odd mutant beauty now pretty much all these tracks function on a verse chorus verse thing it's an artsy pop album but there's like equal attention paid toward making these songs catchy and also making them kind of surprising take the the biggest single to come from the cell peak rule the track just opens up with these gorgeous string arrangements like closing credits at the end of a Disney movie gorgeous it sounds like a fairy tale with a fantastic beat but there's this really dark undertone to the song with the lyrics and and not only that but the the solo the guitar solo in this it's so ugly and distorted and just like broken sounding it's this intentional blemish on this really pretty song that song and the rest of the songs on here are just so like too they're really easy to get into but they'll turn right around and just sort of like fly a freak flag I think my favorite song on here though is dilettante and that song might be my favorite just because of how how weird it feels the drums are like stumbling they're stuttering like they're they're trying to get going but they can't and they're moving at this this slow pace and I'm just like on the edge of my seat waiting for them to go faster waiting for them to do something but yet they just hang back here and they played so sparsely and then all of a sudden just this this rush of distorted guitar and bass and piano just all hitting keys syncopated at once it's poppy and it's sweet but yet again it's like so harsh and abrasive it's like something I'd hear on a grinder man record or like a Tom Waits record I mean throwing all these really noisy elements these glitchy electronics - especially on the fifth track Northern Lights which I love it just feels like really liberating to me things don't have to be just pretty or just harsh and abrasive they can be both now this LP swings over to the softer side of things as well but it stays really alluring and it stays pretty weird - the title track I love the title track on here it's just really stark and cold and kind of painful surgeon has a really weird synthesizer landscape hanging in the background and I love how kind of robotic and mesmerizing the hook is on that track of the weird guitar leads and it just mm-hmm their morbid lyrics on this track about being cut open and that's one of the many darker lyrical moments that will buzz by you if you're just wrapped up in the music which I can understand because there's a lot going on musically on this album a lot of layers a lot of subtleties a lot of things you're gonna pick up with multiple listens but lyrics like convinced it was the end of times and and sharks swimming in the red no matter what kind of flavor or sound that a song is going for on this album that dark outlook is is one of the few strings that run through all the tracks I thought actor was we colorful album but this thing brings out way more color and not only that but the songs on here feel a little more polarized in that the more depressing moments are more depressing and the brighter louder noisier moments come off even more bold and that's a word I have to kind of bring it back to bold I would use that word to sum up a description of this album it is pretty bold it's got some very strong instrumentation surrounding these tracks it's got some strong vocals in a time when really light weak singers with not that much range are praised left and right in the indie community my only real gripe with this LP is there's a handful of tracks that do not come off as flamboyant or adventurous to me like the track neutered fruit it's a fine song but it kind of ends up sounding like a more pleasant version of a track from Dirty Projectors bit of Orca but aside from a few tracks that I just think are ok I can't say much negative about this album it pretty much does a perfect tightrope walk of being experimental and catchy it was really easy to get into and yet I don't feel like I'm listening to something sugary dumbed down or simple and most importantly it was just fun to listen to I think even coucher chesta had it had a fun time I can't really see much I might I'm not religious well there you go feeling a light too decent 8 on this loved it thought it was really good I recommend it which is why I'm making a video doing that what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantana st. Vincent strange mercy forever [Music]

hello my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review the new wolves in the throne room LP celestial lineage these guys are a West Coast metal band who just about everybody seems to have an opinion on I'm sure Cal Church esta even has an opinion on them if you got wolves in your throne room you should probably call an exterminator hurry add dad catcher I hate counter chesta but seriously with these guys american black metal represent now these guys other than that with 2007's to hunters and the album that came before that diadem of 12 stars these guys were creating this this really vast an open style of black metal it sounded like a black metal ocean that's how massive these records sound atmospheric black metal isn't new at all it's not a new concept but these guys brought it to a different stylistic level to the point where it was almost like shoegaze music and these guys also kind of brought American black metal to a new level of popularity to it just kind of put black metal on the table as being a worthy discussion for people who weren't just black metal fans now is American atmospheric black metal was getting bigger wolves in the throne room went in a kind of different direction with their next LP black cascade there were still some effects on this album but wolves in the throne room stripped a lot of the reverb away and just put all the guitars drums and vocals in in plain sight it was a very kind of naked direction for the band now this new LP celestial lineage this feels like a much more kind of logical follow-up to two hunters everything that made 12 stars and two hunters unique records is back and kind of taken up to a higher level I feel like the female vocals on this album are spotlighted more their their lavish sound effects and field recordings and and chimes pop in a little bit there's a pretty noticeable synthesizers on here a spot where I think I'm hearing harp and some male choruses to the atmosphere from wolves in the throne rooms earlier work is back to it's not as high as it was on two hunters and twelve stars and I'm liking that because it's kind of made this LP feel more heavy than it is hazy but I have a pretty big gripe about this LP sometimes something that's really holding me back and keeping me from loving it I feel like these guys haven't really pushed themselves past their previous efforts to really kind of make this feel like a new album this to me kind of feels like an old album but with some slightly new additions the freshest out of all the tracks on here to me feels like the first song which starts off with these really kind of empowering female vocals has all these new righteous guitar leads that these guys haven't really explored yet but you know as beautiful as other tracks are like Woodland Cathedral where you've got these female vocals singing over a really kind of primal and sparse beat with these soft distorted guitars in the background it's not really like new territory for the band another track like subterranean initiation just comes on really hard but it feels like a little bit of deja vu for me wolves in the throne room throw some new sounds and ideas into a couple interludes on this album but outside of that I feel like they're pretty much aiming at the same target same exact target that they aim for on previous albums it's a target that I think they've already hit the bullseye on it makes me think of another American black metal band with third and fourth albums Agalloch their third LP ashes against the grain is way different than marrow of the Spirit not only did Agalloch change what production and what instrumentation they surround their songs with but they changed how they write their songs to wolves in the throne room on the other hand in my opinion are just kind of writing songs the same way that they have been it's like the same buildups same concepts the same anthemic asked melodies thrown in the same spots at the end of these same ten-minute tracks there are similar chord progressions too I feel like the only difference this time around is that it's done with with more volume and more layers and you know what that has its merits too consistency is important and if you're into wolves and the therm room sound then there aren't really going to be any potholes on this release for you and the thing is I like this - when I was listening to it it's not like I was scrambling to turn it off but then again if I was given the choice to listen to this or twelve stars or two hunters I'm going to opt for one of those two albums before this and those two albums already sit in my collection I'm feeling a light decent six on this thing thought it was decent like I said not really any potholes on this but it's not offering anything refreshing to me that makes me want to return to it but what do you think of this thing are you loving it are you hating it why and what do you think I should review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantana wolves in the throne room celestial lineage forever you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's most unshaven music nerd and it's time for an album review the men leave home these guys are a New York band this is their second full-length LP I heard a lot of people asking me to review this back in May when it came out I promised myself I would get to it eventually so here I am now if you're a punk fan if you're hardcore punk fan a noise rock fan if you've enjoyed albums like Ice Ages new Brigade that came out this year I think this is definitely something you need to try out these guys have a lot of good things going for them they recorded this LP to tape so the distortion the really saturated and compressed guitars are just really filthy their grimy the the distortion is is is really coarse it's the difference between you know rubbing some sandpaper on your hand and having your skull just like dragged across a hundred yards of asphalt the drums are booming the guitars are just abrasive they're loud there but what I think is really cool outside of the production is that there are three people in this band who all kind of share songwriting duties so this LP has a kind of schizophrenic make up with one song going in a completely different direction than the next the opening track does a heavy psychedelic kind of thing the third track goes into this noise punk thing with these dissonant interludes where these guitars all freak out and play these random leads blast track has the kind of driving post-punk repetition that that bands like the fall popularized the sixth track sounds exactly like a Fugazi song and the fourth is almost kind of like a doom metal track so there's a lot of variation among these tracks almost at the point where this album is is kind of scatterbrained the only thing that to me really links all these songs together is that no matter what different idea the men seem to be chasing after they just turn it all the way up to 11 and just do it in the most extreme way they possibly can in terms of volume in terms of noise in terms of speed in terms of energy so this is kind of led to an LP that has an interesting progression it's always switching gears and there's nothing more I hate than putting on an album the first few tracks are hard they're heavy they're loud they're maybe they're fast to their extreme and it's got me pumped and maybe like three or four tracks and I just start getting bored because all the songs sound the same not the problem here but I do have a major issue with this LP it's kind of a major issue while I don't really hate any of the songs here the guitar riffs the melodies a lot of them are just so bland and forgettable and just kind of like throwaway for me you know I know nothing is 100% original these days everybody is borrowing from somewhere but I just don't really find anything distinct about the guitar riffs that are used on a lot of these tracks they don't really stick into my head and most of the time they're just kind of giving me this this sense of deja vu I think it's something that should be checked out if you are into noise rock if you are into punk rock and post-punk I'm feeling at 6 on this but what did you think about it if you've heard it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana thank you for watching the men forever

he's the most thunderous cat around his name is Thunder cat bass solo it's an airbase Thunder cat oh hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here internet's busiest music a nerd and it's time for an album review the new Thundercat LP the Golden Age of Apocalypse Thundercat is bassist Steve and I first heard of him through a feature spot he had on Flying Lotus his last LP cosmic grandma Flying Lotus actually produced this LP and Steve also serves as the latest bassist for one of my favorite crossover thrash acts suicidal tendencies Steve isn't a part of the original lineup but still he's in this band and he also collaborates with Flying Lotus and now he has a solo LP of song after song after song of just these spacey a lek tronic jazz fusion tracks something is up something is here somebody who stretched themselves into so many styles and categories has to be doing something interesting now when I first came into contact with this LP I had kind of been fed up by being disappointed by a lot of releases coming off the label that this album is on brain feeder records so after a short listen I kind of discounted it but I was getting a ton of comments to review this thing so of course I had to give it a deeper listen and it wasn't long until I realized that I was actually enjoying what I was hearing a lot now if you're a bassist or you've hung out with bassists you've probably heard them say oh man you need to listen to some Jaco Pastorius man you need to listen to some Stanley Clarke dude and I've enjoyed that stuff I enjoy those dudes I enjoy the music they make but the style of jazz fusion they play even the style dude like George Duke would play a guy who under cat actually covers on this LP that sound is just so isolated in this old time period dudes like Marcus Miller and Victor Wooten and Stanley Clark are still alive they're still kicking still making music I think a lot of that stuff has just been stereotyped as being music for for musicians one of the only artists who I can think has branched kind of outside of that camp while still playing some kind of shade of jazz fusion is like square pusher who is combining that sound with with drum and bass in the 90s so because there's a lot of music out there like this already and I see it either being glossed over or people just aren't paying attention to it that's what makes this interesting to me this LP people are hyping it people are freaking out about it people are loving it and people are asking me to review it and I'm not saying it shouldn't be enjoyed I'd actually like to argue that this sticks out for good reason on this LP thundercat embraces an older smoother style of jazz fusion but execute it in a way that could have only been done in 2011 in a way that only could have been done with Flying Lotus producing this thing this LP makes this style like really fun and vibrant and alive again it's like hopping into a spaceship and rocketing through a jazz fusion galaxy loaded with stellar bass solos and fantastic grooves and some of the bass lines on here just so nimble and dynamic they're like doing backflips all over the place like on the song fleur ultra one of my favorite tracks on here I mean the bass line on that is just dizzying that track is more of a fast straightforward lean more orchestrated instrumental and then there are songs on here where Thundercat is actually singing in this very light falsetto I'm not totally into it I don't think it's the strongest vocal on the planet but when he does sing it's usually this winding jazzy melody that is so great that I just fall in love with what the vocals are doing anyway that's tracks like is it love and for love I come those are more like poppy catchy accessible moments where the vocals are really kind of leading the way and then again there are songs on here where they really kind of feel like jams like there's a lot of improvising going on tracks six to eight or kind of like that but there are a few moments here that I think maybe some people are not going to love right at first because they sound a little bit like they're just base exercises but the thing is spots like that are very few now aside from the vocals I think the only shortcoming of this album is that it's a little short a lot of these tracks feel a little short considering that Thundercat is such a strong bass player an improviser I think a lot of these songs could have been a minute longer a lot of these tracks sort of fade out or just end abruptly or really don't go on past the two-minute mark when for me things are just kind of getting started I think this thing could have explored a little bit more so so yeah my biggest complaint is I want more but outside of that I love the style I love the songs the recording is fantastic just the the the the rising instrumental crescendos they're just so gorgeous but even though I thought this thing was a little short of breath I do have to give it to Thundercat and maybe this has to do with with Flying Lotus producing that he's taken this style where you know it might not be uncommon to put out a 14-minute live track or something like that but he sort of pared it down to the two minutes three minutes four minutes and even though I wish it was longer it doesn't sound bad this thing was a really fun listen it's an enjoyable album I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this I liked it a lot didn't underwhelmed me at all I find this guy's playing really interesting if you consider yourself a jazz fan a fan of strong musicianship then got to check this out at least once Thundercat the Golden Age of Apocalypse what do you think of this LP love it hate it let me know Anthony Fantana Thundercat forever [Music] you

come on mom dad bye hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd time for an album review slow-mo and this is his according to the label that this album comes off of the full-length debut of this project but this is not shalom o's first rodeo there were some eps that came out before this a nice little compilation of new and old tracks and it's all built up to this an album titled bad vibes this dude is an electronic music producer from LA and he's heavily influenced by the beat music scene out there that's been getting a lot of press all over the internet this year there's just been no shortage of this stuff between flying lotus and his label brain feeder and basically any unsigned artist who can log on to Bandcamp and soundcloud and you know upload their own little EP or album of beats that they've produced on their laptop but thankfully this thing stood out to me it did not come on strong it's not a really bright album but it stood out nonetheless the first thing that i think is worth noting about this LP is just the really chill mood the chilled out atmosphere it's the most prevalent thing on this entire help it's just one soft pretty beat after another that sounds like this guy's been listening to a lot of downtempo from the 90s i wouldn't say this LP is ambient though it's kind of like relaxing beats for the foreground and there are a lot of points on here with this album actually reminds me of Bath's debut LP the strong percussion and the falsetto vocals that fans love from that thing also appear on this another thing about bad vibes that makes this thing stick out to me is the detail and the effort that i sense in these tracks a lot goes into these songs it's 13 different tracks on this thing and a lot of them land around the four-minute mark you're not going to be listening to another J Dilla copycat who's somehow thrown together twenty one minute beats in a day and they act like they're the first guy to do it the tracks on this thing don't just run around in a circle they have a point a a point B the beats change they shift new sounds introduce themselves different instruments pop up atmospheres layer on top of atmospheres the music just gets thicker plus a lot of the tracks here just have strong melodies good chord progressions and that kind of brings me to the style the the aesthetic the production of this album it's definitely a do-it-yourself affair and it doesn't embrace being do it yourself it doesn't embrace the bedroom aesthetic by being really low fire or really noisy or really messy or anything like that it embraces the sound by incorporating sort of everyday sounds that occur around us the percussive sounds on this album sound like they were recorded by like tapping or just sort of lightly pounding on a desk or just smacking pencils together snapping your fingers and a lot of the melodies on this are coming from acoustic guitar either being strummed or just a melody being played some electric guitar here and there baby xylophone birds chirping getting a sample on here on a track some melodic cut to slo-mo just has this really interesting way of taking the very quiet sounds that just occur in everyday life and making very beautiful music with them MacGyver beats that do a lot with a little their beats on a budget it's low volume bedroom funk now there weren't any tracks on here that I really hated but there were a good chunk of songs that just kind of breezed by and that's kind of the point of this album anyway to kind of be relaxing be kind of a place a setting to just chill out in there are spots on this LP that demand my attention a lot more though like I love the guitar chords the very pretty good power chords and the subtle groove on the track places I love the droning the booming the distorted guitar chords on trapped in a burning house it's kind of like Shlomo tried to create a little tiny baby son concert in whatever room he was recording this album in' and the cute little synthesizers the plinky dinky synthesizers that open up just us make me want to cuddle with my girlfriend there are more pretty moments than there are bland moments on this LP and that's obviously a good thing this thing is really consistent it's very ambitious considering how little it has to work with and it's very slow burning its beat music for people who like to stop and smell the roses there are some songs on here that I think get held back a little bit by how limited the resources are on bad vibes like a lot of the tracks where Shlomo is just kind of throwing out these falsetto vocals moaned into a microphone and then a bunch of reverb is thrown on them and that's only going to do so much for me especially considering that this guy's voices is not the strongest vocal in the world I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this what do you think of it

rock bands that hit it big in the 90s but have somehow managed to stay relevant stay whole and stay producing music well on past 2010 and the latest LP from these guys I'm with you comes at kind of a pivotal change for the band their longtime guitarist John Frusciante has left the group and has been replaced by another guitar player josh klinghoffer now if you're Red Hot Chili Peppers fan you already know how monstrous of a guitar player in a musician John Frusciante is and you know that when he rejoined the band in the late 90s he just sort of brought this ambition necessary to make double albums like stadium arcadion switching from John to Josh has meant a change in dynamics for these guys but Red Hot Chili Peppers with this album seem kind of determined to not let that be the downgrade that everybody is expecting it to be the strengths and weaknesses are different now and they sort of realign the way they make records accordingly the really flashy strong fiery guitar playing a lot of chili pepper fans have come to love is not on this record and he'll like even fleas bass lines have been kind of dumbed down a little bit purposely intentionally in order to make an noisy deafening sound kind of just like swelling up in the background in it and it's slowly like choking the entire song it's like indescribable it's like a field recording from another dimension this whispering vocal comes up and just sort of introduces itself as these larger-than-life bass drums or pounding pounding pounding like knocking on this gigantic gateway or something and it's like all of and the whole track is followed by this really tortured tortured screaming and slamming hands against a piano it's pretty freaky this song and a lot of this album is like bringing Dan's capabilities as a singer-songwriter together with a lot of the experimental sounds and drones from that novel ear record there are other tracks on this LP that have kind of similar swells like I'm not going to do it it's kind of like being suffocated really slowly by depression there are some more accesible moments on here too kind of had these more experimental ones out I know I'm more partial to the experimental tracks on this album but I don't think everybody is going to feel that way so luckily there are some acoustic ballads on here that remind me a lot of grizzly-bear actually that album yellow house in that you've got these very kind of straightforward acoustic songs but they're just matched up with it with a sea of reverb and background vocals empowering and just making it seem bigger than what it really is but in a way it also kind of reminds me of Mount Airy it's produced in a way that's messy but kind of lends it this unique style that you're not going to find anywhere else Dan Barrett's production style like on have a nice life like on novel ear some of the sounds on here that get louder really over modulated kind of overblown some of the guitars feel kind of thin and tinny a lot of vocals in the background when they're being multi-tracked and singing in courses they assemble a little lazily and like I said about the reverb there's tons of it but enough music sounds that I pick up a little bit more of them every time I revisit this album it's like an Easter egg hunt or something now this book is kind of like a different story a lot of pages a lot of text a lot of pay pictures as well like previous projects dan has been involved with themes of this album revolve around depression death suicide but there's sort of an added element of the occult and the afterlife and ghosts involved with this a lot of the pages on here kind of in a way look to give the reader some kind of existential crisis but when it's not doing that the the words on this thing kind of followed the exploits of someone I assume Dan made up because when I google this guy pretty much all links go to this album the man's name is Robert for like any good piece of fiction this book takes what is not real and routes it so deeply into what Israel that it kind of blurs those two worlds so in a way I'm convinced he's real his obsession with the afterlife death and the occult they're real I'm convinced that the hood wearing cult that he led into the woods that was real there are points on this book that reference back to particular spots on this album which actually kind of made this LP go from being creepy - like frightening for me when Dan was talking about the vores head device which is this weird hood that I alluded to earlier which is supposed to be giving members of this of this cult like visions connection to the afterlife something like that and Dan explains wearing this hood and getting axe to the piano and just like having this freakout session that got recorded to tape and then it's thrown onto this album Plus for me it was pretty great to get a look into the lyrical side of this album by looking at the pages of this book like the song spectral bride is pretty much about being so depressed that you want to commit suicide but you have this loved one that you've left behind that you want to be with romantically so you know you die but you're still with that person as like a ghost the context and the ideas that this book brings they're fine they're good I think they empower this album a lot I like the fact that this album is named after Giles Corey who was a colonial American who was killed during the Salem witch trials and was basically put to death via getting crushed by stones because he refused to plead guilty or not guilty to the witchcraft charges he was faced with and on this album and in this book Dan pretty much puts himself in Giles place but instead of being crushed by rocks he's being crushed by this story about Robert war ideas and obsessions with death in the afterlife and and suicide and of course depression to all of that is crushing down on him now is this book necessary to enjoy this album probably not on some level I think a lot of people are going to enjoy this album even without the book but we're living in an age where for some reason people are more interested in what goes on behind the scenes with albums and and just sort of what makes albums tick and what inspires albums if you really want to see what made this album what it is the book is a must sonically I think the only issues that I there could have been a little bit more to it it could have been a little bit more climactic or something but I love this thing I love the concept I love the way it made me feel because after I read big deal out of this and that's not something that you know over a great beat with some great lyrics you usually hear a rapper say I haven't heard it done to this extent since like that Eminem song Stan I dedicate this to you is a love song that pretty much goes off without any hitches it gets a little corny but it does the job but the song that was nearest and dearest to my heart was peace Connecticut a straight up rap song about Connecticut and it's really something anyone and everyone from Connecticut should hear from calling Willimantic Connecticut heroin town rapping about grinders north face jackets good old Tom it should make anybody who lives in this state feel a little bit of CT pride there are some moments on this LP in the lyricism in the beats where this feels like you a whole you can call me CT biased that's fine but I don't think this dude would be attracting the kind of features and the attention that he is if this was just a Connecticut thing I'm feeling a light too decent seven on this liked it a lot I wish it it ventured more I wish it experimented a little bit more but apathy is more of a guy who brings it straight from the gut doesn't take himself too hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd it's time for a review Danny Brown xxx aka 30 and I know this is a hip-hop review I'm sure I'm going to see some comments that are all like the needle drop reviews too much hip-hop when I can't help but the hip hop is killing it this year I can't help that I'm just following my ears you know what do you want me to review so a lot of people have been asking me to review this thing and I'm glad I checked it out I'm glad I did I might have actually slept on this because the first time I ever heard of Danny was last year when he came out with his album the hybrid he emailed me a page where I could stream the whole LP in full its it's an email I'm sure he sent to a lot of blogs he said something like pitchfork took a whack at my album you should too I liked his flow I was kind of into his voice at the time but I just had a hard time seeing what the big deal was I didn't like a lot of the beats on the album here's some tracks from some mixtapes that he's released before the hybrid but definitely after this there was some kind of revelation some kind of change outside of Danny Browns now kind of Skrillex looking haircut on 30 Danny is coming out with tracks that are really raw disturbing personal like almost too raw disturbing and personal to me this is kind of like hip hop's version of dr. Jekyll and mr. Hyde but you get way more mr. Hyde than you do dr. Jekyll on the cell P Danny wraps about the usual kind of rap cliches you know just greed misogyny money violence bragging about himself about his mic skills making really kela similes everywhere but like the Death Grips album that came out earlier this year he takes all these ideas and brings them to such an extreme they kind of become parody it's a kind of cartoony embrace of drugs and violence that reminds me of Eminem back when he was kind of in his prime and when I say cartoony the dude does sound kinda silly and it's not just because Squidward is the first pop-culture reference on this album it's his voice he just has this really odd whiny inflection when he's rapping it's something he kind of puts on you know and it may take a little bit to adjust to it's not something that you you may necessarily just fall in love with on first listen but for me it was semi easy the way that he just throws his voice everywhere and just kind of sounds like he's going a little bit wilder than he really is kind of makes me think of him as a really skinny high-pitched old dirty bastard but during these more kind of dr. Jekyll moments on the album he is rapping in a more normal inflection a more accepted inflection this album is 19 tracks almost an hour and I'm not going to lie you may be tempted to turn it off as soon as it starts but if you're in hip-hop music stick with it because the full punch doesn't come until the end of the album when the bigger picture kind of comes into view on the first chunk of this album the beats are really sparse odd electronic a lot of atmospheric sense hanging in the background something I could almost hear like little be spitting over a little bit the track died like a rockstar has these really fuzzy bass notes hanging in the background and the lyrics on that track are pretty much about these excesses that Danny raps about kind of bringing him to an early end and that's the character he plays here the character is excessive but not necessarily stupid like on the track radio song which is a pretty clever piece of satire where Danny is pretty much spitting in the face of commercial rappers with a very Annoying hook intentionally annoying and the song bruiser Brigade comes out really violent almost in a parody of violence sounding kind of like a waka flocka flame track and even referencing him in the process but as weird as Danny gets I feel like maybe there's a little bit of Danny in all of us because he was pretty much reading my mind on the song I will the first part of it you got a listen to the tape to figure out what that songs about so as Danny comes out with this really eccentric personality he's droppin lines that are so hilariously quotable like the Virgin Mary snorting coke certain parts of the anatomy tasting and or smelling like Cool Ranch Doritos or tropical fruit skittles crapping on someone's mixtape literally giving a girl's jaw stretch marks and the beats match this weirdness like the weird bleep II blue penis on the track outer space or that very high-pitched noisy whine on Detroit 187 the party on this album though is kind of over once it all comes to a head when Danny drops a track referencing one of his favorite drugs adderall before that track the entire album was kind of like the high it was the high and after that everything just drops into a depression after this point Danny is rapping in a more normal inflection and he drops a track called DNA where he's rapping about how his addiction is like hereditary and kind of coming to terms with it rapping about losing family members and friends and pretty much like letting go of his life but I la I love the ending of this album where Danny is back to his weirder character he's back on the drugs he's having an emotional meltdown his entire life is melting down he's overdosing on pills paramedics are trying to revive him he's rapping about fool's gold finally signing him and it's just a really hectic ending to this thing on this LP there are a lot of moods Styles sounds layers and personality it comes on strong it comes on kind of weird to don't listen to this and just observe it at the surface scratch below interpret think observe and enjoy I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this I think it's great there were some tracks here that underwhelmed me a little bit toward the middle of the album but strong start and strong finish but what do you think of this thing loving it hating it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana dan brown forever you you

hmm hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's most active music nerd and it's album review time active child you are all I see active child is the project of singer-songwriter Pat grossie this is his second LP under the name this thing pretty much began as an ethereal bedroom recording project with a lot of laptop and synthesizer in the mix and there wasn't really much to separate it from pretty much everybody else who was making music in the room with a laptop and a synthesizer but even at the start of this project Pat had a pretty unmistakable vocal very heavenly very sweet I wasn't surprised to find that this guy actually has a background singing in choir when I was reading up a bit on this project it's one EP and kind of an entire year later and we've got this you are all i see and this album comes with some really big improvements ambitions and sounds all of these changes all of these great sounds are apparent right from the start of the album with pat's vocals they just sound like rays of sunshine breaking through clouds of harp arpeggios these analog synthesizers kind of starts swelling in the background and it's given me kind of an 80s vibe why but overall it's kind of like a dreamy pop opera a dream popera it's all very fine and pretty and delicate a lot like an antony and the johnsons song but a lot less eccentric and not implying arts enos in every direction possible I love the sounds on the track and most of the sample might do but it's not like the opener really has a song that I'm blown away by you know it's it's it's more like a pile of really pretty sounds like butterflies just fluttering about not really a direction more of a mood but my favorite two tracks on the album come next and they stick out like sore thumbs this LP because they are very very different they're wrapped up in the same shimmering and glistening production as the other tracks on this LP pretty much the same instrumentation but the execution is different and that execution is experimental R&B something that a fan of the weekend or maybe even how to dress well could appreciate and I know I have reviewed albums from those projects and I didn't really dig them but I am digging this these tracks just really have very smooth beats lovesick lyrics honey-flavored vocals and they're all just filtered through this active child lens with lots of atmosphere and reverb inand pretty acoustic ethereal instrumentation just swarming around it like fairies how to dress well is even on one of these tracks and active child throws a little bit of a gritty loaf I ish sound on his voice just kind of maintain that maintain that same aesthetic that he had on his full-length LP but what I love about the sounds here is that the beats are better the synth our betters everything is a better sound I would love to hear these guys collaborate again in the future maybe on an EP maybe on an entire full-length I think that would be amazing active child departs from the R&B stuff after these two tracks and that makes me kind of sad because they're really the high points of the album I'm not saying the rest of the tracks are bad they just kind of evoke different imager you know they make me kind of feel like I'm floating through space or ascending to heaven or listening to something that would be put on at a cult meeting there are some tracks on the latter half of this LP I do love though like High Priestess which is this very bleak atmosphere kind of art pop song in the vein of Peter Gabriel or especially fever ray considering how many weird chorus effects are on the vocals on that track the track way too fast is lyrically as lovesick as some of the R&B songs on here but the vocals feel way colder way more electronic and that's kind of empowered by a lot of synthesized zehrs in the background a very steady rigid beat and the vocal melody sounds a little bit like something James Blake would even sing and hearing those really kind of passionate vocals fed through the vocoder that active child uses on that track it's really kind of freaky it's like hearing a robot trying to a moat a lot like that movie bicentennial man with Robin Williams where Robin Williams is a robot and he wants to become a human I guess my problem with the very end of this LP is that active child in my opinion just kind of runs out of ideas a little bit and is recycling them and that doesn't make the songs terrible to me it just makes them a little less exciting a little underwhelming that's all I'm feeling a decent too strong six on this I liked it but definitely not in love with it what do you think of this if you've heard it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana active child forever you

Africa high-tech hi everyone Anthony there's a moth that Fanta no friend to no one hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd friends with everybody and it's time for an album review thank you for watching some of you who are watching this video may be new to the channel because this channel just got featured on youtube.com slash music which put a smile on my face like this so to those of you who are new or maybe just don't know yet and have been subscribed for a while the point of this channel is to introduce you to music you may not have heard of yet hmm that sounds nice just think of it the greatest album you you've ever heard in your life could be out there somewhere and you just haven't found it yet that's what I want to help you do I'm gonna help you find that album so maybe this will be the album Africa hi-tech 93 million miles this is a duo spearheaded by two musicians Mark Pritchard and Steve Spacek and between the both of them and their various side projects they've covered everything from soul music to techno but this is my first introduction to their stuff so please excuse me if I'm not very well-versed in what these guys have done already now this LP came out in May on warp records and when it dropped I was feeling it a little bit I thought it was okay mmm definitely some bright spots on here I did a track review of the album put it up on the needle drop calm toward the end of that month and let's just convinced that I wasn't going to review the entire album just because I thought it was it was alright but to me like the show of a good record is that you want to return to it you want to hear it again you want to revisit you want to get the same feelings and the same experiences from that album over again so surprisingly like at the beginning of this month I just started getting this very small but ignore ball to listen to this thing again eventually this itch got so big that I just couldn't think about anything else anymore I had to listen to this again but this time when I listened to it and I revisited the LP it just like clicked what magic I mean don't you love it when albums do that now my favorite thing about Africa high tech is this project sounds exactly what you would assume a project with this name would sound like one track after another finding a different balance between African and electronic sounds like the track out in the streets which is done in a juke or ghetto house style of electronic music with lots of repeated vocal samples very fast busy beat it's a style of music I ran into earlier this year on that machine drum album rooms however at the time I wasn't all that experienced or knowledgeable on the subjects of ghetto house or Juke and I wouldn't say I am now but I am conscious of the style now I know that's what the style is that is being pursued on that track and I apologize for anybody who I may have pissed off for mislabeling that machine drum album sorry I I don't know everything I wouldn't be the first guy well now that I know about this style I love the way it's executed on this album on that track with a really hard nosed beat that just makes me want to throw my hands up in the air and this really dizzying repetitive vocal sample of Jamaican reggae singer na Camozzi just cycling over and over how didn't the speed in the street didn't is it's just really overwhelming for me just makes me feel like I'm spinning in a room I love it the track do you want to fight is really synthetic the strings the horns the beats the keys all this sounds so robotic and to throw on top of that someone kind of like singing or emceeing really there's an African accent in the voice I think but there's some heavy vocoder on that voice so it's like listening to an African robot spit over some weird electronic Africa beats it's strange and there are other tracks on here like Gang slap and future moves and the opening track to that just feel like an electronic drum circle with different poly rhythms introducing themselves throughout the track arpeggios - and sometimes when these new things fly in they change up the groove like all together the sounds here are just so so plentiful so colorful so blatant so bright and sweet it's like eating a hundreds leaves of like digital lifesavers and some of the beats on here like almost 8-bit quality it's kind of like listening to african chip tunes i mean just like in the way that african drum music can be seen as is kind of going back to the beginnings the more primal moments of music this album takes electronics themselves back to those beginnings - much simpler much more blatant rigid and robotic sounds some of these tracks can be kind of like staring into a big ass circuit board or something there are a lot of tracks on here that hit hard there are a nice chunk as well that come on slow and soft I love one of the longest songs on here our love which just mmm just swells nicely with keyboards in the background just keeps the soft repetitive groove and has this robotic woman's voice just announcing various musings about love it's something that like the Kraftwerk and laurie anderson fan in me just eats up like it's candy and in this softer side of this album some acoustic sounds come out to the track spirit has these sampled hand drums on the song and this voice that's that's touched with a bit of vocoder to make it sound robotic underneath all these very subtle electronics it's kind of like trying to spot an animal hiding behind all this brush in the jungle or something especially considering all that the jungle sounds happening in the background of this track with crickets and I think I hear like a monkey or something and the last two tracks on the LP have a really chilled out tribal vibe to them to some songs on here to me are a little short of breath maybe some of the the vocals in the background of some tracks could have been brought to the foreground and and yeah there is a very blatant influence on this thing coming from dubstep coming from techno coming from Juke and ghetto house sure but all these songs have such interesting production and sounds in an African twist to them that makes this feel really unique to me I've just never heard this kind of stuff attacked specifically at this angle so many times I think what did keep me from loving this LP at first though when I was first listening to this thing again and again is that when I say bright and when I say blatant on this album I do mean that it does throw a lot of sounds out there right at the get-go it is kind of difficult to digest in one sitting and the influences are clear about making sense of all of it quickly is just not gonna happen if you do decide to listen to this do give it a couple chances because I did and I'm really happy I did I almost dismissed this and I'm glad I can say that I'm feeling at this point a very decent two strong eight on this thing loving the hell out of it it's just a really fun listen for me now and really just gets my blood boiling and I love it when electronic music can do that for me what do you think of this thing if you've heard it love it hate it why then what should I review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantana Africa high tech forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's druggist music nerd album review time the war on drugs sleeve ambient you know today I was reading some of the comments on my watch the throne review um let me tell you for me some people just don't get that this this is opinion this is just my opinion that's it you know it's nothing more than that I'm not right about anything I might actually bet that I'm wrong just some people get so my kick the war on drugs is a Philadelphia project spearheaded by singer-songwriter Adam and I was pretty excited about the build-up to this release because this album is a very interesting hybrid of two styles sounds that I really love tracks like come to the city and baby missiles remind me of guys like Bob Dylan because of Adam's really roots II draw in his vocals and folk full crock really cool you know it's hanging at the bar and then all of a sudden on this album shoegaze music and and krautrock kind of come over to it and buy it a few drinks and seduce it and take it home and then the three of them do things to each other that they'll never speak of this thing is kind of the dirty secret that's just been let out now and there have been a lot of psychedelic takes on folk music and folk rock before trying to weird it out one guy who I have to say sounds a lot like the war on drugs is curve Isle actually who dropped an album earlier this year so imagine my surprise when I was looking through the internet and saw the Kurt Vile is actually on this album kindred spirits I still got a review that album though this LP is not just your your usual psychedelic take on folk music the drums behind this record are very muscular repetitive and driving much like the drums off of one of my favorite records of all time noise seminal noise 75 great record with one rigid krautrock groove after another especially on the second half every track on this LP builds into a wall of sound a nice atmospheric wall of sound imagine Neil Young's Allah knows if it actually had a backing band behind it that's how I kind of see this record and though this LP can be pretty loud pretty overwhelming at times the sounds on here for me stay very pretty this album really kind of glistens you know they shimmer it's like watching a waterfall in the moonlight and in the vein of a lot of crap rock artists some of the tracks on this album get kind of strung out like five or six minutes making these long Airy psychedelic jams while I do love the concept of this record I love the idea I love the fusion not every track is is as stellar as the next for me there are a lot of points on here where the sound of this record and the songwriting come together to make something awesome like come to the city which has these really heavy primal drums that come on slow and build the track up with one climax after another just making the song bigger each time the vocal melody on the opening track best night really pretty really captivating and baby missles is where adam on here gives his most enthusiastic vocal delivery in my opinion but sometimes on this LP Adams vocals either take a turn for the worse or they just kind of feel okay to me like I'm not getting a strong personality from him or something I feel that way on the song I was there he's really off pitch kind of all over the place on that song and some of the instrumental interludes on this LP like the animator are really pretty I love the way horns are used on that track it's very ambient it's really gorgeous but other instrumental songs like original Slavin and city reprieves they don't really add anything new to the album they're not bringing anything to the table that all the tracks before those tracks didn't already bring and this next thing I can't really explain I'm not sure why it could have something to do with the way these guys recorded this album but the grooves on this LP just feel really flat for me I'm not really feeling any interplay or interaction with the keyboards the guitars and the drums the momentum just kind of feels like this doesn't really feel like I'm hearing a full band playing together you know I could be wrong and and I'm open to that but still the the climaxes and the jams I'm just not really getting anything out of hearing them go on for an extended period of time I just got to feel like I'm hearing the same thing over and over and over again I just don't feel like I'm progressing with some of these songs I don't know I love the sound I love the concept and I love a good chunk of the songs here I was just kind of left wanting more and that's it overall I liked it I'm feeling a a decent two strong six on this pretty enjoyable and but to be honest what I really want to know is actually what Cal chesta thinks of the war on drugs you know what I think legalize it man I agree Jesus Aaron Henry yes do it do it Oh Daria you

where's the love where's the love okay all right happy times Anthony Fantan oh here internets busiest music nerd thank you for watching album review time on the needle drop Chelsea wolf this woman is a singer-songwriter who I admittedly unfairly categorized unfairly grouped into this new wave of dark wave gothic rock and maybe even like which house bands I slept on her first album and I was going to do the same with this album but then some some comments and suggestions really made me want to listen to it really deep give it a deep listen and just see what comes out I was streaming some of it on NPR music and it didn't take long for me to find out that I actually loved what I was hearing the title of this album is in Greek and the word apocalypse actually descended from this word but in Greek it translates roughly to Revelation which can be just as cataclysmic as an apocalypse if you're interpreting it from a biblical standpoint it's not like I really get a religious vibe from this album but considering some of the song titles on here there's definitely something spiritual going on there's something just kind of otherworldly about it this thing soaks in its own atmosphere and atmosphere is the key word because this album is a little drenched in reverb which is kind of something a lot of bands are way too addicted to these days reverb is kind of like becoming the duct tape of studio recording like oh does your song sound like crap throw some reverb on it but the reverb itself isn't bad it's just finding out that there's not really anything behind the reverb on this album everything that you would want in a good song is behind the Reverb some solid playing a simple foundation of guitars drums vocals and some organ here and there and various noises and effects popping up like I'm in a haunted house kind of there are actually some tracks on here where I was hearing reversed guitars just weird wailing in the background and I just could not figure out how some of these sounds were were being made it's that kind of out there now this LP is incredibly consistent in its style it's always spiraling downwards into a hellish pit of confusion and ominous Ness there all sorts of cobwebs everywhere snakes speaking in tongues almost just just freaky shut what I love about Chelsea wolf and this album is that this album approaches darkness with a lot of different flavors sure every track is just kind of covered in the same reverb has roughly the same mixing and an instrumentation Chelsea's voice is always present but some moments on here and the vocals and the and the simple guitar and drum foundation remind me of PJ Harvey the track demons on here the pace and the rhythm of the drums in the guitar really reminds me of like Sonic Youth there's a little bit of vocal phrasing and rhythm on the last track that really reminds me of Portishead after listening to this album a bunch of times I'm absolutely sure that Chelsea is at least a little bit into Nick Cave and this might be a stretch for some people but considering how long and kind of do me some of these guitar riffs are some of the slow sludgy paces of this album I'm thinking a little bit of Earth or at least do metal as a genre going back to Black Sabbath there's an ambient sound scape on the ninth track Chelsea obviously has a lot of influences but what I like is that she brings these influences out without drowning in them she doesn't just become the artists she listens to she takes those sounds and molds to the direction that this album is moving in out of all the different things Chelsea tries on this album I'm not really finding a weak spot on here I mean yeah the the 24 second intro where she's kind of doing these black metal growls and the ambient sound scape on here were both a little bit of a surprise but shorter and more straightforward tracks on here like myrrh to me felt just as entertaining as songs that come on a lot slower like the wasteland which just starts off quiet and slowly becomes this bigger shimmering wall of sound that I feel like I could just swim in and die this album kind of shifts into a lot of different gears from beginning to end between these ten tracks but it all adds up to a really nice moody ride kind of narrated by Chelsea wolves voice which is kind of just punctuating the darkness of this album and just giving it meaning giving it direction I love the flow of this album - it doesn't just feel like the collection of songs I have to kind of listen to this thing from beginning to end to really get the full effect of it it feels like kind of a sculpture kind of like a rebuild of Pandora's box and I just want to open it again and again if you're looking for some pitch black rock music with a lot of atmosphere around it in a pretty strong female vocal this is where you want to be I'm feeling a decent - strong 8 on this thing this was nice this was a nice surprise for me but let me know what you think about this thing if you've heard it hmm love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next hope you're doing well Anthony Fantana Chelsea wolf forever [Music] I want to say thank you to everybody who actually went on that South by Southwest panel picker page that I brought up in an earlier video and voted that thing up means a lot thank you for the support thank you for trying to get tnd to South by Southwest in 2012 it means a lot spreading tnd gospel gotta do it I appreciate it thank you

it's track review man it has been a long time since we've done a track review we're here on the needle drop Anthony Fan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd reviews the latest in rock pop electronic and experimental music of the independent persuasion if in this review is the first track to drop from the upcoming Feist album metals how come you never go there now singer/songwriter Leslie Feist she is so popular I don't think I need to go into the details of how or why other than that in my opinion she's one of the more interesting in these songstress --is out there today and sadly it's been a while since we've heard from her full-length style this is gonna be the follow-up to the reminder which actually dropped in 2007 and like I said the first track to drop from this LP is how come you never go there link below this video listen let's let's listen with our ears first thing that really hit me on that track is as being really enjoyable was of course the instrumentation had a nice subtle combination of of piano bass vocals and drums right at the start and what I love about Feist's voices that it has enough personality so that I pick up on it right from the start but it's not so weird and eccentric that it sounds annoying to hear her multitrack herself basically kind of clone herself in the mix as backup vocalists what makes Feist different for me is that she's a little bit more ambitious in her phrasing she's got a wider range and she jumps all over it on this hook jumping up to those highs and then digging down into those lows this song has a nice really swaying groove to it it just makes you want to go and it's really soft really comes on easy the instrumentation here a lot like Feist's voice does not aim for a heavy impact it doesn't scream for attention but there's more going on than you may think if you're just kind of you know giving this a really quick glance there may be a different drum fill there may be a couple little piano notes added in a different vocal phrasing a little bit of horns just flying in for a quick visit it's really subtle and I like that what I like even more is that this song does not rely on the hook it doesn't rely on the chorus to kind of make the track interesting I actually like the verses more than the hook I really love listening to Feist kind of get lost in this narrative that she's singing the lyrics are kind of like a monologue of a character she's playing and the story to me I kind of feel a lot of abandonment in the lyrics I feel like there's no love but there once was love and the two people involved are trying to get it back if I had a couple of wishes for this song I wish that I heard a little bit more from the horns toward the end of the track maybe to fill the song up make it a little bit heavier and I wish the ending were a little bit more fleshed out we're a little bit more ambitious these multitrack vocals just kind of pop up like a stone wall and just stop the track just kind of like guillotine the song into ending done I could see this thing is being kind of underwhelming for some people because it's not gonna come out and punch you it's not a physical punch it's more like an emotional punch like a breakup letter you just got to read it you can't just put this song on and go internet browsing you have to pay attention I'm enjoying the hell out of this track and if this new LP maintains this really bleak sorrowful attitude it could be a nice nice fall album I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this song but what do you think of this track are you excited disappointed a little bit what do you think this new LP is going to offer and what did you like or dislike about this Anthony Fantana Feist metals forever you

emotional but maybe these guys save their really flashy playing for their live shows as a unit these guys really shine it's not like you're gonna listen to this just from the guitars or just for the vocals you're gonna listen to this because these guys are a tight band that writes some really lean catchy and great songs and maybe that could be a good thing for some people because often Zeppelin have been critiqued as being a little too indulgent for their own good you know and if you're looking for something of a hard rock style that's more straightforward more to the point maybe this is for you there are some really standout tracks on this LP for me I love pressure and time the title the guitar riff and the drum be in that song just make me want to like go downtown and just start strutting in that electric piano that pops in over the chorus great and I like that these guys can put slower and softer tracks on this LP and keep them as interesting as the more upbeat songs but I think the combination of hearing this stuff before and hearing it done better is holding me back a little bit it doesn't ruin the album for me it's nice to hear a modern sound on this kind of stuff there wasn't a single song that I hated just some impressed me more than others feeling a decent too strong seven on this liked it a lot and was pretty surprised that this album is being released on earache records ear ache records and there is an addition of this LP that comes with bonus tracks and some of those are in my opinion better than the songs that actually made it onto the LP so if you can get ahold of that do it if you've heard this thing what do you think of it loving it hating it why and what do you think I should review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantana rival sons pressure and time forever

cerebral hey everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd we're viewing the self-titled cerebral palsy album before I start this review I want to apologize for yesterday's review of the Madonna Roberts album coincoin chapter one free people of color I kept seeing her name wrong and maybe I said it wrong just now too either way it was like 4 or 5 a.m. and there were a ton of editing mistakes in the video but still those of you who enjoyed the album thank you you know just let it be known that I make mistakes lots of mistakes all the time and just sometimes I really do seriously ok these guys are in New York hardcore punk outfit this is their self-titled debut release through Williams Street which is kind of a sub little record label through Adult Swim and Turner Broadcasting Corporation and when I first came upon these guys I was really excited because they have this throwback Punk sound they just display a lot of aesthetics that I think have been missing in Punk for a while now it's just very rough very fast and very kind of grimy it feels like a New York City Street with a gutter and trash and smog and just like dirt gathering under my fingernails everywhere I go and I have no clue where it's coming from and that was my first impression I thought I was gonna love this the more time I spent with it but this thing really did a 180 on me and fast there are just so many things I guess I found missing from the album you know one thing that I love about punk music is that it's so full of energy and that it can be so full of rage and meaning and purpose but the thing is that rage and meaning and purpose is so much more significant when you know what the reasoning behind it is or you know basically what's led the singer to this point to be this angry and not that there's not a reason to be mad if bands like crafts or Dead Kennedys or even DRI were in their hay days today they would be having a field day with what's going on across the world but what keeps the lead singer of Cerebral Palsy awake at night is that people are telling him where to peak a release that came out last year the set of off EP is kind of comes to mind as a punk throwback and this stuff is fast it is furious it does have a lot of personality but the thing is you know who the targets are that frontman Keith Morris is singing about like on the track poison city which is a pretty bold statement about terrorism 9/11 propaganda not everything cerebral ballsy says needs to be on that grand of a scale but I guess I just don't understand their approach to rebellion I mean getting wasted isn't rebellious to me if it was then basically everybody who goes out to a club on the weekend is rebelling in the same way that cerebral palsy is because people who are drunk out of their minds don't want to be told where to pee either and I guess the only other thing that's really bugging me about this album and keeping me from enjoying it are the vocals and they're not the most terrible vocals in the world the vocalist of cerebral ballsy sings in a pretty established style that I've heard paired with hardcore skate punk before but his voice just has this really snotty cocky or around it that I I just I couldn't get down with I'm feeling a strong 32 a light four on this album but what do you think of it are you loving it are you hating it why and what do you think I should review next and what have been one of your favorite punk releases of this year let me know that too Anthony Fantana cerebral palsy forever

artist album title hey everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd it's time for an album review with my my special guest crickets thanks for watching this is the latest LP from saxophonist and composer botana Roberts and yes you guys convinced me to man up and review a jazz record anyway she's put out full lengths before this album she even has a live album that came out this year too but this is my first introduction to her work so it's not like I'm an expert on her earlier stuff but still this album was a really good introduction to her and I think it could be for you too if you're willing to kind of suck it up and just try something different because this thing is not your your average jazz record it experiments more than it sticks to traditions if you're a fan of avant-garde music and you've enjoyed jazz greats like Ferris Sanders some raw Alice Coltrane Ornette Coleman you will definitely feel at home with this album coincoin chapter 1 free people of color is an album of music of songs but I really think it's best to kind of approach this thing as being a story a narrative kind of a movie and this thing is chapter one in what's supposed to be a 12 chapter series six chapters of this series Madonna says have been worked on improvised written and I'm just thinking when will these 11 other pieces be heard this one album is an hour will they be her live will they ever see a print on record will they have the same narrative as this album are they going to be in a similar style have a similar sound same musicians the more I tried to read into that and Madonna's personal approach to musical notation using like visuals I just got really confused I don't really want to know how the sausage is made I would rather just the sausage be cooked and then put on my plate and I enjoy it for what it is or what I interpret it to be between the eight tracks on this album Matano goes through a lot of different jazz styles from light loungy jazz to Dixieland to modal grooves and drones as well as free jazz passages that get pretty noisy and dissonant there's even one track that just really openly embraces the sound of spirituals which really sit at the roots of jazz music and this story that this album tells that I keep alluding to is one about the ancestral history of Africans in America going all the way back to the days of slavery now being a white guy born in 1985 with European descendents from France and Sicily who traveled over here to North America a couple generations ago for a better life I cannot relate at all to what it must be like to be a slave in the 1700s but what I love about this album and Madonna's work on it is she takes her emotions for this ancestral history and translates them into music in such a way where it impacts me and makes me feel like I relate in a way or not really relate but just feel deep and painful emotions for what she's saying and what she's trying to convey on this album with celebration and fear and confusion and suffering this thing really covers the emotional spectrum and it all comes out ringing loud and clear but musically it's very noisy harsh taxing and experimental at a lot of points it can be really difficult to translate and wade through the music on this thing really kind of brings me down too depressing lows and and of soaring high as one right after another the introduction to this album rise is really sporadic really kind of awkwardly disjointed not one of my favourite tracks on the album because things feel so disconnected on that particular track but it serves a purpose with a really tense and kind of ugly soundscape of horns strings piano upright bass drum rolls in every direction it just really kind of creates this pull that snaps on the second track when the music basically explodes and I mean explodes in a way that I've never really heard an album explode before not only is all the instrumentation just boiling over like lava out of a volcano but Madonna is screaming blood-curdling screaming she's just screaming murder and not like screaming in a really obnoxious or annoying way for me that's it never came off that way though sometimes screaming on an album can make me feel like that it was more like a painful scream a scream of of suffering of heartbreak and it literally breaks my heart to hear it over and over as much as I am kind of drawn to the uniqueness that I feel in that track and this album it's still not very easy to listen to the song falls into a groove and Madonna through some spoken word just presents this character that she's drawn up to play this narrative that she wants to weave together she's 16 she's a slave she's being bought and sold her parents died of yellow fever it's a song that plays every single time Madonna needs to kind of come forward and push this narrative again and tell you more about this person who she's talking about the second time you hear about her she's 25 and her master seems to be kind of forcing himself upon her and having kids with her at first I didn't really like her spoken word I didn't like how jumpy and and jittery it was but as I kind of returned to the album and listen to it more I just came to appreciate what she was saying and how tense she needs that moment to kind of be when she's describing this character and telling the story on the fifth track the lyrics lay heavily into a spiritual but the lyrics diss but the lyrics disturbingly paint a picture of people being lined up to be bought and sold and just auctioned off there's only so much I can really say about that track I feel like some people will be too cynical to take it seriously but I found it too disturbing to really kind of put into words and by the last track this character that Madonna is playing is speaking for has been released by her master and has had kids with this guy for almost and as kids with this guy for like 19 years and she now has land is working it is making money and is doing her best to buy back her kids and other people as well it's a pretty powerful story just enhanced by all of this tense and and beautiful jazz music and it does have its upsides it does have its really difficult moments I mean I found a lot of this album to just kind of make me sick to my stomach literally literally sick like and kind of disgusted and not in a in a white guilt kind of way like I feel directly responsible and guilty for slavery because I'm a white guy I'm just more shocked at the sheer inhumanity of this whole situation this album stares boldly into the face of inhumanity for a very very long time longer than most people would be willing to bear musically I guess the only issues that I have with this album is the first track feels pretty disjointed and maybe it's not the the strongest introduction to this album for me I felt like it could have been a little bit more to the point and the last track though I enjoy the sentiment behind it it feels a little kind of anticlimactic or uneventful for me it does kind of end on a lighter note but it's not like maybe the the climax or the explosion that I was hoping for but maybe that's what will make this album kind of a perfect lead-in into chapter 2 which I hope gets released this is a very strong album it's a very bold bold album and definitely unlike a lot of the music you're going to hear this year so at least go into this expecting that there's a link below this video somewhere on the needle drop com2 or you can string the entire thing in full let me know what you think I'm feeling a light to decent 8 on this Anthony Fantana Madonna Roberts coincoin chapter 1 free people of color you
