oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Shabazz Palaces black up right there sitting there gonna be there all week okay Beirut is a project spearheaded by multi-instrumentalist Zac Condon and this is his third LP third full-length LP under the project the riptides so Beirut when I first came into this band it was pretty exciting because around that time in college a professor of mine had recently introduced me to Balkan brass music gypsy music Romanian music klezmer and ever since then I've had kind of a soft spot for that stuff and anything that you know kind of tries to be like it the kind of sounds that that bands like a hawk and a hacksaw recreate so lovingly and so well it's not new for a western band to be kind of toying with this sort of stuff but Beirut to me was a little bit different in that Zac Condon really wanted to write pop songs but was still so in love still so enamored with this sound and style it just had to be incorporated into his music he seemed really like kind of dedicated to the origins of this kind of stuff and making that really clear in his music I mean he even collaborated with one of mine and and I'm sure there one of his favorite Balkan brass bands the cocaine II orcas star if you check out B roots first record gulag workers star there's just a mood there that isn't usually there in western music with the really weepy horns and accordion and and strings and piano just just really weepy really mournful I don't mean sad I don't mean depressed I mean mourning and Zach took that sound and really just like translated and translated it for a Western audience there were poppier on that album like postcards from Italy but that stuff wasn't the the main event for me the main event the majority of the stuff on there really had deep roots in that Eastern European flavor then after that came the Flying Club Cup in 2007 and there was a change there the songs seemed a little simpler a little poppier but it resulted in catchy ER songs something that was a little more immediate plus the recording was better there were some awesome string arrangements on there from Owen Pallett and it just seemed like the natural progression past gulag things fell silent for a little bit and then Zack dropped these 2 EPS together real people Holland and March of the zapotec real people Holland was something from another solo project of Zacks which was really more of an electrified indie pop sound but March of the zapotec achieved something that I always wanted to happen for Beirut a really gigantic huge live hit Orchestra sized horn section not multitrack horns thrown together in a studio real actual horn section playing arrangements and songs that he's putting together perfect recording and great musicianship just bringing it all together for just a massive and emotional set of songs and now we're here with the Riptide and I can't help but feel like we've moved backwards just a little bit those 2 EPS that Zac released in 2009 they were on such opposite ends of this spectrum that it was hard to love both of them but now after I hear this I can I can hear why he wanted to print both of them because his love of really simplified pop music comes on strong with the Riptide in comparison with the Flying Club Cup and Gulag orca star this thing comes to the table with less less detail in the arrangements less length less foreign flavor and less energy it's hard for me to feel that way and be happy you know what I mean the songs on this are simple and the songs on the Flying Club cup are simple too but the trade-off on that album was that you know the songs are simple but the Arrangements come on heavy they're everywhere they're intricate they're very layered and there's always something new you could pull out of them making it worth it to return to this album and listen to it again and again and again they're still horn sections on here but none of them weep none of them really a Moute none of them Papa they just all kind of fly in between verses to to just break things up a little bit East Harlem vagabond Santa Fe Zak's horns have kicked more butt than this they have they have and you know I can appreciate simpler simpler is cool but these heftier horn arrangements these heftier instrumental passengers haven't been replaced with anything the songs just feel a little neutered most of the tracks on here just consist of of several different chords I mean the first two songs pretty much had the same chord progression but in different keys the same chord progression in a different key that is used behind the song Nantes on the Flying Club cup this thing isn't entirely bad though I still dig Zacks vocals a lot and the songs I gravitate toward the most are the ones where he's digging into that a lot his vocals his singing on port of call is great I love his emotion on that and hearing him sing over that pump organ drone I assume it's a pump organ on the peacock is really dramatic too still all the instruments are on this album just like they used to be there was a little bit of a flash of indie pop flavor here and there like on the song Santa Fe with the with the bouncing synthesizers that open up the track and for the most part the music here still implies stuff like baguettes and wine and candlelit dinners on the balconies of of expensive and fancy five-star hotels and Downton Abbey it's just that to me the riptides is like a night in Paris whereas flying Club Cup is like a week and gulag work as stars like a year backpacking through Europe visiting every country that you possibly can still this thing is a beirut album I would rather listen to this and I feel more definition in this than any number of low fire or synth-pop bands who all sound the same but I still can't help but feel like I've heard this done before better by this project I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this what did you guys think of it love it hate it why but what does Cal two just think u.s.a u.s.a u.s.a u.s.a forever

hop instrumental hip hop kind of glitching it out experimenting with it an eidm every release after that would kind of switch lanes between being more hip-hop influenced or being more IDM influenced and it kind of came to him even embracing that wonky hip-hop sound coming out of LA from producers like Flying Lotus this is on that album want to 1/2 it sounded like he was embracing dubstep a little bit on some of the tracks from that LP but he went even deeper into that wonky sound on the mini LP he put out afterwards many phases on the first half of it on the second half he plays with a lot of house and 2-step songs but now the sounds of future garage and this new sparse take on dubstep is hot and now he's kind of doing something that could be compared to joy Orbison burial DL Scooba like any other record in this style there are a lot of broken clunky complicated beats that just click tap pop heavy bass sounds rumbling away in the background not the wubwubwub they're just a lot of thick synthesized bass and there's a ton of atmosphere around the synthesizers the vocal samples but there is something very different about machine drum on this thing he isn't very bleak he isn't very atmospheric like a lot of artists chasing this style he just saturates the mix with tons of different sounds and textures and I would say it like kind of works in layers like a lot of electronic music does you know one sound on top of another sound like a lasagna or something like that but this is like more of a 3d experience with sounds popping up all over the place it's like a galaxy of different sounds with stars popping up here here back there Arang from your face which makes it kind of dizzying to listen to on headphones it's really obvious that this new string of producers coming out of the UK is influencing this guy but he really produces these tracks to be thick and cacophonous like a producer would who was making a drum and bass track or a jungle track in the 90s but sometimes this dude's love of experimental hip hop instrumentals does kind of come back to haunt some of these tracks a little bit like with the very fat clumsy heavy beat that would totally fit in a brain feeder on the track sacred frequency the song universe actually even sounds like something Flying Lotus would do sans the auto-tune vocal samples I do like the future Garage sound that machine drum is is emulating on some of these tracks but once he starts breeding that style with other things some real Frankenstein's kind of pop out like G B ye where this guy really goes trigger-happy with the vocal samples and the auto-tune there's no possible way to escape them it's like really overkill it's like taking a bazooka to go deer hunting still despite what genre hopping this album does it comes off pretty cohesive pretty solid stylistically and that's mostly because machine drum make sure that the sounds that are being used are always high-quality he really lays into these vocal samples keeps those consistent and every single one of these tracks just keeps a really constant groove my main issue is that some of these tracks just function simply on throwing as much sound out there as possible without really placing them in a really interesting way and at first I was like yeah this is fun this is colorful this is overwhelming I like it but the more I visited this record the more I kind of saw through the clouds the parting clouds the more I kind of sorted out the clutter the more I realized the magic just kind of was disappearing for me the title track is a good example which you know I thought was pretty good at first but now that I have everything on it all kind of separated and interpreted I'm just still there are some standouts on here I think it's a pretty solid release overall I just wish it stuck more truly to these dubstep and future Garage sounds that made machine drum kind of turn in this direction in the first place because to me those are the best tracks on here I think we should ask coucher Chesto what he thinks if this is a dubstep they like to hear some DEP run or Deb jump and that's why I hate him what do you think of this thing do dis mah towards the megalith hahaha Anthony fan tanto here the Internet's sweatiest music nerd doing an album review of the new disma LP towards the megalith this is going to be something that doesn't make a lot of people happy it's a metal review but no come up come back come on come on come on go come on sit down it's alright so I want you to follow me on this one come on thank you between all the members in dyzma these guys have like a couple lifetimes of experience and playing various styles of extreme metal and this album fits pretty snugly into the style of death metal it's a style I don't cover often and I've said why before I don't like a lot of the modern sounds coming out of the genre the drum triggers the really overused compression just to make the music sound louder and it kills the dynamics the thin digital recordings the melodic passage is trying to pretty death-metal up or just emphasizing technical ability over the overall sound of the music some people are like even singing kind of clean over it you can call me a purist if you want I like my death metal freaky and gory like a horror movie with blood pouring out of the walls and people screaming for dear life which is why I prefer the earlier sounds from the genre like death or more of an angel they had a new one out that I thought I didn't like that much or autopsy but they also had a new one that I didn't like too much or even the band incantation which is a group Dismas frontman Craig pillared used to sing for in the early nights with all of these older bands from the 80s and 90s to sort of keeping the idea alive and this new sea of bands coming in I feel like dyzma still stands out the group has this really slow heavy doom metal approach to death metal that they kind of carried on from the early days of incantation and like those off EPS I reviewed last year I kind of get the feeling that maybe this album is an attempt to reclaim glory from the past and that's a good and a bad thing because while yet it's it's good that disma takes a pure approach to this death metal sound and really relives it in a big way but it's not like they really reinvent the wheel or anything stylistically you've got a lot of basics on this album just double bass drums tremolo picking on the guitars really crackling distortion thick heavy distorted bass that's really murky muddy filthy blast beats a lot of chromatic riffs and leads also tempo changes and of course we have the cookie monster vocal on this album too it's a name I hate to put on that style because it makes it sound silly but if you really listen to this album on a big stereo kinda high volume there's a lot of obvious technical precision he's not just fooling around or making noises he does what a lot of death metal vocalists only try to do sound like an honest-to-god monster I mean listen to him his voice sounds like it's it's almost swallowing all of the music behind it he sounds like the mighty Kraken awakening from like a millennium long slumber and he's like punching the Statue of Liberty in the face and plunging its claws into skyscrapers and like eating the people it pulls out this dude's voice just just goes the extra mile for me it's so low and it's got so much Rumble in this mix it was kind of actually like listening to a Atilla singing on Suns past album monoliths and dimensions sometimes he's got these long-winded growls and other times just like this really ugly Koff like wreck bruh and you know all of it just kind of sends chills up my sideburns and then to the top of my head where my brain starts melting the vocals are huge on here but the music is is almost as massive it doesn't sound like your average metal band recording it's kind of encompassing I'm surrounded by this music I feel like I'm in this album while I'm listening to it it sounds like so panoramic like the music is just going on all around me like I've been sucked into this alternate dimension where demons are decapitating people and throwing the corpses into like a lava bath while they laugh maniacally throw a blast beat behind that and you've got a pretty ugly intense situation going on there and things get even better once they kind of let go of that release it and go into a breakdown get really slow get really sludgy and there's a nice balance between these moments - I didn't feel like these guys laid on being too slow being too fast it was a nice even mix of all these different paces I never felt like a part or an idea went on too long or too short never really felt like anything was too undeveloped but to be honest as far as like standout tracks and moments go on this album I can't say they're there any it's not like there's a catchy track or a really light track or a really melodic track this thing is this solid ball of evil I don't so much see this album as a series of eight tracks it's more like a bunch of very ugly and disturbing moments that last 44 minutes these guys for me make death metal really grimy and really ugly again and I love that not an easy job to do in 2011 this is monstrous this is scary this is serious this is a strong eight to a light nine for me disma towards the megalith forever

They Might Be Giants join us hi everyone he hath anu Fantana here the internets giantest music nerd album review time this is why I love reviewing music because I get to talk about some bands that I love to a group of people who are as excited about music as I am so this review is of the new album join us from they might be giants a Brooklyn band started by singing songwriting duo John flans Berg and John Linnell the John's and easily these guys are one of the nerdiest bands on the planet but we know around here that being nerdy is a huge compliment in fact I think if it wasn't for my nerdiness I wouldn't enjoy songs about shoehorns or cranes or cows or beards or racist friends or mammals or skulls this bands lyrics and song subjects have always made them stand out but they've been paired usually with great pop hooks fantastic melodies bold experimentation and an unmistakable personality They Might Be Giants may not always come out with a great record but they have never made a faceless record even after all of the music that I've heard in my very short lifetime They Might Be Giants stuff still ranks as some of the most fun music I've ever heard for me it stops just short of being a joke for some these guys will be too absurd to take seriously but I need some absurdity in my life every now and then and they might be giants as the perfect place to get it for me now lately these guys have been putting out a lot of kids albums a lot of children's music but still it's not even like their adult music plays to an adult sensibility they're usually playing to the kid in every adult on the face of planet but if you are counting children's albums join us if I'm correct is they might be giants fifteenth studio album there's been a lot of evolution up until this point but I would say the band's recent stuff their recent adult albums have been pretty great at translating their eccentric personality through some modern production and a full band now it's not like they might be giants are going back to their roots on this LP or anything but join us really does come down to sounds and songs for me the songs are pretty on point not everyone is a hit but there's a lot of classic they might be giants on here some tracks are solid but very simple others with very difficult weird and complexly layered vocals that are singing in rounds spots that are almost hilarious spots where songs pause ridiculously esoteric lyrics like an old pine box or even moments that would probably be hilarious to everybody like the track when will you die yeah that's that's about wishing someone was dead and they're great hooks coming from both Linnell and flans berg like on the really jazzy protagonists or the the the small-scale rock anthem canada harry there could have been more experimental tracks on here though these guys are known for really working outside of the box and and being somewhat zany but i guess i don't get enough of that there are two different sets of lyrics going on in the left channel and the right channel on spoiler alert that's pretty funny dog walker has pitch shifted vocals which and i didn't care for it's different ground for these guys but there's a spot on here where john f-- Landsberg is narrating the voice of a raindrop on cloisonne where he just so you know not only is this thing not really pushing all that many boundaries for for they might be giants but to be honest the the sound here on this album really is not doing it for me at all now the sound isn't terrible it's not like it's it's terrible quality it's not like it's weird or anything like that I guess for the first time the instrumentation behind the John's songs sounds a little generic it's not like I mistook they might be giants for another band or anything like that but on a lot of these songs the the sound of the guitars the bass the drums and the keyboards they kind of feel like they could have been generated by like like any group to me on earlier records the guitars have sounded fuller the woodwinds and brass have sounded more eccentric this just doesn't sound like the usual level of color and quality join us kind of sounds like a live session recorded at a radio station or something like that not a fully completed and detailed and rich piece of studio work in comparison the else and the spine are way less flimsy sonically it's kind of like hearing my usual they might be giants but there's like a the thin film of dust on it that like I'm rubbing at it with extra listens and it just will not come off and don't get me wrong there are spots on here where the songs are so good that the sound the plainer sound I guess doesn't really bother me I mean is the band maturing are they trying to distance themselves from the from the quirky label that people always throw on to them are they trying to put together something that is simpler more skeletal something that's easier to execute live but yes to any of these questions on paper sounds great it sounds really good but if it's gonna make an album like join us I mean I'm gonna have to advocate being immature being quirky and throwing all of the complications into overdrive so I'm feeling of 5 to 6 on this record it's not terrible but it's definitely not going to go down in history as one of my favorite They Might Be Giants albums but if this is the first time you're hearing of the band or if for some reason you've heard of them before but you haven't checked them out don't let this album deter you if you do check it out and you don't like it if you're going to get into these guys their first for albums you cannot go wrong they sit proudly in my personal collection especially Lincoln if you haven't heard this album please check it out to not like it is to not like fun but if you were they might be Giants fan let me know what you think of this LP love it hey that why do you feel the same way I do about the sound of this record and if not let me know and what do Portugal man hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's manliest music nerd and the album review Portugal the man in the mountain in the cloud this is the second time I'm reviewing something from this Alaskan band on this YouTube channel but this is definitely not my second run-in with them I've been following them since I got turned on to their LP censored colors in 2008 which actually became one of my favourite releases of that year but maybe that album was a bad place to start because ever since I heard censored colors I haven't liked anything Portugal the man has put out since then I haven't liked any of it for me the satanic Satanist and especially American ghetto are the opposite of censored colors because they're so condensed they're so shortened they're they're simplified they're plainly structured too much to really give me the same rush of energy that the songs on censored colors did and for me this album returns to a little bit the same ambition and big production experience that I fell on censored colors on this album Portugal the man really let's it's David Bowie influences fly to drumming up something that is equal parts psychedelic rock glam rock indie and baroque pop nearly all of these flavors hit on the very first track of the album with these guitar chords syncopated with the drums this big joyous bright rock chorus a lot of strings tightly wound around this chorus too and just a lot of instrumentation backing the song up in general it kind of felt like something I could hear t-rex doing but the style that the band goes for on that track they don't vary too far from it on a lot of these songs it's kind of like hearing the same thing executed again and again and again and again and not that that's the worst thing in the world but some moments were clearly more exciting than others for me and still Portugal demand is is not ready to give up its desire to condense its songs they want to throw more instrumentation in more layers more everything but they don't want to give these tracks more time to grow and breathe and explore like on the track floating I'm barely getting a taste of the verses on this song because I'm hearing the ooo chorus so many times not only that but but but a lot of these choruses sound pretty similar similar two songs these guys have written in the past and songs that are on this album as I'm listening to a hook on this LP I hear memories of other ones echoing in my mind and this is something that usually goes away as I listen to an album more and more oh some of the tracks sound the same I'll listen more I'll learn and I'll hear the differences in the subtleties but the more I listen to this thing the stronger that feeling became still that's that's just my opinion and and there definitely are tracks on here that stick out for me God it all is a great single for this album it's passionate it's invigorating it's a great use of the strings that Portugal the man broked this album out with and the verses have the perfect and the verses have a great amount of breathing room and do I hear some bongos in the background of this track if if I do nice touch the track all your light just brings things down lets things simmer it's a great kind of lower darker point that I wish this album had more tracks like there's a spot of acoustic ballad Rhian once was one and my favorite track which shouldn't be hard to figure out if you've been listening to my gripes is the last one which clocks in at 6 minutes this track takes its time introducing the vocals the electric guitar the swelling strings the cymbal rolls before it falls into a groove and then it saves it's all an explosion for the end and I just find that much more gratifying than three to five semi explosions in one single track though this LP is a step in the right direction I just found too many similarities between a lot of these tracks to really kind of want me to return to them again and again again and I'm not talking about instrumentally I mean Portugal demand is usually pretty good on this LP about kind of featuring spotlighting a different instrument in each song what I'm talking about here is melody chord progression and key I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this LP I know that isn't an exciting number for some of you but it's exciting to me actually because I haven't liked anything these guys have done since censored colors to find myself at least digging this LP a little bit is nice what do you think of this LP love it hate it why what should i review next you're the best thank you for watching Anthony Fantana Portugal the man forever you

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review toxic Holocaust conjure and command I went back and looked at some of my favorite LPS of this year so far and this is definitely one of 2011's more grim moments the personality and just attitude this LP is so horrifyingly ugly that it really ranks up there with Death Grips for me but this is not an experimental hip-hop album it's actually a thrash album the fourth to come out from this project fronted by multi-instrumentalist Joel grind who up until this point recorded and performed all of his albums himself his demos to the stars have really aligned for toxic Holocaust Joel is not solo anymore the project is performing with its best recording quality to date and this album offers up some of the most immediate and pummeling thrash hybrids I've heard in a while because toxic Holocaust is is not just a thrash metal band there have always been elements of hardcore punk crust punk and black metal powering the sound behind this music too but on Condren Command the aroma of black metal is kind of fading in the air and that's not necessarily a bad thing I actually think it's led to something with a lot more impact even on my first listen this LP was getting me really pumped and excited like some of my thrash crossover favorites I know this doesn't really have a classic sound like something from the cro-mags or suicidal tendencies may but I still get that same feeling here of just this unstoppable force the sound of this release is a little different from previous efforts there's little to no reverb on this thing it's not really drenched in effects it's pretty dry actually very lean the beefy as well it's nothing but muscle and bone dismembered limbs and corpses and it sounds so good on my stereo when I crank this thing oh it's so good loud the drums are fantastic the snare is really nice and punchy the cymbals aren't mixed too high like they were on previous toxic holocaust LPS and the rhythm guitars have a nice coarse grinding texture to them it's kind of like rubbing my fingers across some sandpaper or getting dragged across asphalt by a rope tied to the back of a pickup truck and joel grinds vocals for me he walks this perfect tightrope act of just being so forced and so loud that it holds my attention but he's not so extreme that i get tired of hearing him really quickly overall the sound of this album is very filthy it's very thick it's very grimy very grimy thrash album all the songs are covered in this really similar grime eNOS so much so to the point where when some of these tracks fly by even on the second listen of this LP you might get the feeling of oh this is Sammy Sammy but believe me when I say that that's not the case my eyes my ears kind of needed to adjust to the apocalyptic fog that these songs bring so this thing did offer a little bit more every time I listen to it again and actually it wasn't until my last listen that I really started getting into the lyrics and basically the words are about every ugly terrible thing that mankind has ever done lots of imagery of of dying breaths being hunted down by a murderer eating the rotting flesh of dead dogs nuclear fallout there's even the track on here where a woman is being burned at the stake because of course she is being religiously persecuted though the ugly picture is nice what I like most about the lyrics is that most of them are are detailing a store and that's what makes them really stick with me but even the less wordy moments on this LP still come off really great to me because the sound the riffs and the energy are all high quality because this thing is a thrash crossover record it's more of a focus on the grooves the breakdowns the momentum of these songs not really the the flashing musicianship that may pull some metal fans into their favorite thrash albums but I will say these guys are not as punked out as a lot of crossover acts maybe because there are some spots on here where I do notice some nice guitar solos even if they're short I noticed some key changes and some harmonious guitar layering that I think a more punked out band would would avoid and even though toxic Holocaust doesn't change it up a lot on this album it's not like I really need them to this thing only lasts 33 minutes I only have 10 tracks it's a nice quick shot of and this album definitely serves as a nice modern middle ground that I think metal fans and Punk fans can approach with excitement I'm feeling a decent too strong 8 on this loved the the hell out of it really enjoyable but what do you think of this album did you like it did you hate it why and what should I review next thanks for watching love you Anthony Fantana toxic Holocaust forever

but cooler kids ride the bicycle Anthony Fantana the Internet's cruelest no busiest music nerd and it's album review time the cool kids when fish ride bicycles I've been getting a lot of requests for this one and you know what I was excited to do it too because i can't believe it's been three years since i was introduced to these guys on the bake sale EP it almost feels like yesterday when i was listening to chuck english and mikey rock spit funny rhymes about cars and clothes over that chunky beats that rumbled my stereo but after bakesale dropped to me the cool kids kind of lost a lot of momentum I know we got some mixtape action in between then and now but the mixtapes weren't that impressive and my expectations weren't that high to begin with because they were free mixtapes and even though on this LP the cool kids sound roughly the same the more I listened the more I kind of realized I'm not dealing with the same people I was in 2008 one thing I do love about this LP though is something that I think has remained intact and stayed awesome about the cool kids that's the beats Chuck Inglish is production is fantastic it sounds so heavy so crisp it just has so much impact and yet the sounds aren't overbearing there's not a lot of stuff being thrown at me they're very simple beats they're loud but sparse and just really focus on the bass those heavy rhythms they're just a giant and tasty in and simple it's like just jamming ten pieces of bubble gum in your mouth all at once and chewing them up and then blowing a bubble four times bigger than your head they have a sound that is creative fun and playful that you don't hear often in modern hip-hop something that I feel like was was lost a little bit after the 80s another thing about cool kids that's on point for me for the most part or the hooks most of them are pretty monotone and repetitive mantras but that doesn't stop them from being catchy but even the tracks that feature singing on the hook some some R&B influences aren't that bad either like the song boomin or the track swimsuits featuring mayer hawthorne i think summer jam is really the only track on here that has a hook that borders on being a little too corny but my major gripe with this LP my problem and it's a big problem really keeps me from enjoying it the rapping the cool kids have never been the most lyrical duo in hip-hop it's not really what they're known for but to me there was a lyrical side to them there was more of a balance on the bake sale now they've kind of devolved into creating an album that is is hip hop for people that don't even listen to the rapping there's less wordplay on this album and overall the lyrics are less impressive and less memorable I really only came away with a couple lyrics that to me were kind of impressive kind of I like the lyric got endo got out dough on bundle up and I also like who lyric I'm part place you're Marvin gardens hmm outside of that the lyrics just make really plain and obvious observations about fantasy situations involving girls clothes and cars a few funny similes here and there this thing is basically as mindlessly materialistic as a rick ross album but it's somehow cool because it's marketed toward the indie crowd seriously the only verses on this thing catching my attention are the verses from the features specifically Ghostface Killah and bun B from UGK because on here the cool kids rapping just sounds so lazy so uneventful it doesn't hold my attention I'm just not really tasting anything but rapping and lyricism just just isn't what makes this record and the cool kids know that because this LP focuses more on letting the instrumentals play out and repeating the hooks more than they really should be repeated because they're just padding things out there are a few spots here where there's more of a balance between lyrics and in the hooks and the instrumental like on GMC that track a little bit reminds me of when I first came upon these guys but there aren't enough moments like that to really keep me hooked on when fish ride this is basically a rap album for people who don't want Tyler the creators goblin to be the only rap album on their iPod it's basically come to the cool kids producing beer commercial rap or Mountain Dew it's a nice album to just kind of have on and do other things to you know soundtrack to a beach party soundtrack to getting baked in a Brooklyn apartment with 30 other people if that's your thing then by all means but me personally I'm kind of feeling a strong 4 on this album didn't like it could see other people liking it more than me definitely but this this is not for me and in a real letdown but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana the cool kids went fish ride bicycles forever you

do 10 more hi everyone Anthony Fantana you're the Internet's busiest uh music nerd its album review time Touche amore parting the sea between brightness and me now if you guessed from that title that this California 5 piece has a lot to say you guessed correctly this is the band sophomore LP and with a lot of improvements on their sound production mixing just recording quality these guys have put together what to me is easily one of the most open honest and therapeutic cathartic albums of 2011 and this music is of a style I don't usually cover on the channel mostly because my love for it really doesn't stray too far into the 2000s whether or not you want to call it post hardcore scream Oh emo core whatever so because I'm not into a lot of recent stuff from these genres I was surprised to catch myself enjoying this but where to start because there's a lot to say about this LP despite the fact that it is only 20 minutes spread across 13 tracks first off I think the production is the easiest thing to touch down upon it's most likely the best thing this album has going for it the vocals are mixed really high but for good reason the guitars are really grating but equally harmonious and the drums just really pump they drive this record those crashes are just so bright and just so harsh and the bass is just really warm and thick and a very nice counter to a lot of the more aggressive sounds on this LP overall with the recording this album is really on point the band sounds like there they're playing this stuff live in the moment together it doesn't feel rigid it doesn't feel plastic it's very mush loud in a live album now as far as the style goes this very emotional brand of rock music don't take the volume and the screaming as just anger this is not an angry album if anything this album comes off more lonely fearful stressed and depressed if this album is angry it's only anger fueled by those emotions and you hear about these emotions and the stories behind them through these very ultra poetic flowery flowery lyrics and do they get corny yes they do they get very corny I actually think most people would be too cynical not to laugh at these lyrics if they were just written down on a piece of paper really the only thing keeping me from laughing is how sin  sear the band's vocalist is when he's saying this stuff and that's really kind of a part of the appeal of this album I mean the vocals and the lyrics are just so overpowering and so prominent I found myself listening to this thing a lot like I would a hip hop album with the lyrics kind of taking precedent over the music behind them and these words are always delivered in a very serious and desperate tone and some of them go over better than others for me I do love spots like and for my final trick I will make everyone who loves me disappear but I won't know how to bring them back there are so many spots where I really feel like I can quote this LP they really sound like the kind of band who would play at a basement show where the air is so thick with heat and sweat it's difficult to breathe and where 75% of the people attending know all the lyrics and they're screaming along but there are other lyrics like not picking up my phone driving a low damaged goods damaged goods damaged goods rain clouds those spots I could really kind of take or leave so yeah this LP is kind of overly emotional it's a little sappy it's a little achy but I wouldn't charge it as being weak or soft because of that the words feel very vulnerable but the music behind them isn't the music really charges the words on this LP and kind of makes this whole thing feel like a very relieving experience like the vocalist is empowered by saying all this stuff and just letting it go these guys have a serious Punk spirit kind of flowing throughout this album and they know that their style is best suited in small increments which is why many of these songs are pretty brief and to the point but in a lot of these short tracks these guys still manage to throw a lot in take the song artificial building drum rolls that segue into booming chords the band breaks it down in the halftime then they just go full-speed they break it into a climax it sounds like three different things in itself I'm always impressed by how much these guys throw into their music but that can be sort of a default sometimes because there are spots where these songs do come off more disjointed than connected kind of like the puzzle pieces are really being forced into each other and as long as I'm kind of hopping on the complain train I guess I could have used a more variety on this LP especially in the vocals a lot like that  up album I reviewed earlier this year hearing the voice not just do the same tricks over and over and over but basically settle into these mid-range screens throughout the LP kind of wears me down a little bit as exciting as this album can be on a lot of these tracks still as I was repeating this LP again and again to try to get to know it then review it I was giving myself get a little bit of a headache we'll admit it some narrations would have been nice some more harmony and melody would have been Ace even if it is loud the only real change in color on this album is on condolences where there's a soul piano with lyrics screaming of course that kind of asks the listener if they've ever fantasized about their funeral and what music would play which we've all done still despite all the positive things I have to say about this LP I don't know if a lot of you are really going to be into it and I think it mostly has to do with maybe your perspective versus the perspective of the people creating this album I mean this LP is offended at how cheap and ritualistic everyday interactions and relationships are because a lot of people are so fake and avoid honesty at all costs for the sake of being accepted getting along and all that BS most people have been worn down to the point where wearing a mask every day is normal but just because it's normal does that make it good or right or what should be that's the question this album asks and after waiting out my likes versus my dislikes of this LP I am not in love with this album but these guys have my respect and this album has been enjoyed feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing but what do you think of it do you like it do you hate it and why what should i our view next and why am i whispering let me know anthony fans hana to shame or forever [Music] you

sorry hello my needle drops Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busy use music nerd and it's time for an album review zombie escape velocity zombie is a duo one of my favorite duo's which is why it makes absolutely no sense whatsoever that it's taking me until now to talk about their new album but now that I'm feeling this record up and down in a very sexy way if you can imagine it I'm liking what I'm hearing because the music on this thing moves in a very interesting direction for these guys zombie plays a very sound track ready style of synthesizer rock that has been changing a little bit over the course of the duo's past two LPs slowly these guys have been drifting away from their dependence on the synthesizer drifting away from their tangerine dream roots and now they're incorporating more bass guitar more electric guitar and even more acoustic guitar all of it reached a peak on the album's spirit animal which might had been too much of a change for some fans it was a thicker sound a heavier sound a more rock-oriented sound but I liked it it was a lot less Spacey but to me still very thought-provoking with zombie dishing out one long-winded and femme ik epic after another escape velocity basically throws all of the instruments Sambi has been furnishing their music with out the window and they basically get back to the basics of drums and synthesizers of course that doesn't mean this zombie LP feels empty less lush less sound heavy because Steve more just fills in all of these newly formed gaps with more synthesizers just bubbling arpeggios that are sequenced and carry out through an entire tract just wailing synth leads some synth sounds that even sound like horns at some points nearly all of the five songs here really function on an ark really slow quiet introduction to begin things and slowly the sounds get louder more instruments sort of introduced themselves more melodies phrases just repeat into this never-ending groove the grooves get harder tension builds and I like that I like that kind of stuff my issue is that some of the arcs on this album are more tense more thrilling more climactic than others like the title track for instance I wish it were a little bit more subtle and also it kind of exposes the issue that some people may have about zombie it's that you know the drums are really great AEE Patera is a fantastic drummer and he just puts so much intricacy into his fills his changes all of that but sometimes hearing him laid against these repeating synthesizer phrases that are just kind of punched into this one tempo can't expose how flat zombie can feel sometimes maybe you know just needing a little bit more of a human touch my favorite song on the album that was d-iii which is a great combination of this new stripped-down version of zombie where they're getting back to their roots and also the more ambitious directions they were pursuing on spirit animal because that song doesn't really function on one single arc there are many climaxes throughout the track it's really a rollercoaster ride that not only goes up and down but twists sideways it's it's the most multi-dimensional song on the album the last track cuts out a little early for me with a fade-out and the thing is my only real issue with this LP is that the entire album itself cuts out a little early I know we've had some solo stuff coming out building up until this point but still considering this band's last album was three years ago and it was almost an hour long to hear these guys only make music for 34 minutes is a little hmm still this is another solid zombie album for me that comes on slow reveals more detail with each listen and sounds like something that would be best fit for the soundtrack of a 70s or 80s b-movie that has some kind of storyline that that takes place in space where this space pirate has become a stowaway on this military ship and he's climbing through the air ducts and shooting people with lasers who are wearing uniforms and and basically taking over the ship he's kind of like a space pirate ninja of course this movie is loaded with with terrible effects and dialogue and acting but hey the soundtrack is good basically feeling a strong seven to eight on this album but let me know what you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana zombie escape velocity breath

guess who has a new album out the horrors well hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review this is the third LP from UK rock outfit the horrors and before the band put this LP up streaming for free on their website they dropped the single still life which I loved a lot got me really kind of psyched for the record now if you've listened to this band's first LP you know they were off to a very bold and eccentric start just those dissonant guitars that organ the speed the aggression the forced vocals and with the hair and the clothes just the the image these guys were broadcasting it kind of bordered on gimmicky maybe a little bit but things got refined on the band's second LP it's like the sideshow and the music finally hit this perfect balance and the group really found a way to make slower and moodier songs but still make them carry the same impact the same punch that they're louder and faster tunes do of course it's not like they were completely in the dark when they were going about this they definitely wore their post-punk influences on their sleeves now on skying things mature even more mature almost to the point where it's not as exciting or thrilling as it used to be to listen to these guys maybe and not to say this is a terrible LP it's a good enlike Abul LP it's just got some very underwhelming potholes for me my main issue with some of the tracks on skying has to do with the effects and the atmosphere surrounding some of these songs I mean honestly I'm fed up with groups lathering their music in so much reverb and so much echo it really no longer becomes about the music a lot of the effects that the horrors throw on their music on this LP don't define or tell or explain or color they obscure they cover they veil in a way that makes the horror scene kind of faceless I could think of a few groups in recent memory that have kind of made albums with similar effects and came up with something unique like no age crystal stilts women as well but in the case of skying the effects on this LP just end up taking what makes this band stand out what makes them unique and putting them on the backburner putting them in a spot where they can't really be heard or seen look at the track changing the rain if I wasn't told that was a horror song I would have never ever ever guessed and who is singing on the track is it Ferris Rotter I don't know I can only assume so because it doesn't sound like him it just sounds like every other band using this level of effects I pretty much feel the same way out dive in and and wide-eyed they're just all these really syrupy atmospheres and emotions floating around and really no pancake to go with it my favorite tracks on skying are the leaner tracks the more simple tracks the less effect heavy tracks the more straightforward tracks things on this album finally kind of pick up with I can see through you but the band finally goes for the throat on endless blue the guitars blare on that track I hear the bass the drums push a really nice beat as well everything is very defined very rigid and nothing is lost in all this murk the opening is really gentle too and I love the way these guys incorporate these horn arrangements that show up the track still life to me though is kind of this this perfect combination this perfect blend of horrors new and old selves in a way it kind of ends up having the aesthetic of what may happen if you two were forced to put some kind of spin on post-punk music really big-time and glamorous I mean that in the in the most complimentary way possible it's a pretty accessible Thun but it doesn't lose that that moody edge that horrors pull out of their pockets every once in a while the effects are here but they're not overbearing and the horns show up again and play the best arrangements they've got on the album one of my favorite tracks on this LP though is the longest moving further away with every release the horrors find out different ways to not only make their long tracks longer but also some of the most interesting moments on the album as good as primary colors is it would be a tragedy to see these guys make the same album over again I'm happy that they're experimenting happy they're doing something different but these really weak weak tips of the hat too psychedelic music on this album and and just effects are not not doing it for me they just kind of make these guys end up sounding bland on some of these tracks in my opinion I didn't love it but I did things skying was a pretty good record feeling a life 7 on this thing but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan oh the horrors skying forever

there's a new album from washdown hello Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd my needle drops and it's album review time washed out within and without to change this man come on here we go relevant to the topic at hand all right washed out is the solo electronic project of music producer Ernest green who in 2009 gathered a lot of attention a lot of buzz because he was writing maybe not by his choice the wave of popularity fueling this new genre known as chill wave but by now we all know that chill wave is not real the cake is a lie the blogosphere was was very young and reckless we we didn't know what we were doing I'm sorry so let's put that insanity behind us and take this album for what it really is an album of atmospheric and ethereal synth pop tunes that glisten like the Sun on the open ocean this thing has nine tracks spanning 40 minutes and it is a very blissful 40 minutes just take a look at the opening track eyes be closed that track in terms of sound and texture pretty much treads the same water that washed out was swimming through on the life of leisure EP but here the sounds are a little deeper a little brighter a little more expensive sounding the sounds are very lightly smudged with reverb so are the vocals which are not very intelligible because of that but you know in the reverbs defense the vocals aren't very intelligible even when they're not smothered in echo earnest doesn't really like to articulate his lyrics all that well and not that it's terrible but it kind of ends sounding like angelic moaning descending from heaven the production and the sounds are really kind of what make this LP shine make it worth visiting and that's what earnest Greene was doing best when this project started so in a way things really haven't changed all that much maybe they haven't changed enough to really kind of keep me excited about this album even though I was enjoying the previous efforts my only major issue with this album kind of comes down to the songwriting there are a lot of songs that just kind of rely on one single light feathery groove to kind of carry the weight of the entire track and washed-out just kind of lets the melodies and the chords and the song structures get swallowed and all this reverb murkiness and haze and while I do like echoes I do like atmosphere I like something behind that - kind of empowering it and while I do like grooves you know I love great beats I love great bass lines um I like my grooves a little harder than the brand of beats that have kind of been pulled together on this LP tracks like eyes be closed and echoes sound really really good but there's not much behind the sound to kind of keep me engaged and keep me interested it doesn't really seem like something for the foreground I guess maybe more of a soundtrack maybe a soundtrack to whatever they're doing on the cover looks fun not every song is completely underwhelming for me though things kind of brighten up on the next two songs soft and amor fati where these Caribbean and these Island sounds kind of come into play with these bongos and these very bright bouncy keyboards the songs themselves still aren't blowing me away but that track is just so juicy it is a watermelon it is a whole sleeve of starbursts it's a handful of strawberries but I think my favorite number on here is easily far away on that track the haze and the effects kind of take a backseat to concentrate on the song writing the song structure it's not all lost in the hay I hear a really deep sexy bassline backed with some huge drums and shakers and Ernests voice over all of it sounds pretty sensual here I love the twinkling melodies over this track and their string arrangements in it too and their perfectly crafted mixed and section 8 hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd a little stuffier than usual because my sinuses are acting up and it's time for an album review Kendrick Lamar section.80 Kendrick Lamar is a California emcee from the City of Compton a city that a lot of rappers like to represent and flash around to kind of show how tough they are and Compton does come up a lot in Kendricks case but only because his mindset is so against the mindset that usually gets tagged on the City section 80s Kendricks full-length debut he's done the tape thing he's done a lot of good feature spots this year he is getting bigger but I'm not going to say this guy's for everybody Kendricks voice is a little nasal and his inflection his delivery is little too underwhelming to be thrilling to me but he's not really going for one of these stoned or blunted personalities it's a problem I've had with his past stuff the enthusiasm is turned up a little bit more on section 80 it's not where I'd love for it to be but I still enjoy listening to this guy's music a lot and that's because he's really thought-provoking I love his flow I love his wordplay I love his his Rhymes his words what he is saying if there's one thing I cannot attack Kendrick on on any level that is substance he's always got that he's always got something substantial to say and until I looked up Kendricks age which i think is 23 I had a hard time placing his age he sounds really really young he has the hunger and the will to experiment that a young artist would have he's spitting out a lot of beats that older rappers might see as too soft too melodic or even to elect tronic like on no makeup or Tammy song or even the jazzed out spoken word track that is absol outro and from the sound of things I think he and a lot of the people who took the time to produce the instrumentals on this album were heavy into Kanye's last album overall it's just a really young album that feels wise beyond its years because considering some of the dark and abstract stuff that Kendrick raps about on this LP he's either much older than he says he is or he's put a lot more thought than your average 20-something has into just the world at large and existence I mean I kind of knew I was in for something different just from the first track alone your ethnicity which kind of starts off with this smokey deep voice narrator talking next to a campfire and he pops up throughout the album and that leads into a song that points out fighting over skin color religion ethnicity is pointless the mood kind of lightens up on the second track a little bit though hold up which in that song Kendrick kind of muses in his head about having sex with a stewardess on a plane and it's funny how he introduces himself and his personality in his worldview a little bit more even when he's just kind of joking around and in this song he actually spit it it's one of my favorite lines on the album which actually is wicked as a tea reverence in a pool of fire with devils holding hands from a distance don't know which one is a Christian damn on the song ADHD Kendrick kind of talks about drugs among other things kind of eroding the attention spans and values and and health of pretty much my generation and this theme comes up again and again and again on the album using drugs as a way to kind of - now and not in a really joyous or happy way Kendrick kind of seems unsure and uneasy about where his generation is headed rapping about how kind of reckless or directionless but Keisha's song to me is one of the most vivid and depressing on here one of the most notable stories on this album but I don't want to ruin all the storylines for you guys for the most part Kendricks flows on this album are just like the ones on those tracks really laid-back but there's kind of a lot to think about in what he says there points on this LP where he goes harder and that makes for a really you know kind of nice peak and I stand out like on the track Ronald Reagan era or rigor mortis where he's literally rapping so fast and for so long that his voice is getting higher because he's almost out of breath but I do want to talk about the beats a little bit more before I finish this off many of them are so good that even when a hook is weak I still love it I think the silliest hook on this entire help you easily spiteful chant and you know what the epic horns on that track the deep bass the hard drums just the atmosphere of the instrumental itself is just so good I can't hate the track I really love the soulful singing about screwed-up kids on Ronald Reagan era I like the synthesizers on this thing the organ sounds the bass sounds there are just so many jazzy samples throughout this LP that just reminds me of anything a Tribe Called Quest would have would have made a track out of and even though there are more electronic moments on here there are popular moments on here there are jazzier moments it all just comes together so well because Kendrick is delivering this really consistent personality and message over every song so none of it feels misplaced none of it really feels far-fetched most of the beats on this LP are credited to people who seem to be a part of this this producer collective digit phonics another producer on here credited as THC has a lot of beats on here as well and even Jay Cole has a credit on here as well pretty much on section 80 it's cut-and-dry for me I love the words I love the rhyming I love the messages the personality is great the instrumentals are fantastic better than you would expect on a project that is so kind of low-key I do have a few problems with some of the weak hooks on here I think like I said earlier Kendrick could be a little more enthusiastic on his stuff and and because he is as laid-back as he is some of his guest rappers overshadow him a little bit like bj the chicago kid an abs soul and it's not necessarily because they're technically more proficient than he is but you know he's just got that relaxed approach that isn't his ear grabbing as somebody who is more urgent I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this thing loved it for the most part have a lot of love for this album I like where this guy is going this help he lasted for an hour and it didn't bore me once he's obviously advanced past his previous efforts and I'm excited to see him do that more in the future what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana Kendrick Lamar section.80 forever you

oh sorry well well well well well well well hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's most metallic music nerd I know this album really isn't news to anyone but I feel like talking about it these guys have been rocking and reeling in Auckland New Zealand since about 2000 I hope someone gets that joke and this is the band's third LP and when it came out back in January earlier this year toward the end of that month and I first heard it I was not ready for it I was not ready for this I didn't assume this album to be bad but I was not in a mental state to kind of take on a behemoth a mammoth like this and get into its intricacies and really try to understand it for what it is you guys know from my previous reviews I love detail in my albums I love changes I love surprises and left hooks and when it comes to that this album loves to tango and not only that but it is loud it is dizzyingly technical it is heavy it is aggressive so kind of revisiting this LP to take in more of its details is kind of like returning for more punishment it's a death metal album maybe a technical death metal album not really a style I cover much on this channel but the thing is I honestly haven't loved much death metal since the genres heyday for me the Styles emphasis on being extreme has led to a lot of bitten bands and albums shooting for studio tricks that kind of end up making their music sound loud but a lot like plastic and other records try to be more brutal through technicality but end up kind of sounding like meaningless wanker II that does not resonate with me on any level even on musicianship thankfully this album is a welcome change of pace from both of those things even though destroyers of all sounds very very expensive the recording is so organic to me the way the drums and guitars bounce off of each other feels so natural and just kind of keeps me invested into every twist and turn this album makes and while it is really technical the virtuosity these guys display doesn't just get wasted on showing you how great they are individually but as a unit crafting these spiraling metal songs that are just so easy to get lost in now in comparison with ulcerates past two releases this album is a slightly easier pill to swallow but not by much it's still a very overbearing set of seven songs ulcery is turning up the atmosphere and turning down the tempo a little bit to the point where I could see even doom and sludge metal fans getting into this album I know the first three tracks of this LP can be really intense and if you're listening they'll throw a lot at you but if you manage to stick with destroyers of all into its second half it's really surprising to see how great these guys are writing slower songs as well the fourth track is a really brooding one that sounds basically like these guys are playing in an Avant metal jam and things get even heavier and Atmospheric on my favorite track of the cell pee omens where the drumming is just great it's just jumping from the left side to the right side all the Tom's all of the cymbals just sound like they're in different places it's so panoramic it's like hearing the drums dance around in this fog of distorted bass and guitar and it builds up to the more aggressive moments in that song really seamlessly - now the final track which is the title track justifies its 10-minute length and kind of crumbles the world that these guys just spend building with the previous 40 minutes of music a really cinematic ending to this album now if I were to name some some problems I am having with this LP I feel like maybe the vocals and and the guitar tones too could have changed up a little bit and would have aided with being able to separate these songs in my head plus some of these tracks are so Rubik's Cube ish like being puzzling is is one of the best traits and obviously as I listen to this album again and again and again that unpredictability kind of waned for me I guess my only other issue with destroyers of all is is just with how prominent the drums are and don't get me wrong Jami the drummer from this band is is quite possibly the backbone I mean ulcery would not be all sorry if the drums were not this detailed not this technical not this flashy but I think a little extra guitar volume would have brought the atmospheric element of this album kind of full circle plus I think the the bass kind of gets shafted on this album even though my finger isn't always on the pulse of the style of music I'm not stupid I know when I'm hearing something good the the tenants of creativity and interesting sounds still apply no matter what the genre and this LP definitely has a lot of that feeling a decent too strong seven on this album and if you are into metal music and this somehow slipped by you I recommend you go back and listen to it hmm Anthony Fantana ulcerate destroyers of all what do you think about this album and what should I review next forever you

herman do strange music hey everyone anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and yes I know the new horrors is out there on the internet and there are other hot and very requested albums of foot that you know I will review in the future but I just spent 20 minutes talking about little bee just give me the next couple days just kind of you know just just for a few whatever tickles my fancy you know besides let's not forget about the the point of this channel me turning you on to music music without further ado do Herman dune is a French duo which insists on continuing to sing and write its songs in English yay for no language barriers for my english speaking viewers and if i'm not mistaken this is the ninth studio LP to come out of this project strange music music I found out about Herman dune in 2008 with the album next year in Zion and even though I didn't love every song from that LP I just kind of found myself falling for the charms of the duo's lead singer david herman dune kind of has that boyish oddball delivery of jonathan richman but still kind of retains the detailed and meticulous storytelling of silver jews and even though the music on this record isn't terribly original with every track trying to kind of toy with a different influence from country to rock and roll to reggae I just find David's voice so emotive and friendly and approachable and he just finds songwriting inspiration in the strangest places even like a traffic jam of course he finds inspiration and more conventional topics to like loving and done and weird conversations and drugs but he always manages to kind of put a strange quirk on all these things and make me feel like I'm I'm hearing about all of them for the first time even though I've heard about this stuff before I'll give him a chance singing about any of it and partially my attraction to this album is the personality I mentioned earlier but it's also kind of the way David sings with this really thin shaky vocal that kind of sounds like it's trying to put a brave face on in the midst of covering up some kind of emotional pain and I know it's a funny thing to like but I kind of like the way this guy pronounces his words his French accent isn't really thick or anything like that but you can tell that the fact that English isn't his native tongue changes which syllables he's emphasizing and how he says though what do you mean like how does he say to sang rang like how does he pronounced the words in the same I hate god you're just I'm not in love with this album and that basically kind of comes down to the songs themselves it's not a bumpy ride it's not the most memorable ride in the world but it's a smooth one the thing is albums that have kind of this boyish charm aspect to them can wear thin for me a little bit and there are a few tracks on here where I think this album kind of dips a little too far into that trough relying on that to make the songs interesting for me the song the rock is kind of like that and the song be a doll and take my heart is like that as well but what kind of makes that track even worse specifically is that David as much as I like his voice he pulls out his worst singing on the entire album on that song he's so off pitch and maybe just not as a motive as i would have liked him to be and it's not a hard song not a complicated song I think it just might have been able to get fixed with a second take or something they're definitely more highlights on this LP then there are potholes I love the opening track that kind of paints a crazy character of him and this woman that he's in love with a girl who jumps out of windows while he's kind of a guy who refuses to go down to the record store because he's frustrated with how like the band's of today sound like the band's of yesterday i love how breezy and just easygoing tracks like lay your head on my chest and your love is gold are but easily my favorite track on this album is the shortest and it's not because it's short but my joy easily has some of the best lyrics on this entire LP talking about kind of nearing death in a way I think and how I interpreted it was kind of like enjoying life up until that point even talking about dancing like Christopher Walken for me this is a pretty sturdy summer album it's not bad kind of a thing I would put on if I were skipping out on work to cuddle with someone I love all day it's that kind of album feeling a strong six or a light seven on this let me know what you think of this LP do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantan Oh Herman doon strange music first you

Sam Baker album sam-i-am hello my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh you're the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's album review time this lp's title is sam baker's album it's the sophomore release from la beat meister Sam I am the follow-up to a CDR album rap beats vol 1 on brain feeder records and brain feeder if you haven't heard of it yet is a record label started by Flying Lotus Los Angeles Flying Lotus Kozma grandma Flying Lotus the Adult Swim bumps Flying Lotus and Flying Lotus and sam-i-am have collaborated together under the name fly am Sam and they might be coming out with an album later this year collaborative album precious cargo but honestly I'm not sure if I'm gonna be looking forward to that album I'm actually not sure if I'm gonna be looking forward to to anything brain feeder puts out in the future from from here on out but the thing is when brain feeder first came out I was really thrilled I was really excited one of my favorite musicians was going to be releasing music from what I assumed were gonna be like-minded artists who I didn't know about shed some light on some people who would push beat music to new heights of creativity and sound nearly everything that's come out on this label so far has kind of underwhelmed me a few artists have come really close to WoW me and I'm keeping an ear on them of course like Gaslamp Killer and mono/poly whose new EP was pretty awesome but so far the albums that have been put out on brain feeder have kind of fallen into two categories for me and that is they're either so odd and formless that I can't really attach anything to them emotionally or they're so straightforward plain and simple that they're just kind of in one ear and out the other they're just not memorable to me and sadly for me sam baker's album falls into that category there are 17 instrumentals on here but a vast majority of them are just kind of non descript to me no matter how many times I listen to this I can't retain much of it but it's not for lack of good production though the drums are really heavy the beats are pronounced the bass lines are very husky very chubby and thick what samples I do here are chopped up pretty well the highs are nice and the entire package is mixed so clearly it's a little saturated but it sounds fine and this thing is definitely not a one-trick pony in terms of different sounds and styles I love the sweet parliament-funkadelic influence coming out of those synthesizers on frosting packets I love those schmaltzy electric piano chords on the song turtles or that rattling percussion on understanding its how these songs are built just assembled that that kind of ends up boring me pretty much all these tracks move past a short introduction and then they run in circles for a little bit with one idea and then they just end up with a predictable fade-out each of these tracks sound best when they've reached their peak which isn't even really that high it's kind of more like a hill and maybe that's because of a lack of development or something so many tracks here just instead of evolving instead of changing instead of adapting they kind of peace out and even when a track on here sounds pretty nice that leaves me with a really kind of empty Hollow unsatisfied feeling I kind of feel like I grab ten bucks and instead of going to get some dinner or something I went down to my local drugstore and bought one of those you know $10 boxes of chocolates you know various assortment and then I just picked out on that and then of course afterwards I felt tired and crappy and unfulfilled I mean this album does have a consistent mood and style though maybe it would appeal more to beat producers and people who are looking for some thing to mmm kind of soundtrack there day maybe so I will say if you were into that Teebs album that came out on brain feeder and maybe you're looking for something that is slightly slightly more upbeat alive then I think you should try to get with this if you're an electronic music enthusiast a hip-hop instrumental enthusiast who's looking for a set of gentle giants because these tracks while they are subdued they're very heavy they've
