should bathhouses black up hey I hope everyone is doing well doing good Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd it's time for an album review Shabazz Palaces black up as far as I can tell Shabazz Palaces is a hip hop project led by Pallas ear Lazaro but that's not his real name he's actually Ishmael Butler who used to be in the 90s hip-hop outfit digital planets but you don't need to hear that stuff to enjoy this palace ear also brings on some collaborators for this LP but as far as I can tell they are anonymous or working under pseudonyms that I saw listed out on a sub pop Records website if anything you should try to check out the to self releases that Shabazz put out before this new LP black up and how to attack this because there are so many things to say about it let's start with the beats and the production because it's such a vital part to this album I would say more so than a lot of hip-hop albums and I say that because there are so many points where the textures and the effects and the samples and the beats basically take over and maybe drown out the lyricism a little bit and kind of make it play second fiddle but I love the way this thing sounds it's it's really something else if you don't have this LP on a big-ass stereo you're really only hearing half the story because some of the drums some of the low-end some of the kicks on this are really really nice not a lot of release on the drums they're very lean they're very kind of sharp guts but very hard clicky clicky the low-end Rumble shake the ground the the highs are nice and crisp and an atmospheric the samples are cut really well the effects are executed with finesse and this thing is mixed like a monster unless a track is going for a very cacophonous wall of sound it's very clear it's very well balanced some of the beats here are just a really nice straightforward enjoyable no-brainer like were you can you are you felt are you can you where you felt just a really nice droning string sample stuttering jazz piano chords a boom click beat a very chill laid-back flow the whole package of it all kind of puts me in a place that may be listening to Quasimodo or some other Madlib related album would but straight-and-narrow is not the game this LP plays most of the time a lot of these beats are out there you gotta trust me on this one each track has like a plethora of different sounds that I could go into very great detail with like the opener free press and curl very eerie bass hums on that track just sputtering cymbal hits flying all over both mix channels there are a lot of effects being used on Pallas ears voice as the as the song evolves and there are these vocal samples that are literally manipulated mauled I would say to the point where they kind of sound like a steam train whistle blowing it's weird another one of my favorite beats is the second track and it does this trick it does this little turn of the hand that I hear on a lot of these tracks that I haven't heard done quite like this before there's a female vocal sample on there and it is stretched out just aggressively because it's stretched and it's not pitch shifted there's all these like digital stretch marks on edges it's a noisy sound that maybe another producer would do his or her best to try to eliminate or cover up but this LP he just puts it out in the open and it's got a pretty surreal quality their tracks on here loaded with various synthesizers bleeps and bloops like a treaty dedicated and eulogy which that songs first half is basically a cacophonous wall of various sounds and noises but there are tracks here I like a lot that come off very sparse very empty luckily palace e'er has enough charisma to me to fill an entire stadium which is really what locks me in with a lot of these tracks I love the Rhymes I love this flow I just love the personality I love the delivery but I know it's not going to be for everybody if you're a boom bap traditionalist who enjoys a lot of fiery flows a lot of technical ability then this is definitely not going to be for you though there are some very strong statements made in the lyrics on this LP it doesn't really go hard while many rappers are kind of in this bragging competition this LP is more content kind of sitting in the stands and meditating and making fun of albums that fall prey to clichés like materialism and violence and swag that Death Grips album I loved earlier this year made that stuff look stupid and ugly by taking it to such an extreme that it couldn't be rationalized by anybody to be good this album does the same thing but it does it in a way that's toned down kind of in a in a studious way like it would say these rhymes after closing a book and looking over from its tipped glasses this thing is just kind of like a socially conscious full course meal about freedom and racism society at large the Internet age hip hop making music attracting girls and of course there's a bunch of abstract stuff on the menu too like actually one of my favorite verses the Knights are getting stronger and the days are getting longer the building is getting bigger outside is getting smaller the lives are getting truer and the truth is getting brighter things are looking blacker but black is looking whiter what weird but I love it the only thing I'm really kind of mixed on on the fence with is how these songs are put together we have ten tracks here but there are some songs that could easily be two because they hit a transitional moment where the track becomes something completely different it's not really an evolution as much as it is like an immediate shape shift of mood and that's fine it actually makes this LP kind of a thrill to listen to because it unfolds it surprises but there are some songs here that don't have enough track length to fully develop the shifts that they make the track endeavors to me comes off a little aimless its various parts don't connect as much as they kind of clash and the Kings new clothes just kind of ends and fizzles out for no reason just as the song sort of seems to be gaining momentum emotion and a message but outside of that I'm loving this thing it's a great reminder of how mind-altering and up hip-hop music can be but still sound great while being those things so I'm kind of feeling a decent eight on this a decent eight but let me know what you're thinking of this are you loving it are you hitting it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Shabazz Palaces black up forever [Music] [Music]

it's track reviews it is so humid I hate it it's humid I hate it hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for track reviews where we talk about the latest and greatest and rock pop electronic experimental music of the in der major label everything persuasion but I had to jump on this opportunity this is the first time I'll be reviewing a song a piece of music anything from Bjork an Icelandic singer songwriter who's been making music for a minute and she has a forthcoming LP which this new song comes off of Biophilia and from what I understand this will be her seventh studio LP and this track has been getting a little bit of buzz because before the studio version came out there was a 30-second clip of Bjork in a van playing the song on a stereo and then we were listening via crappy camera microphone but since the studio version has come out other information has come out along with it - like this album is supposed to have a music video accompanying each song and not only that but this is supposed to be like an iPad album with each individual song kind of being its own app and all of the songs coming together into the biophilia app which is kind of like a mommy app for all the songs and I've been hearing that the apps are supposed to maybe allow people to recreate the songs on this album it's really involved and confusing when this album comes out am I going to be able to review it number one I don't have an iPad and number two I'm really more of a music slash album reviewer I wonder if I'll really have anything to say about the visual aspects of this LP or if I just simply review the music is that may be kind of pointless or maybe against the purpose of the album since maybe it should be enjoyed with its visuals much like a soundtrack as much as I appreciate the growing ambition that comes with each new Bjork album I kind of wonder if what's going on here this project is gonna kind of end up like those enhanced CDs that labels used to put out in like 1999 and 2000 and 2001 will we still be using iPads 10 years from now I don't know all I really care about is whether or not I will be wanting to listen to this song 10 years from now so let's give a listen to it Bjork crystalline there's a link below this video on YouTube where you can listen to it let's go all right let's start with the sounds on this track for the most part I enjoyed the sounds quite a bit I liked the chimes that were constant throughout the song for the most part I liked the beats how I guess shy they were at the beginning of the song and then how as the song progressed they just put more force into what was happening the percussion is kind of glitchy I liked that a lot and Bjork's voice dynamic as usual just twisting and turning in various directions creating odd melodies swelling falling changing with the song or maybe it just kind of seems like it should be the thing is I do have an issue I do have a big problem with this track and it's that there are a couple parts in this song where the beat kind of just falls out of the picture in Bjork's voice and the instrumentation kind of takes over for a moment and then the beat kind of enters the picture again like I said this happens a couple times and even though this is a change a change has occurred I still kind of feel like I'm listening to the same thing over and over and over and over for four minutes and that's kind of weird I can't really recall a song that made me feel that way where I was listening and even though there was some kind of noticeable change going on I kind of felt like I was still listening to the same thing maybe not enough progression or not the progression I was looking for the beat falls in the beat falls out the beat falls in the beat falls out when it comes back in it's not all that altered and the thing is the melody of the track and Bjork's vocal inflection to me hasn't changed all that much either to make me feel like oh the first minute of the track is definitely in a different place in the third minute of the track at the very end of this song there is a change it gets loud very loud and even though it's nice to have kind of a climax at the end of this thing I'm not sure it was the kind of climax I was really looking for I guess all these breakbeats unexpected break beats just kind of flew in and took over and created an all-out sonic assault the song just basically ends with 42 seconds of these hard loud breaks and the way they're executed the way they're put together I can't really say much about them honestly I mean they're that kind of faceless it kind of sounded like some internet DJ who is just starting out likes to upload remixes on to the internet remix to Bjork song and then put it up on YouTube and after that part the song just kind of stops I'm just kind of lost on this track it doesn't have all those things that I usually look for and enjoy in Bjork's music like growth than just that incomparable passion and emotion that she displays in her voice and her instrumentation and songwriting but that's just my opinion let me know what you think I would like to maybe hear some positive views on this track down there in the comments maybe be swayed on this and become a little more excited about this forthcoming LP because I mean honestly I haven't really been in love in love with anything Bjork has done since like Vespertine so I'm kind of feeling a strong five to a light six on this track some very likeable things and it's not a terrible song but I'm definitely not going to be returning to this anytime soon outside of the context of of this new LP which I hope I get a chance to listen to all the way through and maybe enjoy in the multimedia context and see if it makes a difference experiencing this on an iPad as an app Anthony Fantana Bjork crystalline forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd time for an album review this request has been hanging over my head a little bit and still manages to get a ton of comments tweets Facebook messages death threats so I I figured I should do it because believe it or not I do read the comments plus maybe if you don't know this New York duo you'll you'll like them this LP comes on the heels of a little 7 inch EP that came out in 2010 some tracks off of that got passed around the blogosphere a lot very popular I even mentioned it on my favorite EPS of 2010 lists so now I've got 11 tracks in 33 minutes from these guys and I could be wrong but I think outside of the genre of children's music this is probably the sunniest album of 2011 there are a lot of things that I could talk about with this LP in terms of its style like how it tries to go for an old-school pop sound with that wall of sound technique and that high gloss finish and lots of cute and sentimental songs about friends enemies and lovers there are a lot of very very influenced melodies and chord progressions all over this thing tons of reverb pretty solid guitar tone a little piano here and there maybe some organ and this thing this plinky plinky thing which is either a little baby metal xylophone or a fisher-price piano which is just mimicking whatever the vocal melody is and hanging underneath it chirping along for what I think is every song and there are some modern beats on here like on oh my god which sounds like it could have been behind a hip hop song and there are some tried-and-true ones on here - like Most Wanted which I could see backing up a 60s girl group and there's some standout songwriting moments on the thing to like go outside and oh my god where the songs feel fleshed out they just don't fade out after a verse and a chorus and the melody feels pretty original it's memorable and it's catchy and not because it's rehashed outside of those tracks I don't really think this band's songwriting sets them apart from other groups I mean for the most part it all just feels so familiar to me its cults very bright attitude that I mentioned earlier just that sunny sunny wave of feelings that come at me when I put this album on that sets them apart from other groups the savage track on this LP might be the song you know what I mean and even on that track I just hear nothing but but blue skies and flower fields I know I've enjoyed sugary albums before this year but with cults my teeth are just falling out and it's not really just the mood of this album it's one thing piled on top of another thing piled on top of another thing for me the really cutesy instrumentation adds to how fast this LP wears thin for me and also Madeline fallens vocals which are very light and fine to begin with but how her voice is mixed and produced on some of these tracks it's like they're made to be light and fine to the max it's like they're made to be so loud and thin and echoey that when I hear her sing on some of these tracks it's like shoving a hot branding iron in my ear canal I'm really having a hard time enjoying how light young these vocals feel how cute everything is how summery the album is how happy the mood is how simple simple simple the instrumentation is and how it just kind of goes back and minds from the past in a kind of kitschy way I feel like a terrible person when I do a review like this if I'm going to hell it'll be reviews like this that send me there but a lot of songs on this LP just remind me of like what would happen if kids bop decided to do an album of Phil Spector covers young young young I keep saying that word but that's what this album feels like to me it feels so young and it doesn't feel like a teenage album like like this May it feels like this album is is yet to break into the double digits and maybe that's what well why do you guys like about it but it's it's what's keeping me away from it maybe if the songs felt a little more original maybe if the instruments were a little more interesting to me maybe if I didn't find the vocals so harsh at some points on this LP I could be swayed I could be swayed but at this point this is just not for me I'm feeling like a strong three to a light four on this thing but what do you guys think of this new cults LP are you loving it are you hating it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana cults cults forever you

hi my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's double music nerd and it's time for an album review the new subtract LP self-titled this guy is an anonymous london-based music producer whose material I could say is electronic soul all the sounds and the atmosphere surrounding this album are so clean so sanitized there's not a speck of dirt on this LP and normally that would bug me you guys know how much I like listening to something grimy every once in a while but the spotless electronic sounds on this LP are levelled out with Sam fuzz voice it's not the most powerful vocal on the planet but it is a very emotive one and that's what I like about it so much though it may be kind of corny to sing about for example on one track somebody not calling you back somebody you're into I still kind of get wrapped up in the drama I kinda feel for the guy it just goes to show that delivery is everything and I kind of dig his range too he's got a nice warm voice and he hits some highs too and when he does I can't tell if he's like straining his voice a little bit or if he's about to break out crying so while Santa's voice is kind of overheating with emotion on a lot of these tracks the electronics behind him sometimes wrapping around him like a straightjacket are very calm cool and collected sometimes the beats here are very simple and light and lean like on the track right thing to do but then again on the opposite side of the spectrum we have songs that are very lush very thick very layered and what I like is no matter what side of the spectrum these tracks are on they always work toward empowering the emotion that subtractors trying to convey in a song like on hold on where the bleak and very sparse music plays into the loneliness and the lyrics and never never where the confusing pain of like losing everything is projected on to me while I'm listening to it with how much this song builds how it escalates how it just throws so many different sounds and ideas at me at once there are several female features he brings on to the album and my favorite of them is actually you key me from a little dragon she's on the song wildfire and her vocals just have so much personality she was a great addition for this album and I love what subtract does with her voice on this song he throws all sorts of effects on her voice and progressively changes them as the song moves along and they're never too overbearing or distracting I'm always listening to her singing the other two vocal features Jessie we're on right thing to do and roses Gabor on on Pharos I'm pretty on the fence with them their voices just don't feel all that distinct or we're interesting to me they just kind of get the job done I kind of feel like I could have heard these vocal takes like like anywhere but the thing is the beats underneath their voices are so good I don't really mind it the song isn't completely ruined for me the intro and outro tracks are are all right they're not highlights for me but they're good and pretty much everything outside of those moments is is stellar for me now I've held off on saying this until now but I guess you could you could say this is a a dubstep album I know that's a kind of a dirty word for some people that either hate dubstep or hey seing things labeled as dubstep to me this album actually sounds like a dream collaboration between James Blake and Flying Lotus some of the sounds some of the really cacophonous layers on this LP remind me of tracks from flying lotuses latest EP except that had a very clean James Blake production style to them plus Sam FFA's voice kind of sounds like James Blake's maybe he's a little less depressing but he's still kind of a dead ringer having said that I love this album it's nice to hear a debut this solid I'm happy to hear another electronic album I love at the halfway point of the year I know I haven't been going crazy over a lot of electronic LPS this year I've been listening I've been looking but I haven't been binding but I'm happy that now I have found I'm feeling like a light too decent eight on this thing it's good I really enjoyed it links below this video and on the needle drop comm where you can hear some of it hmm but what do you think of this do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana subtract forever

I say new Brigade oh hi everybody Anthony Fantana the Internet's busiest music nerd I'm filming this review late it's 4 a.m. it's for 12 a.m. in the morning and let me tell you this is exactly what I needed to listen to it for 12 in the morning these guys are a Denmark band their name is ice age this is their debut full-length new Brigade it just got released on a u.s. record label what we've got here is a 24 minute post-punk record that sounds more English than it does Danish these guys are noisy and abrasive like the Jesus and Mary Chain not in a not in a shoegaze kind of way but you know what I'm saying and also there's this cocky swagger to them that reminds me of Gang of Four or wire but those aren't the best possible comparisons you could make if you want to get more accurate stylistically these guys are much more of a annoys rock band maybe even a no wave band because I definitely pick up sounds that I would like into groups like DNA there are a lot of influences crashing into each other at high velocity creating this mangled orgy of metal and shattered glass hmm but still new Brigade comes together with a really cohesive sound surprisingly this thing could have jumped all over the place and it does a little bit but for the most part these guys have a style and they stick to it and they manipulate it in a bunch of different ways throughout this LP the sound is what really say is the most consistent the vocals are loud they're apathetic they feel kind of slurred but they're also kind of wild too and they have this echo um that just makes them bounce all over the mix and the bass is very warm very fuzzy and on the opposite side of the spectrum you've got the guitar which is so trebled it's so brittle every pick stroke sounds like metal rubbing against metal and the trums come in loud and clear - everything is just mixed so evenly I like that it's so loud and noisy and harsh and flailing in every direction possible but I can make out what I'm hearing loud and clear now the harshness that I mentioned about this album what I like about it is that it doesn't come from a lot a lot of effects and stuff like that mostly it's kind of coming from how these guys play they play so so raw but there is some sweetness there to kind of mat match up with the sour the songs for the most part are very catchy very rhythmic very angular very memorable in a way it actually reminds me of that women album that I loved last year there's a lot of weirdness to it it's very kind of an alienating album it's not a very accessible album but yet there's something almost unexplainable about it that is so attractive as far as bright spots go the hook on remember is almost uplifting to me feels almost positive and same goes for a broken bone maybe even the last track on this LP - but for the most part this record is is dark it is a dark album it's like a really really really cloudy day after two or three straight months of nothing but cloudy days it just kind of you know begins to itch at your sanity a little bit some tracks here just feel so tense and and feel so Jerry the track white rune just has such ugly guitars these pounding just migraine inducing drums also the title track the band is just like bursting at the scene total dredge just speeds up in spins and spins it's kind of like what falling down a spiral staircase must be like and the song never returned finds this really weird groove with these rolling and these guitars that sound like Picasso painted them and one of my favorites on here and it's actually one of the shortest count me in is kind of like this this weird combination of thrash punk and shoegaze it's executed amazingly this album for me is something that I just wanna I want to put on I want to turn it up as loud as possible and just sit back and watch something burn and not like a campfire or anything like that more like a building or a forest and I know that sounds terrible but this is a terrible album it's the feel terrible hit of the summer hmm I'm feeling a strong 8 to a light 9 on this album for me it was really thrilling invigorating noisy overwhelming and something I will be returning to Anthony Fantana ice age new Brigade forever [Music] you

Bon Iver hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Bone Iver or Justin Vernon is a Wisconsin singer-songwriter who after many collaborations in ep some feature spots and side projects has just dropped his highly anticipated sophomore LP and whether you like the guy or not the amount of musical connections he's made the amount of attention he's received is extremely surprising considering how little music he's actually released because the only other full-length we really have to refer back to his bony bear's debut for Emma Forever Ago an LP you could label as a singer-songwriter album an indie folk album or something like that but the level of desolation and pain on this LP is unmatched by most guys who try to pick up an acoustic guitar and sing a sad song but anyway the vocals and a lot of the emotions that made for Emma such a powerful release remain intact on this new LP but the most noticeable shift between the first LP and this one even blood-bank in this one is that there is a lot more instrumentation to account for on this which is something that Bon Iver might not have been able to pull off if a sophomore album came just a year after for Emma French horn trumpet different saxophones clarinet flute string arrangements piano synthesizers drums various effects - it's definitely a step up from the sparse percussion and the guitar and vocal layering that was happening on the first LP but the thing is for me these new sounds these new instruments these new textures are executed throughout this album with just kind of mixed results take two of my feet tracks on here Holocene and towers to guitar-driven tracks and not just strong and very memorable songs very emotive songs but the arrangements on these tracks surround them in a way where it complements the song it empowers the song you don't lose sight of the direction of the song because that is top priority on Holocene a shaker and some handclaps just push the song along as these tones just swell underneath the song and later these marching snares and and horns just start boiling underneath the track and get louder and louder and by the end of it it is this it is this emotional unstoppable powerhouse that to me is what Bon Iver is all about the picture has just gotten bigger because of these extra instruments and I think the instrumentation arranged around the track wash Washington is done really well to the piano the very somber piano on that one sounds like an old stone house meanwhile the strings and the vocals just kind of wrapping around our like decades or maybe even centuries of ivy growing on it just sounds so pretty it's like a place I want to live if every song here was is focused or is well arranged as those three tracks I would be in heaven but for me that's not really the case there are a lot of tracks here that feel like they've been produced or arranged messily songs where it just kind of feels like instruments come in and start making noise just to to make noise or even spots where I question whether or not the guitar the percussion or even the vocals have been eq'd like the second track Minnesota Wisconsin I love the first half of that song such warm voices such a such a beautiful and memorable melody but as soon as the falsetto vocals and the banjo finger-picking come in the instrumentation kind of loses track of itself the finger picking just continues on as the music changes these muddy drums just start pounding there are these distorted bass farts it's like three things that have nothing do with each other Misha Kant is a track where I enjoyed the song I enjoy the vocals the horns were a nice touch but I wonder if a single percussive sound on that whole track was eacute or even mixed in um Texas is another weird track for me it doesn't really feel like a song it just kind of feels like a spot of filler that exists merely to prove that there are sounds on this album that were not on the last album I've already reviewed the song Calgary in a previous video and I don't really feel any different on that song now than I did then and I don't really have any burning desire to return to it even after we're visiting it here I'm still left wondering why do the manipulated guitars squawking over this track feel so aimless like they're just there to be there why does the explosion toward the end of the track feel so flattened one-dimensional the last section of this LP has led to a bit of controversy mostly because of the instruments inside of it there's a pedal steel two different kinds of synthesizers I think some saxophone Dueling auto-tune vocals some Casio drum hits it's basically kind of like a corny instrument parade and I'm not going to get down on this album for trying to evoke a different musical time period if I came in here and said ooh this sounds a tease why I mean I would be a complete hypocrite because I did love that destroy your album earlier this year it's cool that Justin Vernon can just go BAM and do something that people don't expect of him but my issue with that track is that it feels just as claustrophobic as a lot of the other songs here to try to pour a lot of instrumentation into the mix not only that but the guitars and saxophones just kind of pop into the song whenever they feel like they're not getting enough attention when it comes to bringing a broad spectrum of instruments into a loaf i recording style which I think has been done here I've heard things that come off more creative to me over this I would rather listen to any number of Mount Erie or microphones albums I'm not saying you have to like one or the but here the sounds are so tinny they're so muddy the instruments a lot of the time distract from the song more than they add to the song or sometimes there's just not a song at all the track kind of exists to just show off the new digs so yeah I was kind of underwhelmed by this record admittedly I'm feeling a light too decent six on this shocker but what do you think of this album are you loving it are you hating it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana Bon Iver Bon Iver bunny bear [Music]

hello there I'm bad I am evil nice to meet you hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's EP review time bad meets evil help the sequel bad meets evil is a rap duo featuring Eminem and Royce to 5/9 and yeah I know Eminem mainstream why are you reviewing this but to be completely honest even though I'm not a big fan of him now Eminem was one of those artists for me who helped cultivate a love for hip-hop music in here along with some others but I mean come on it's not like I was the only kid in middle school who thought my name is was one of the coolest songs ever but I haven't really enjoyed anything Eminem has done since the Marshall Mathers LP and there are some songs on those older albums that even today when I returned to them I cringe a little bit inside but it depends on the track because a lot of Eminem songs for me have not lost their luster over the years which brings me to the 19th song off the Slim Shady LP bad meets evil featuring Royce to 5/9 both of these guys are Detroit emcees their history goes way back but for some reason their power is a duo sort of fizzled out because of a falling out so now it's years later after em and Royce guested on one another's albums and we have something very sizable from bad meets evil a 9 track EP and the result is em and Royce bringing the best out of one another on most of these tracks there's a huge sense of competition on here they really keep each other focused on these songs I'm just putting together hard fast and dizzying verses on some of these tracks the flows get faster and more intense as em and Royce or trading verses over the beat and not only is there like kind of a competent going on to see who can put together the better verse or just be a better rapper but there's also kind of a competition here this is bad meets evil to see who is more bad who is more evil who is more reckless with rhymes about smacking cops and crushing pills and crashing cars but there are a few songs here where the competition thing kind of dies down and Emin Royce concentrate more on being a tag-team and putting a story together like on the reunion where they kind of create these two personalities that are complete jerks complete misogynists and they end up meeting at the end and being one another's evil twin and the thing I like about that track is that it's not supposed to be serious it's supposed to be funny but I actually find it funny having Royce to 5/9 around keeps mm from getting so goofy that I can't handle it or I don't want to deal with it he keeps him from getting too overly emotional - and too bogged down in his own personal BS because of that it feels kind of in the moment it feels fast it feels quick it feels rushed and even though that gives this album a kind of freshness to it just a live feeling other elements of this EP suffer because of that - I think a good chunk of the beats and hooks here or either pretty bad or just really generic like life to a fast car ride it doesn't really add to the unique dynamic that these guys have and it gets worse on a track like above the law where the chorus is singing about the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer I mean it has nothing to do with what em and Royce are saying but the biggest pothole for me here is his lighters with Bruno Mars on the hook doing his Bruno Mars thing with sentimental pianos and Emin Royce rapping about their kind of love-hate relationship with Fame and I'm like you just spin and the entire EP convincing me that you guys are the biggest jerks on the 30k yes 30k dance 30k dance 30k dance 30k dance take it to cow 30k dance 30k dance 30k dance 30k dance which is I my because I'm so 30 K yo basedgod what should we do you should add a few or something hey review something I like it I like it blood ceremony is a Canadian rock band and this is their latest LP living with the ancients their sophomore album in fact and this brings me back to earlier this year when I was loving the album opus eponymous by the band ghosts Swedish metal band and though they don't play the same style of metal that blood ceremony does both of them do bring a very occult vibe into their metal and blood ceremony brings that vibe in a way that embraces the old-school sounds of doom metal not the sleep electric wizard I'm gonna hit the bong kind of doom metal the Black Sabbath style of doom metal just these heavy dark guitar riffs that that scream Tony Iommi very brooding and very bluesy too I will say some of the guitar riffs here do feel a little familiar I guess like they could have been on a lot of different records from way back when I'm not saying these guys are forging a new sound but this LP is not just some kind of Sabbath revival it's not as simple as that the band's lead singer Ellie O'Brien plays both organ and flute and believe me when I say she does not hesitate to break the flute out for a good chunk of these tracks I'm talking some serious flute rock here and when you're talking flute rock you got a talked all jethro tull who tony iommi actually played with for a little bit but he didn't stay with them he was still in earth who would eventually become Black Sabbath so because of that living with the ancients is kind of like this fantasy rock collaboration that never actually happened I could really tell from the way she's playing the flute on these tracks that she's listened to Ian Anderson she listens to Tull and oh she's so fiery when she plays on some of these tracks I especially loved her playing on the last track daughter of the Sun where the band brings the music to justice this perfect an overwhelming climax close out the album they just go so hard sinister melodies everywhere organ and guitar mmm I mean the track literally sounds like Pandora's Box has opened and demons and ghosts are flying out in every direction and who you gonna call nobody cuz Ghostbusters wasn't real it was a movie Bill Murray can't save you now but there are some moments here where the flute oriented tracks take it down a notch and don't Rock so much as play something that is a little bit more fit for the Renaissance Fair I know that sounds dorky but I like it tracks like the Hermit or the witches dance they totally have a folky medieval vibe to them the only other things I can really speak positively on with this album are the interplay between these guys and the songwriting I mean when this band rocks they rock some of the instrumental moments here where they're playing off of each other are just so energizing to me and the solos the improvising that I sense is going on in this album I like that these guys are playing you know an older style of metal music an older style of rock but they've also brought back that strong strong playing and musicianship that usually comes hand-in-hand with this kind of stuff the only issue I have with this LP and it's one that I can't completely ignore it's with the vocals the lead vocals I like the idea of having a female singing for this band I wouldn't like a male it's perfect with a female all these lyrics about witches and the occult it's better with a female and there are moments on night of Audrey where they've multi-tracked O'Brien's voice and just these vocals together layered on top of each other just reaching for as high as they can go and I'm just seduced I'm sold I'm into it I'm bowing down I'm joining the cult but on other moments like the Great God pan or Coventry I don't know about you but to me she's kind of like dragging her notes out a little bit longer than she she's audibly kind of strained for me and she's just forcing herself to put on this vibrato that takes away more than it adds is the vibrato there to sound dark is it there to sound dramatic I don't know it just kind of sounds like the way a lady who fronts some kind of local bar band would sing that did lets Appling covers every weekend but the thing is I love so many things about this album the recording the songwriting the musicianship the instrumentation that for the most part I can just sit there and take it and enjoy everything else that blood ceremony has to offer and it's funny because a vocal I don't like would usually ruin an album for me completely but I think this is a very solid LP I enjoyed it cohesive sound a nice bit of revivalism that sounds like a bunch of things but not one single thing kind of like the record that should have been so I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this one links below on youtube and also on the needle drop comm where you can hear a little bit of this album definitely recommend that you listen to this if you're into metal old-school metal the dark stuff or if you were into that ghost album I loved what do you think of this love it hate it why and what should I review next 30k forever

poor poor Lily hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review in yesterday's video you may have noticed I swapped a few album covers around I'll try not to make such mistakes in the future but what you may have also noticed is that yesterday I reviewed a punk album that I didn't really care for all too much but today I would love to introduce you to a punk album that I care for quite a bit poor Lilly's self-titled LP poor lily is a punk trio from the Bronx these three guys have varying levels of experience with punk music the guy with the longest rap sheet in the group is Max Capshaw who has drummed in such bands as Murphy's Law h2o sick of it all a lot of New York punk and hardcore groups but despite his experience as a drummer he for the most part plays guitar in this band the band's drummer actually has some roots in the New York hardcore scene as well and the youngest member of the group is the singer basis the youngest at 26 years old so even though two-thirds of this band of held down regular jobs and raised families they still musically sound like 19 year olds who like screaming moshing shoplifting and going to the record store every Saturday so the energy here is just very very young but the style of music of course is is not these guys cherry pick in my opinion from a lot of my favorite punk and post-punk groups throughout the 70s and 80s their spots where just New York punk and thrash crossover stuff bleed into the guitars a little bit there's some very minor threat esque narrations on the track in gravitas very tough and so time's the satire laced into this music can be as strong as the dead milkmen or even the dead kennedys the opening track just reminds me of mission of burma a lot sometimes these vocals just hit a very Roger Miller esque cord and I think minutemen fans will love just how eccentric jagged and angular this music is to it just jerks around in a really awkward and weird way there are 13 tracks here it's kept down to a very lean 23 minutes it's downloadable for free on the band's website and i got to say my favorite thing about this LP is the is the personality it's not the weirdest thing on the block but it flies a really honest freak flag like the song decide to sleep which is literally about becoming a maniac over a lack of sleep which I can relate to but my favorite is easily regular guy which is a series of mad internal ravings from someone who might just be your next-door neighbor like I hate doctors and I don't vote and I performed my own surgery with other lyrics about needles and sex and machine guns and people who kind of make you think what a shithead there there is not a dull moment on this album vocally or lyrically another thing on this album that is completely free of dull moments for me it's just how these guys put their songs together some tracks here don't even repeat themselves have like an a B C structure and then ends and even the longer tracks here where there are verses and choruses going back and forth like 800 jerks or in gravitas veritas there's a huge angry aggressive build up at the end of the track maybe a gang vocal or two or something it's like this punk as hell volcanoes just erupting and and burning down the town that live near the volcano if there's kind of a weak link in the chain of this LP though it's definitely the recording and not that it's terrible not that that's loaf I or anything like that it just doesn't really bring as much personality to the table as everything else about this album does it just kind of is some of the vocals feel muddy because of the recording are the mix here and there but luckily the band's musicianship their riffs there lyrics their hooks are just so fierce and and fun that they step past any limitations that the recording has for me it's a short solid punk album that looks backwards but doesn't feel dated has a lot of charisma a lot of things to say and I'm loving it I've had I've had a great time listening to this again and again and again feeling a light eight on this album but linked below this video on youtube and also search poor lily on the needle drop com find a link where you can download this album for yourself here the whole thing front to back and let me know what you think love it hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana poor Lily poor Lily forever but

gradual cross-draw Oh if it's humid and you know it kill yourself if it's humid and you know would kill yourself if it's humid and you know it and you really want to show it if it's humid and you know it kill yourself hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review battles is a New York quartet recently turned trio and this is their sophomore LP gloss drop and the loss of tie and a Braxton as a frontman a multi-instrumentalist in this group bred a lot of rumors about this album what is it going to sound like why our battles continuing to call themselves battles after losing such a pivotal member and of course the first single to come off of this LP ice cream featuring Matias Aguayo on vocals featured on that track only fueled flames only fueled rumors and guessing games considering a lineup change a series of guest vocalists on this album and the fact that this is a sophomore LP coming on the coattails of a very beloved first album the cards were kind of stacked against this LP battles was challenged on this record and I'm happy to say in my opinion they met that challenge for me battles have maintained those intricate and complex and experimental elements that made their first LP so appealing but they've also taken gloss drop and used it as an opportunity to almost put a friendlier and more accessible face on their music but in doing that they haven't dumbed it down this thing is a really hyper very active album it is a high-octane non stopped experimental dance rock party that just makes me want to move move move move move move move move move move move move I just want to jump around and eat candy to this album I want to try eating the pink stuff that's on the cover I want to jump around in a clown shape bouncy castle that's as big as a house it's weird to be in my mid-20s and feel that way but this album put me there and I'm thankful for that it's just got this rebellious ly youthful feel to it and yet it's so seasoned and experienced and complex there are certain subjects I like to harp on in my reviews a lot like interplay and a live feel to a band to me that kind of stuff makes a record exciting and this album has so much of that hearing these guys bounce off of each other on these tracks is a serious tree for me because they really know how to work a rhythm each track on here moves differently in the guitars the synthesizers of the drums are always figuring out different ways to dance around the tempo and interact with one another I mean John stanner puts so much heart into the way he plays drums on this LP and just in general as good as the guitars and the synthesizers are on this album the drums are really the driving force for me I love this guy's fills how subtly he builds up to certain parts in the songs and his improvisations too but the thing is everybody is improvising on this album there's so many tracks here that don't really feel like they've been written out or realized beforehand like the band is making them up as they go along Futura inchworm wall street these songs have a certain climax or a post that the band is eventually going to hit usually like a keyboard melody kind of flies in there's a breakdown and a thematic melody plays but when the band actually gets there doesn't really seem to be decided because these songs kind of progress forward as the band sees fit with every little added extra drum hit or book on the guitar or synthesizer note the song just moves an inch closer to its final destination but there are some tracks on here where battles are a little bit clearer and confined themselves to a structure maybe a pop structure or something like that an ice-cream is definitely one of those tracks which after hearing that song multiple multiple multiple times I'm pretty sure it's it's the most fun song of 2011 the the way it opens the ooh ah ish whoosh and the building circus organ synthesizers and in that bass guitar that drum beat and Matias Aguayo vocal on that one I love the effects they lay on his voice and it just kind of acts like one more polyrhythm on top of this groove in the song it is a great job here they need to work with this guy again in the future the other guest vocalists on here pretty good as well like Gary here in my car Newman he shows up on the song my machines and Gary does a great job the guy has not lost it I think my only complaint is that maybe his vocals are are pretty high in the mix if only he could have been sunken into the instrumentation a little bit more and maybe if he was given more to sing just lay more personality into the track or something like that and I kind of have a similar gripe with the next vocal feature on this with Kazuma Chino from Blonde Redhead she's got a great voice but I feel like a little bit her voice is battling with the chirping and growing keyboards that are just causing a ruckus underneath her voice I mean battles does invite these guests on here but I feel like in a way they don't really make a lot of room for some of them and Yaman taka I is on the final track of this LP and if you know that guy if you know who that guy is you can pretty much guess what he does on that track Wow but it actually fits in with what battles is doing really well on that track he's in the thick of it and making as much noises everybody else's but I do want to say even though not every vocal spot on this LP is fantastic I love that battles is doing this they need to continue doing this on future albums inviting different guests on the LP seeing what direction their personality and their voice brings the album in its very Gorillaz ish and i like it for that there are a few spots here where babbles throw some shorties on this album tracks that are like one or two minutes long and normally i would just be like the filler but i'm actually as impressed with those tracks as i am some of the other tracks on here dominican fate is so fun with all these handclaps and just that that giant bass drum and the song toddler even though that's the shortest it has the prettiest melody on here delivered by the shyest keyboards around and the song rolls bass is one of the biggest head bobbers on here the last thing i guess i can say about this LP is the recording the production way up way up just everything sounds so clear and so loud and so in my face I mean the drums are so crisp and loud on this thing it's like I'm standing in a giant room and listening to them seeing them being played right in front of me and the guitars are always in a nice spot even when they're being layered over each other whether it's with a loop pedal or multi-tracking I'm not sure but always audible and the keyboards they're just kind of sparkling shimmering bleeping and blooping over at all the album start strong finishes strong fantastic production fantastic grooves cohesive sound the volume of this album the instrumental make up for the most part of this album isn't going to be for everybody but still I'm feeling a light too decent 9 on this album really good stuff really really good stuff man despite this lineup debacle battles have maintained much of the same energy that made me fall in love with the band in the first place but what do you think do you love this do you hate it why and what do you think I should be reviewing next just with my ears let me know Anthony Fantana battles Glaus drop forever [Music] [Music]

snake-oil oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd it is really hot today it is really humid today but we still need to do it as we still need to do an album review and we're going to do one of the new snake oil LP snake oil and this is actually the first time I'm reviewing a band from my own backyard of Connecticut snake oil is a collective of ten musicians from what I've been told hailing from my state and New York and Massachusetts and even though there are a lot of cooks in on this broth the band still comes together with a pretty cohesive instrumental psych rock sound for the self-titled debut it's nine tracks 29 minutes but most of the songs here do last long enough to leave an impression on me who posted that picture of me with hair was it you are you sure well someone posted it it's just I used to have hair so what is now I just shaved my head well like I said between the nine tracks on this LP snake oil comes up with a direction it's not the most original direction in the world but still cohesive now for me easily the best thing this album has going for it the production guitar face organ drums various sound effects and studio tricks all of them come through clear as a bell and when all the sounds layer over each other on some of these tracks into this sweet sonic casserole of psychedelia I just want to shove it in my ears and try to find a way to eat it that way that guitar on the song I was a total pyro the opener to this LP listening to that for me is like wearing three sweaters in a sauna just start purse parading listening to it and that's some pretty nice groove to it too and that's the thing I like about this album a lot of great grooves the track no fear all animal is another great groove on the cell p I love the way that song moves and i love the oriental esque guitar melody bouncing over that track it's like dropping a bunch of ice cubes into an empty glass all at once there are a few quieter moments on here which go over all right like I'm song hungry Z which has a tempo maintained by a drum machine and while that sort of carries on and keeps the song constant keeps it moving the van just creates a soundscape of guitar feedback and cymbal crashes but I think my favorite softer moment here is siedel in the salt flats one of the tracks toward the end of this LP and that song to me as a sense of place more than any other track here listening to that is kind of like wandering through the desert into some kind of kaleidoscopic horizon with swirling clouds and multicolored buzzards and tumbleweeds I love the beat it starts off with and when that first guitar comes in its whoa but i'm not completely in love with this LP i do have my reservations about it there are a lot of points here where it doesn't rock and i don't mean like there are softer moments here i don't mean there are quieter tracks i mean the latter songs at some moments feel way too rigid in mechanical constrained take the track can of love and the captain for example the riff on that track that drops it around the two minute mark i kind of feel like at that point a bomb should be going off but at best it just kind of sounds like a firecracker it's just the band is latching on to this really constant tempo and they're not really moving together as a unit on some parts of this album just sometimes where the drums are going and where the rest of the instrumentation is going seems like a different place so some of the instrumentals here do come off sounding like sugar-coated psychedelics like they would soundtrack a scene where a character is doing drugs in an after-school special or like I can see them going over pretty well in an elevator like a trippy elevator there are a few spots here where snake oil feels like they're letting go getting a little noisier like on the last track or go center but it's just not enough for me I want to be overwhelmed damn you still the sound the recording a lot of the melodies the grooves are all pretty good on this album and for the most part the textures here really shoot for something similar to dumbo gets mad or even black moth super rainbow without all the fuzz and weird vocals it's not amazing me but it's a solid debut there are links below this video on YouTube and on the needle drop com or you can hear cuts of this record this thing is self released the band is selling the vinyl and the digital on their website let me know what you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I be reviewing next Anthony Fantana snake oil / you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd I do not dress up before my video reviews because I'm about to go on a job interview I just dress up because I want to it's nice to look nice it's time for an album review Woods Sun and shade Brooklyn's Woods is a band who over the past couple years I fell for really hard abrir house songs of shame at Echo Lake every single album I heard was just loaded with these creepy depressing lo-fi folk tunes loaded with noises and effects and fronted by Jeremy Earl's very distinct falsetto vocal and i freaking loved it I couldn't get enough woods just wrote such catchy songs on those albums and to me they have a pretty original sound they definitely have some Grateful Dead love going on and they're not the first band to experiment with folk music but they have a style that I couldn't see myself getting anywhere else in the nutshell that's addiction but I think I started to worry just a little bit when at Echo Lake dropped a few tunes on there sounded extremely similar to songs the band had already released and some other songs on there just felt kind of unfinished just ended abruptly so now I've got woods latest LP Sun and shade and this might be one of my biggest letdowns of 2011 like all of my worst fears confirmed the issue I had with a echo lake where songs were kind of abrupt felt just unfinished or just kind of ducking out before I get a real impression of them is increased on here say goodbye any other day what faces the sheet and the LPS overall length is a little misleading since its padded out with 27 29 minute instrumentals the first of which is pretty good out of the I just has this really patient repetitive hypnotic rhythm and flow it kind of feels like psycho delek folky krautrock pretty cool while Soliz ambra starts off pretty interestingly very dark very soft but it just kind of ends up underwhelming me and feeling like it's really not going anywhere it's just kind of like overall both of these instrumental tracks just aren't as electrifying as other instrumental moments I've heard these guys pull together like September with Pete on top of that there are some songs on here that just sound to me to be too close for comfort two songs woods has already released like handed out and pushing only but still there are a handful of tracks pretty good tracks on here where woods does make an attempt to write themselves out of their comfort zone to broaden their horizons to have in the home and what faces the sheet are like two of the sunniest songs these guys have written beforehand I always pictured myself listening to these guys in the forest at night or in like a haunted house or something but now some of these songs are more fit for a bunch of hippies dancing in a field of flowers in the middle of July which has a very liberating vibe to it but on the other end of the spectrum the song wouldn't waste is easily one of the most bleak and painful songs these guys have ever tried to pen but you know what the thing is even this album's brightest moments to me feel kind of dull the playing is a little messy or less enthusiastic maybe and I know the noisiness of woods has always been kind of a selling point of the band's music but some of the guitar parts on here could have used a second take the vocals too and honestly one of my biggest pet peeves in music happens on this album one of the best songs on here one of the catchiest and most memorable songs is the cover there's a cover of the song who do I think I am on this album and I hate it when the best song and an album is the cover or the song that I like the most at least but it wasn't always like that these guys covered graham Nash's military madness on songs of shame but in my opinion the other material on the album measured up I mean I was excited about this I thought I was going to love this but the only thing that kind of happened for me was that all the things I didn't like about at Echo Lake were magnified and spread across this album one thing I will say I like overall about this LP is woods makes a noticeable effort to brighten their music a little bit alter the mood make music that's a little bit more upbeat and I love the idea of them doing that there are a few great moments on here some decent ones but this LPS just kind of slumped by a bunch of material that I'm just never ever going to want to return to hopefully coucher jesta can bring some kind of silver lining to this cloud of sadness no hang out nothing I feel empty inside I'm feeling a strong 52 ally 6 on thing why and what do you think I should be reviewing next in the video brain talk needle drop thing vlog youtube channel forever you
