havock hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's trashiest music nerd here with something that's going to take you guys off no no it's not a rap review takes you guys off more than that it's a metal review Havok is a denver band that proudly relives the sounds of old-school thrash metal and I'm not a thrash expert I don't pretend to be I know my early Exodus my early big for Bam Bam Bam Bam and I also like a lot of crossover acts too like DRI suicidal tendencies and crow bags and for me Havoc's time up is just as enjoyable as some of thrash metals classics I listen to times up because I want to listen to time is up not because I want to get nostalgic and think of peace cells or Master of Puppets like any good thrash record this thing is an overwhelming dose of sonic testosterone because when this thing is on I want to punch stuff I want to run around I want to climb on things I want to blow things up the energy on this thing is non freaking stopped for the most part and maybe that's almost to a fault because even some of thrashes best records had a slower moment of to some kind of semblance of balladry you know like a breather a break but pretty much every tune here is a lean and mean three to five minute thrash fest the song DOA has some pretty nice harmonized guitar solos in trowing the song and the title track takes a little while to take off but every other song here hits hard and hits fast like a blitzkrieg or like a thrash krieg which is fitting because some of the lyrics here are about war international war and also two-faced scumbags and throwing your life away because you're living too fast during some of these lyrical moments I feel like the the frontman David Sanchez is like singing directly to me and it kind of freaks me out for a second like on time is up where he's like take a number and have a seat we'll be with you shortly not only is that awesome but I kind of feel like he's somehow figured out how to channel Dave Mustaine or something and I love David Sanchez vocals not only because of his vocal delivery but just the way his voice sounds it's like this high-pitched raspy kind of thing in a way it kind of sounds like a bottle rocket going off or maybe a more intense version of overkill and every once in a while he'll pull out this high-pitched wail that's very King Diamond desk so the vocals do come off versatile because they do everything well whether they're shouting or talking or singing or doing these really big gang vocals that emphasize the hook from time to time and as far as mix and recording and sound goes I really can't fault this record on much of anything maybe the guitars are a little too loud maybe the bass could be brought up in the mix I mean I know for example I loved the fact that the bass brought so much counterpoint on another modern thrash record vector's black future even though I don't get much of that here the guitar tone is still really nice and the drums on this thing are extremely just pounding an intricate I mean the drummer's always thrown in all sorts of fills and yet he never loses track of the groove or anything like that back to the guitar one thing we need to talk about with the guitar the solos on this thing which play a huge part in thrash metal they're all very tight straight to the point flashy while they're there but they don't devour the entire song Banshee note bends and just a flawless sweet picking and these whammy bar whales that sometimes kind of sound like a laser melting my brain my only other complaint is that there's not really a break on here so a lot of the tracks this thing can come off kind of say me say me in terms of blueprint Wow even though the tools the havoc uses on this album are tried-and-true that doesn't mean they don't use them well like you know juggling the art of juggling is ancient but if you came across somebody juggling grenades and and chainsaws would you say of juggling so old it's been done whatever I really love this album and I don't think you need to be an old-school thrash metal aficionado to enjoy it I think this LP goes far far far beyond nostalgia if you enjoy music that has really intense drumming great grooves and guitar riffs technical guitar solos and a ton of aggression then this is where you want to be I'm feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this record I had a hell of a time listening to it it was fun every single time I went through the album can't wait to listen to it again Anthony Fantana havoc time is up forever

well hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review music is kind of like food because at first when I was thinking of reviewing this album partially because of how many requests I've gotten um I kind of felt like a kid sitting at a table and it was dinnertime and with my parents and they're trying to force-feed me with something in a spoon that I want to eat and I'm like mmm hmm and I'm sure there are some of you out there who can sympathize I'm sure some of you just hate Death Cab for Cutie on principle but if you're more like me maybe you fell off the bandwagon when plans came out in 2005 and to be completely honest I have not listened to that album since it came out I mean I real issen to it for this review but I really don't see why my negative reaction was so strong at the time I mean they definitely did change their sound after Transatlanticism but not in the worst way possible it was slower more mellow more baladi I guess maybe at the time it was just a change I was bored by plus on plans the band made the move to Atlantic Records which at the time was still a no-no still a no-no for indie bands they're going mainstream the mainstream should be so lucky so screw me for falling off the wagon with these guys I'm not in love with Death Cab for Cutie anymore mmm but still I tried gave this album an honest shot and why not it's been over five years since I've listened to a Death Cab album the week it was released I'm not in the same place I was back then the band's not in the same place they were back then why not so I went to listen to this album assuming that I would be pissed off and earning guard by nearly everything that I was going to hear but after many listens to this album I couldn't find a single thing that offended my ears about it really and I think that's mostly because this LP is too earnest it's too honest it's too comfortable with itself to be doing things that are loud or flamboyant just to grab attention it's a simple and straightforward album that's completely devoid of any and all cynicism it's like having a person come up behind you and say hey you're really cool and nice and smart and I like you and you know you just kind of turn around you're like what's wrong with you in your head but then you kind of realize oh wait this person's like serious they're being nice oh nice nice Ness a weird analogy I know even though Ben Gibbard and the guys are getting old this album still feels really young to me the recording is crisp and bright the instrumentation and the lyrics are devoid of the complications and adults might try to throw into them and even though Ben doesn't sing exactly the same way he used to his voice still sounds really light and pleasant now there are some spots on this LP where I think Death Cab writes some of the catchiest songs they have in a while like Monday morning and underneath the Sycamore but I think my favorite track here is you are a tourist which has this this really positive melody and vibe just emanating off of it just radiates nice feeling it's got lots of lyrics about hearts and and burning and the way Ben sings on this track and the way he repeats this simple melody over and over just kind of reminds me of like folk songs or something like that or a sing-along I just kind of in my head I see a group of people singing this little light of mine I'm gonna let it shine this little light of mine the band does experiment a little bit on some of these tracks but the whole album is so low-key that I remember when I was first listening to it these moments just really kind of blew by me I'm thinking of a track like doors unlocked and open which is really rigid really kind of mid-tempo and reminds me of like krautrock maybe even the same direction that Magua was taking their latest album in and while we're talking about songs that sound like other songs the title track codes and keys the piano the the way the song moobs sounds little suburbs ish and while I'm complaining Ben Gibbard x'v ice on this the way he sings I guess he just doesn't have as much inflection or emotion in his voice as he used to he just flatly delivers these same vocal melodies over and over and without making any alterations to them melodically or emotionally but still that didn't really ruin any of these songs for me at worst at worst this album was underwhelming underwhelming and even though I wish these guys would stop using electronics in their songs when I hear a little sequence a little rhythm here or there or something like that that's generated electronically or in effect or a string arrangement it's not like it takes over the whole song it's not like it swallows the song all of the additions around these songs are very quiet very subtle and I like that it doesn't distract it complements maybe light 7 on this overall it's a pretty solid record Death Cab for Cutie chooses a sound and then creates 11 songs within that sound that overall are pretty enjoyable and to me that's what makes a pretty good record even though this is not going to be one of my favorites of the year I'm surprised I enjoyed a Death Cab album again this much but what do you think of this thing did you love it did you hate it and why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana Death Cab for Cutie codes and keys forever you you

London bloggers holiday I need a haircut I need a shave I need to sleep hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and I'm sorry this video is late today you know I was just up very late with a lot of you and a blog TV which was fun you know with kouchuu chess stud and mike 555 and sad sad robot I just had to sleep late today everything is off now the website got updated late kouchuu chesta is is free so i'm going to take it easy today with an EP review of Theophilus london's lover's holiday this guy's a Brooklyn emcee this EP came out toward the beginning of this year but he actually has a new LP coming out by the middle of this summer I think mr. London isn't doing anything terribly innovative in fact it's been done before combining rap music with pop but for some reason this musical style is finally starting to catch on in the indie community with artists like Kanye West Drake and Kid Cudi but if you guys watch the channel you know that I like Kanye stuff not in love with it and I'm not really a Cudi or a Drake fan I mean while they're more upbeat songs are nice I just have a really hard time relating to them when they try to get depressing and sad and upset like what's wrong seriously Theophilus is a lot less prone to mood swings and the way he combines rap and pop is with a lot of synthesizers a lot of female backup vocals and New Wave era drum machines it's just reminding me of all these different things but no one single thing like radio pop from the 80s and early LL Cool J singles and 80s electro like Afrika Bambaataa and the soul sonic force and West Street mob weird comparison I know but it's not like rigid funkified rap music theos instrumentals are very clean very detailed very smooth they have that modern Sheen to them even though there are aspects of them that are kind of retro check the beyond the opening track why even try just these glistening synthesizers bouncing on the tempo a really nice rhythmic bass line squawking synthesizers over the chorus guest vocals from Sarah Quinn and Theo proves that he can sing as well as rap which you know is nice singing can kind of be the downfall for some rappers who want to be taken seriously as singers Theo doesn't come off in this song or really any of these songs honestly as a spitter or highly lyrical and he doesn't try to and that's that's not really the point I don't think it's more about the sentiment it's more about the songwriting it's more about the melody in the groove and the chord progression and all of those things are great I love the way the chorus on this track just escalates in a really heavenly fashion a lot of contrasts between that and the verse and the bridge is great too I mean I'm not getting a lot of songs here but what songs are here are really well-crafted the New Wave influences get turned up on wine and chocolates and Strangelove but the song girls girls money is more fit for like the club I could totally see that getting DJed and yeah the title in the hook are pretty ridiculous but it's not like the song gets so tacky it's hard for me to handle now I'm sure that you could charge the song with you know being shallow maybe a lack of depth or something like that but my favorite track is the last one here flying overseas which is easily the sexiest song on this album a nice really heavy beat this this this warm bass just you know and I love how slow this song moves and when Theo wraps on this thing man he's just bleeding coolness everywhere it's getting all over the place it's a biohazard it's gonna get on me I really like how the verses simmer before the chorus finally comes on they really string it out and when it does it just explodes it's pretty much like having sex in the dark with your ears I love where this thing is I love where Theo is going with his music and even though he's not the only person making pop rap out there today he's definitely making something I clearly clearly prefer over a majority of what I've been hearing I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this EP recommended a lot let me know what you think of it there are links where you can hear it below this video and yeah what do you think I should review next on this to YouTube channel where I do reviews with my brain Anthony Fantana the Ovilus London lovers holiday forever you

My Morning Jacket hello and my needle drops it's been a while since I called you that Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd it is hot as hell today I've been chillaxing and relaxin all day and now I'm ready to do this review My Morning Jacket cerca del sur kiddo circuit circuital alright so right now we're in a review that I was really really excited to do my first My Morning Jacket review these guys are a kentucky 5-piece who carry a lot of weight when it comes to alternative country music folk rock because of past records like at dawn and z but all my excitement has kind of built up to this album that i don't really love even though at first when i was listening to this thing it seemed like that was gonna happen but one thing i can say about this LP is that it has those simple but very important things that make great records like lots of interplay between the musicians just a great mix a live feel no matter what the band no matter what the style of music there's a noticeable difference between just multi-tracked separated instruments following a tempo in a band playing together just look at the opening track on this LP victory dance just as this this growing morphing evolving groove as the song trudges on and I love how huge and ambitious and in the moment the title track sounds - I might not totally be in love with Jim James vocals but that song is really well structured has tons of nooks and crannies - and things get really beautiful on my favorite track here wonderful which is just kind of about having a great state of mind I just love the sentiment of the song I love the finger pick guitar I love the background vocals I love the strings just wrapping around the song a certain points of it but I think the superlative for cutest song on this album should go - out of my system which even though it doesn't have giant group harmonies of group vocal harmonies on the track it reminds me so fitness so much of a Beach Boys song because of the the reverb on the vocals the sunny guitars and the subject matter on this track kind of reminds me of just coming of age which a lot of Beach Boys songs do for me it's a track about doing drugs stealing cars basically do anything that is bad wrong or will get you landed in jail simply because you know even though these things may get you in trouble with the law some people have to do these things have to do something dangerous have to explore do something exciting to get it out of their system or else maybe you end up growing up with a lot of regrets it's just a moment on this album where My Morning Jacket is trying to have a good time with our music and make a funny observation and it helps here it helps but what's funny is that to me it hurts on the very next track of this album the song holdin on the black metal kind of ironically deals with how misunderstood black metal is and its effect on kids and its message and Lucifer and I get the impression from the lyrics My Morning Jacket feels that black metal is kind of something you should grow out of and I think the idea of growing out of a certain kind of music is universal for all music fans I mean there's a ton of music I haven't enjoyed since like ninth grade but I can't help but feel like the message on this song is just kind of condescending just a little bit and I feel like this is the first time the irony of a song has really ticked me off and made me feel like man this this just backfired a lot of people complain about irony and music oh this is so ironic but making a statement about black metal with a kids choir and sultry horn hits and a moody melody and falsetto vocals just had my eyes rolling again and again I thought they were just gonna fall out of my head my issue with every track after that song really has to do with kind of the songwriting because all the chord progressions the melodies on these on the second half of the album are really really borrowed tried and true influenced familiar which isn't a bad thing everybody is borrowing from something else it's just that the question comes up in my head does My Morning Jacket make these chord progressions these melodies exciting for me again do they kill it slow slow tune makes a pretty funny observation but it's not like I'm dying to revisit it and moving away just drags on forever to me this LP is just extremely extremely extremely front-loaded in terms of enjoyability effort ambition so because of that I'm extremely torn and extremely on the fence feeling a strong five to a light six on this record really love to the first half and that's where I am on this record where you want it how do you feel about it love it hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana My Morning Jacket circuital forever
